name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, common values such as human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights are the cornerstone of the European Union. Each Member State must therefore respect, protect and promote them.  After the debates in January and September 2016, this is the third time that the Council has been asked to intervene in this House on the situation in Poland. The continued debate on these issues shows again that the protection and promotion of the rule of law and human rights are a constant challenge. This challenge requires unwavering attention and efforts across different policy areas. The Presidency – and, indeed, all of us – agree that the protection of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in our Union cannot be taken for granted. We also agree that there is never a time to be complacent about the state of fundamental rights protection in Europe. Our core values are put to the test every day as we are facing multiple interrelated crises, be they in the area of migration or internal security. Ensuring the rule of law is an absolute priority and has to be our joint commitment, of the Member States and EU institutions together. Equally, fundamental rights need to be upheld and defended as our best guarantee for sustaining stable, open and free societies.  Only one month ago, on 12 October, the Justice and Home Affairs Council had an exchange of views with the Director of the Fundamental Rights Agency, Michael O’Flaherty, on the priorities in the protection of fundamental rights. After this debate, the Council adopted conclusions on the application of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights in 2016. These conclusions reaffirmed that democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights lay down the foundation of the European Union and our societies.  A few days later, on 17 October, the Council held its annual Rule of Law Dialogue. This year, the specific focus was on media pluralism and the rule of law in the digital age. Let me assure you that the rule of law, including the independence of the judiciary and the balance of powers, are at the heart of our concerns, and the EU is not alone. Our strongest partner is the Council of Europe, which is fully engaged in the promotion, protection and development of human rights and the rule of law.  According to our information, the Polish authorities are in contact with both the Venice Commission and the European Commission, following the opinions and recommendations issued. The Council has already been informed twice about the situation in Poland by First Vice—President Timmermans, and I am looking forward to the update he will now present to us on the latest developments. From the Council side, it is worth mentioning that on 11 July this year, the Ecofin Council adopted country—specific recommendations in the context of the 2017 European Semester, of which one specific recommendation concerning Poland addressed the issue of the rule of law. The issues raised go to the heart of our commitment to the Union. We therefore trust that all sides will act responsibly and constructively to reach a swift solution that leaves no doubt about our core values.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to start by thanking this Parliament for its strong engagement on this issue, and especially the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, which I had the honour to update on the issue on 6 November. It is not my intention to repeat everything I said then, it would take too much time, but let me start by saying that an issue pertaining to the rule of law never affects only the country concerned: it affects the whole construction of the European Union. That is the basis upon which I believe this Parliament’s engagement is so important. I want to recall that on 26 July the Commission adopted a third Rule of Law Recommendation addressed to the Polish authorities. This was necessary after four laws adopted by the Sejm would have had a very significant negative impact on the independence of the Polish judiciary and would have increased the systemic threat to the rule of law. Two of the four laws were sent back to parliament by the President of the Republic. The recommendation also recalled the situation of a systemic threat to the rule of law, resulting from the changes to the Constitutional Tribunal, which have led to a serious undermining of its independence and legitimacy as the result of its complete recomposition, contrary to the normal constitutional process for the appointment of judges. Moreover, the Polish executive persists in its refusal to publish a number of the Tribunal’s rulings. Unfortunately, the Polish reply regarding the third recommendation did not announce any concrete measures to address the issues raised by the Commission. We have now sent four letters to the Polish authorities since July, inviting them to meet. Sadly, these invitations were not accepted. I have not had the opportunity to talk to Polish Ministers about the issue. So our exchanges have essentially been in writing. That said, my invitation still stands, and I hope I can have a dialogue with the Ministers of Justice or Foreign Affairs as soon as possible. In parallel to the Rule of Law Recommendation, the Commission has also initiated infringement proceedings in relation to the Polish Law on the Common Courts Organisation, which discriminates against individuals on the basis of gender. This is contrary to Article 157 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and to the 2006 Directive on Gender Equality in Employment. In our reasoned opinion, the Commission also raised the issue that giving the Minister of Justice discretionary power to prolong the term of office of judges who have reached retirement age, as well as discretionary power to dismiss and appoint court presidents, would undermine the independence of Polish courts. To be very clear: the Minister of Justice in Poland is also Chief Prosecutor and the Chief Prosecutor now has full discretionary powers to appoint and dismiss presidents of courts. Just let this sink in for a moment. The Commission understands that, on the basis of this law, a considerable number of court presidents have already been dismissed. The Commission is currently finalising its assessment of the Polish authorities’ reply, with a view to deciding on the next step. President Duda also presented two new draft laws on the Supreme Court and on the National Council for the Judiciary. The Commission is now analysing these new draft laws very carefully and will follow closely the related developments. At this preliminary stage of our assessment, the Commission already notes that certain issues in connection with the new draft laws could raise serious concerns. The Commission will continue to assess these issues thoroughly and objectively, including in the light of the Venice Commission opinions which will be forthcoming in December. The Commission is not alone in its assessment of the gravity of the situation. Other critical opinions have been issued on the draft laws, not only in Poland by the Supreme Court, the Council for the Judiciary and the ombudsman, but also at European and international level. I would refer to the recent opinions of the European Network of Councils for the Judiciary and the Consultative Council of European Judges. I would refer, too, to the preliminary observations by the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the independence of judges and lawyers, who also takes the view that the independence of the judiciary is under serious threat in Poland today, and has expressed serious concerns about the two draft laws on the Supreme Court and the National Council for the Judiciary. Every Member State carrying out judicial reforms must respect the rule of law as one of the fundamental values to which all Member States signed up when joining the EU. It is up to the Member States to organise their justice systems, including whether to establish a council for the judiciary, or not. However, where such a council has been established to safeguard judicial independence, as in the Polish constitution, the independence of that council must be guaranteed, in line with European standards. So let me recall for the record what it is that the Commission expects from the Polish authorities to avoid further escalation. First, the Polish authorities should restore the independence and legitimacy of the Constitutional Tribunal as guarantor of the Polish Constitution. Second, the Polish authorities should bring the Law on the Common Courts Organisation into line with Union law by abolishing gender discrimination and by abolishing the Minister of Justice’s influence on judges through the retirement regime and the dismissal or appointment of court presidents. Third, the Polish authorities should bring the law on the National School of Judiciary into line with European standards on the independence of the judiciary by eliminating external influence on assistant judges, notably, again, by the Minister of Justice. And finally, the Polish authorities should bring the two new draft laws on the Supreme Court and on the National Council for the Judiciary, proposed by President Duda, fully into line with EU law and with European standards on the independence of the judiciary and the status of councils for the judiciary. The legislative process on these two draft laws, which is about to commence, will provide a key test for the Polish authorities, to show to the outside world whether or not there is willingness to respect the rule of law and take full account of the Commission’s concerns and the forthcoming opinions of the Venice Commission. The Commission is looking for real, constructive dialogue in order to redress the situation in Poland with regard to the rule of law. This Parliament’s support for our efforts is essential if we want to succeed.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - It is the fifth time that the European Parliament reacts to the abuse of power in Poland, because this is what this debate is about. What I feel today, I will express in the words of my compatriot, who recently committed a desperate act of self-immolation in the center of Warsaw: "I am ashamed that I have to explain to my Western friends that Poland is not the same as the Polish government." The source of this debate lies in the Polish government, in the abuse of the mandate, which was won in democratic elections, but it would probably be weaker if people knew that they were voting not only for a wide distribution of money - which helps the poor, but debts the country - but that they also vote on trampling on the constitutional order, an independent judiciary, and even cutting down the last existing forest in Europe, but also on prosecuting participants of peaceful demonstrations, as well as tolerating manifestations of xenophobia, racism and neo-fascism on our streets. It is all very clearly visible. This cannot be hidden. Some new iron veil will not come down. Polish democracy is doing well only in the imaginary world created by the media, also appropriated, which have become the mouthpiece of government propaganda. But this imaginary world ends where your daily brainwashing ends. In fact, no government has ever so quickly ruined the international position of its own country, has so quickly and so painfully compromised its country on the international stage. And it is about Poland, which we could be very proud of as a collective work of Poles, reaching for the highest positions in the European Union, the greatest funds, influence, and translating its ideas into European Union programs, such as the Eastern Partnership, and the energy union. The question arises about the future of Polish women and Poles, and it is not only about respect, image, money and influence, but about safety. Today's loneliness of Poland, the self-exclusion of Poland, is completely contrary to the Polish raison d'état and the lesson that history has taught us. Because it's like someone he asked that the curse of Polish fate, the curse of Polish geopolitics, would return. Free and democratic Poland has friends in a free and democratic European community, not in Turkey or Belarus. The free world, the democratic world stands up for Poland as a member of its own family, it stands up in the name of the principles which hide wisdom through trial and error. The wisdom of how to organize a free society to protect civil liberties from dictatorship, how to organize a good economy that thinks about the next generations. These are the principles of our constitution and EU treaties. Whoever breaks them takes away people's freedom at first, but in the end may also take people's future. The current ruling camp has a certain inconvenience when we recall how it behaved when it was the opposition, how gladly it was here, in the European Parliament, he initiated various hearings, interrogations, which, moreover, had no meaning, because they were unreliable and relied on untruth. But then the current PiS MP - the ruling party - cheerfully tweeted (it was December 2014): “It is good that the opposition organized a public hearing in the European Parliament on the threat to democracy (that is, they initiated it). We are in the Union, this is also our Parliament. " Yes, this is our European Union, this is our Parliament, but we are not looking forward to these debates because we do not want to be ashamed of the rulers of Poland. We want pride in our country to come back.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address the Polish citizens directly, our Polish citizen friends. I am well aware that your government will try to pass this debate off as yet another attempt to rage against Poland. It's false. We love your people and we love your nation. We have done everything possible, as Vice-President Frans Timmermans pointed out, to keep the dialogue open with the Polish authorities, and we continue to do so today, as Timmermans said, ready for dialogue. But dialogue is divided into two, and if there is deafness on one side it is difficult to make a dialogue. We are always open to discussion, as long as the principle on which our living together is based is not questioned. First principle: freedom, democracy and the rule of law. The European Union is not a restaurant, which one enters and serves à la carte, but it is a democracy that lives, it is a community of values ​​to which all its members are bound. This morning I would have liked to discuss how to defend the rights of Polish citizens in the face of the consequences of Brexit, how to prevent many young Poles from having to leave their country to go abroad, and instead we are all hostages of the Polish government, which does not he comes to Brussels to deal with the problems of his citizens and continues to provoke us with an attitude of closure. I ask the Polish authorities: you say you represent the majority of Poland - you have had the votes, yes certainly - but your fellow citizens have never given you any mandate to attack the independence of the Constitutional Tribunal, to reduce the autonomy of the judiciary, so why do you do this? The real truth is that your attempts to undermine the independence of the judiciary are a weapon of mass distraction from the difficulties you face in government. You lied to your constituents and you don't want to confront you on concrete problems. But behind your projects there is also another thing, another deeper thing. There is contempt for liberal democracy, hostility towards human rights and constitutional rules, the cult of the law of the strongest, and seeing the streets of Warsaw manned by far-right squads last Saturday reminded me of the darkest pages in European history. To all Poles, to those who oppose this government today, but also to those who voted for it, to all Poles I say that we will not leave you alone. The Socialist and Democratic Group with its Polish delegation is close to the Polish people. We are not against Poland, we are against deviating from the linear path of a rule of law. We want this path to be corrected. We want Poland to fully experience its being a central member of the European Union. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: blue-card question. – My question to Mr Pittella is: caro Presidente, would it not be better for you to tackle the real problems of your political family, the Socialists, and of your caro amico the Prime Minister of Malta, Mr Muscat, rather than the fictitious problems of Poland?

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: answer to a "blue card" question.- It is really ridiculous to compare the situation in Malta to the situation in Poland, and to compare the situation of the Maltese Prime Minister, who has always given his willingness, concretely, to dialogue with the European institutions, to be present in the European Parliament and to correct defectsand the problems in Malta with the situation in Poland.So we don't compare!This too is a distraction weapon from real problems.Putting Malta and Poland on the same level is a false history.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! As a man a bit experienced in politics, I thought there was a limit to shamelessness, but after what I heard from my colleague Lewandowski, I change my mind: there is no limit to shamelessness. Well, you can fall even lower than the Lord fell today, telling these incredible things. I just can't figure out so far that there's really no inner moral control, that you can say such gross, untrue things. Outrageous! Please state! As for the substantive answer regarding the reform of the judiciary and contacts between the Polish government and the European Commission, I sent it to your mailboxes. You have very detailed, precise information on this subject. If any of you want to engage in a dispute with me on this subject, I am of course open. However, here in this room, as during the previous editions, it is not really about any dialogue. This is not a debate. Well, let's face it - this is another Orwellian screening. This is a show of strength in relation to the Poles and the Polish government. This is not about the rule of law. It's not about values, it's about power, right, who has the power. This is another version of the same. After all, a few or several hours after the announcement of the bills on the judiciary, our colleague Weber and other MPs had already launched a pan-European, anti-Polish campaign. After all, Mr. Weber does not speak Polish. He did not know the content of these laws. He did not know any expert opinions. He wasn't interested at all, but he already knew. Just a couple of hours and we have to launch this wave, this next crusade against the Polish government. Besides, the socialists did the same, the liberals did the same. Is this an invitation to a debate? This is not an invitation to debate. Do not kid yourself. You have some obsession, some persistent compulsion when it comes to the Polish government, right? You could see you keep coming back to it. (Applause) Come on people, have mercy. This is also an example of the incredible arrogance that is widespread among the political elite in Western Europe, not to mention the media. Well, the German media. I do not know what to call it, what is written there about Poland. This is some anti-Polish orgy, or simply dyrdymały. These are complete dyrdymales. It's such a Niagara of lies that instead of six and a half minutes, I'd have to be six and a half months to get it all straight. Well, I can't do that. Or the barbaric behavior of the German Defense Minister. Just like, without trying, Soviet diplomats, too, did pledge to help their friends in the satellite countries. Or President Macron's statements about Poland and other Eastern European countries. These are some of the ... I see in this the old colonial habits that show up here. And this Eastern Europe suddenly dares to do something, right, to decide about itself, amazing, without our knowledge. Please acknowledge that the process of empowerment in Eastern Europe is taking place and that you, I do not know what you have been doing or not doing here, will continue. As for the Commission, President Timmermans, I have actually said everything in previous debates. Please don't tell me here that the Lord represents the law, that the Lord represents values. All these actions of the Commission against Poland are unlawful actions which violate European treaties. And the fact that these actions are stuck here in Parliament does not make them any less unlawful. You have the majority here. You can vote anything you want, even if two plus two is five. But the truth is, these are illegal activities. These are also - I have spoken about it many times - these are the double standards that are inherently associated with your name in Poland. You are a party to an internal conflict in Poland and you do not hide it, do you? When various bad things happened in Poland, then The Lord was silent. When bad things happened in Spain, you spoke here in such a way that it was not really known what you were talking about. If a tenth of the things that happened in Spain are happening in Poland now, you would change here into Saint George who fights the dragon. (Applause) The Commission, unfortunately, has this bad habit of simply ignoring all the responses of the Polish government and repeating the same thing over and over again. The Commission calls it a dialogue or an invitation to talk. Mr. President, this is not a dialogue. This is not an invitation to talk. There is a concept that suits this. This is an ultimatum. You say: it has to be done, and if not - you will be punished. It's more or less a dialogue, right, Commission style. This is what Shakespeare called the insolence of office, right? This is the insolence of the offices or the insolence of the authorities. You can do anything. You believe that you can say anything and command everything. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen! It won't really hurt Poland. We dealt with bigger problems. It harms the Union. This means that if we collected all the anti-EU diatribes that fell here in this House, they would do less damage to the image of the Union than your speeches. That is, the Lord has done more than Nigel Farage and Marine Le Pen put together to destroy the image of the European Union. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I would like to say that the way to avoid this type of debate is not to destroy the Constitutional Tribunal, not to destroy the independence of judges, common courts and not to comply with the orders of the Court of Justice.Therefore, my question to Mr. Legutka is: do you treat the European Union as a cash cow from which only money can be squeezed, or rather as a community of law in which we are bound by the same civilizational, Western values?

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- No, we do not treat the European Union as a cash cow.I don't know what else to say.As for the tribunal, I would like to remind you that you and your party wanted to take over the tribunal completely and place all their nominees, fourteen out of fifteen members, but then Mr. Timmermans did not notice it somehow.Truth?If your political friends do outrageous things, you don't see it.The Lord did not notice.I have not heard.Did you say a word about it?The Lord did not say.You may smile, yes, mockingly and indulgently, but the Lord did not say.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to ask Mr Legutko why he doesn’t stay for the debate.  (Mr Legutko left the Chamber) Why are you leaving, Mr Legutko? Because I have something to say to you. I have to say something to you. Your attack on Mr Lewandowski I find outrageous. (Interjections from the floor) If there is one sensible, reasonable, colleague of ours, sometimes even a little bit boring, then it is Mr Lewandowski. And to say that he has lost his senses, well, I think it is the Polish Government that has lost its senses and not Mr Lewandowski. (Applause) Mr President, on Saturday 60 000 fascists marched in the streets of Warsaw – neo-Nazis, white supremacists – and I’m not talking about Charlottesville in America, I’m talking about Warsaw, Poland, 300 km more or less from Auschwitz and Birkenau. Well, I have to tell you, I thought that it should never happen in Europe, and that it should never happen also in Poland; certainly not in Poland, because we do not have to give lessons to Poland. That’s not the point. It’s the place where, before Magna Carta, before Habeas corpus, there were free cities, a beacon of creativity and of freedom. It is the country that liberated itself from two authoritarianisms, from fascism and communism, and they did it alone.  And at the same time it is also, since their entrance into the European Union, a country that was really at the heart of Central and Eastern European democracy, and moreover also of economic growth, before Germany. So there is nothing to say about Poland – we are not attacking Poland. What we are attacking and what is being said is that over the last two years there has been a government, and behind that government there is a personality, Mr Kaczyński, who thinks that he can copy someone – and I apologise to the PPE Group – namely Mr Orbán, who also thinks that he has to establish illiberal states everywhere in the European Union. To copy Mr Orbán is, I think, not in the interests of Poland and Polish society and Polish citizens. And that is the point of our intervention today.  And unfortunately, in this case, we will ask you, Mr President, to activate Article 7 – and not, I have to tell you very clearly, to punish any Polish citizens. That is not the point. My proposal is even that, when we have sanctions, the European money should go directly to Polish cities, to Polish civil societies and to Polish citizens, because we can never allow Polish citizens to be the victims of this reactionary agenda of the Polish Government and of Mr Kaczyński. (Applause) (The speaker declined to answer a blue-card question from Ms Gosiewska)

name: Marek JUREK
text: - ... with an unacceptable allusion to the Auschwitz camp, which was once again spoken by Mr Verhofstadt, I am asking the Presidium of our Parliament to deal with his statements.This hate speech must finally end.Thank you very much!

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address my Polish colleagues and in particular the representatives of the ruling party. I would like them to understand that we are not punishing a member country, that we respect the multiple sovereignties of which the Union will increasingly have to be composed. The reason why we will adopt a third resolution on Poland is to remember together the reasons that keep us united, the legal foundations that all member countries have signed up to. I mean the rule of law in the deepest sense of the term. I invite you to read recital E of the resolution. The rule of law is distinct from the rule by law. Rule by law means government by law, where the law is the act used by those who exercise power on the basis of a parliamentary majority. Rule of law is a notion in which a substantial concept of law enters, as a set of fundamental rights, independence of judges, separation of powers, free expression, rights of refugees and women. Whoever wins the elections obeys this set of rights, does not grant them. Once elected to this Parliament, we all have the task of representing all citizens of the Union, without distinction of nationality or constituency, and at the same time the primary duty to ensure that the foundations of citizenship, fundamental rights and freedoms, are fully guaranteed. By asking for Article 7 (1) to be activated, we are asking for nothing more than to honor this commitment and to take responsibility for continuing open dialogue with the government of a Member State. On the other hand, it is the only instrument that the Treaty has given us as a Parliament.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Debates on fundamental rights and the rule of law often run very high in this Parliament. Somewhere in the debate someone comes and says that there are two measures. That it is a political game. That one country is tackled and the other is not. That the ruling party still has a majority in Parliament and that all decisions are therefore democratic. Also, someone will say that changes to the constitution, the composition of the Supreme Court or the financing of newspapers in another Member State are regulated in exactly the same way. And then someone really gets blazing because the people and the country are not treated well. Mr President, those are you-tots and you-tots kill the debate. Ventilating concerns about laws passed by a government is not the same as attacking a population. It is important that we do not lump the people, the country, the government and the party together. Because the majority exists by the grace of the minority. And those are also members of the population, including people with rights and needs. The way to debunk your bins is to show that we embrace them, that we are critical ourselves, that we are willing to identify the shortcomings in our own system and that we do not look away from abuses, in any European country. So today we are debating the actions of the Polish government and not the country or the people. The Greens see a trend of shrinking civil liberties. Legislation that restricts the legal certainty of citizens is rapidly passing through the Polish Parliament. The independence of the Constitutional Court is undermined. The logging ban in Białowieża Forest is being ignored. Women's right to self-determination is under threat. Refugees at the border are being pushed back to Belarus and journalists have a hard, very hard time. There is, therefore, reason enough for this Parliament to investigate whether the rule of law is systematically deteriorating. Finding the Greens it is therefore very sensible that this Parliament is ready to start that investigation.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! Let's establish some facts. First, this parliament has absolutely no right to judge the actions of a sovereign Polish state. Why? Because on the one hand, we have a European Parliament here, which is an empty shell. He is some kind of European joke. On the other hand, we have over a thousand-year-old Polish state. Poland will continue long after the entire history of the European Union turns into one tiny paragraph in a huge textbook on the history of stupid political doctrines. Secondly, this whole debate was summoned by the inspiration of some Polish-speaking politicians to cover up their political problems in Poland, to cover up their re-privatization scandals, the memory of their inept rule and the current lack of any idea for Poland. These Polish-speaking politicians looked too much at the party of treason, the Rzewuski and Szczęsny Potocki families, and dreamed that they would rule Poland by the grace of Brussels or Berlin lords. Third, this parliament is reaching the heights of hypocrisy and hypocrisy in today's debate. So everything is fine in Spain, where there are riots, where there are over seven hundred wounded, where there are political prisoners. So everything is fine in Germany, where political censorship is rampant. So everything is fine in Belgium, where the military has to patrol the streets in fear of Islamic terrorists. But it is not fair in Poland, where a legally elected government keeps its election promises. Hypocrisy, hypocrisy and falsehood - that is what this debate is. Ladies and gentlemen! A few days ago, on November 11, we celebrated the anniversary of Poland regaining independence. We regained freedom thanks to the titanic work of wise Polish politicians and the high national awareness and our society. In contrast, during World War II, Poland lost its independence due to the policies of England and France. I am an MEP of freedom and, like every Pole, I know that we do not need it EU advice, instructions and critic.Take care of your own countries and stop embarrassing yourself here.(The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question.- You said that Poland has a legally elected government.That is true, and my question is whether you think a legally elected government has the right to do anything.Does it not oblige Poland in any way that we, as Member States of the European Union, are committed to common values: human rights and the rule of law?The fact that a legally elected government can do anything is a abuse of power.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam!I am not a supporter of this government.Unfortunately, the question was not right.I am opposed to this government, but I am opposed above all to the values of the European Union, which are completely different from European values.I do not agree with the bureaucratic approach of European Union officials who try to interfere in the activities of a sovereign Polish state.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr Chairman! Please state! We, Poles, remember the time when the decisions about what Poles were allowed and what we were not allowed to do were made in Moscow. In Moscow, the limits of our political freedom and sovereignty were being set. A lot has changed now, but you can see that what has changed for us, Poles, is that now the borders of our political freedom are set by Brussels and Strasbourg. We know that the rape of nations and states ended in the death of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. And the same procedure of interference with the political freedom of nations and states will end in the death of the union of socialist European republics. And there will be nothing to regret ... Free and safe citizens in free and safe countries - that should be our goal. Several hundred years ago, there was a whipping boy at European courts, such an office. Today you made a whipping boy from Poland. I will say what the Polish street says: hands off Poland! (Applause)

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I would like to remind everybody that in reality we were not forced to join the European Union.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - I want to start this appeal to the EU by explaining that I do not intend to rule the PiS government. As a rightist, I am their bitter enemy. The only reason Poles support PiS is that the previous governments were even worse. And the problem is that the Union is perceived as a supporter of previous governments. That is why attacks by Mr. Timmermans and others increase the popularity of PiS. The more so as Poles do not like anyone interfering in their affairs. Many of the arguments used by the Union are valid, but many are absurd. This is because you do not know the situation in Poland, and you receive information from people who do not see things as they are, but as they would like them to be. So they are misleading you. Moreover, your demands contradict the feelings of most Poles. You demand rights for homosexuals - support for PiS is growing. You demand some stupid women's rights, you talk about some gender - support for PiS is growing. You accuse PiS of nationalism (this is not true: PiS is a sanation, nationalists are the enemies of PiS) - support for PiS is growing. In other words, you are preventing us from fighting this disgusting government, so please back off. Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Mr Korwin-Mikke, you have a request... (Mówca zgodził się odpowiedzieć na pytanie zadane przez podniesienie niebieskiej kartki (art. 162 ust. 8 Regulaminu)) (Interjection from the floor: ‘No!’) No? Listen, colleagues. The only person who has the right to accept or not to accept is Mr Korwin-Mikke. We said it would be one blue card per speaker, and Mr Korwin-Mikke accepts the request from Ms Becerra Basterrechea.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: "blue card" question.- Mr. Korwin-Mikke, every time you open your mouth, I think Poland is ashamed.To be honest.I believe that Poland is in everyone's heart and we all love Poland.We love her freedom, we love her bravery, we love innovation and what she has managed to do.And you come to tell us that if we agree that the party that governs now, which is destroying the rule of law in Poland, is improving in popularity because it has an anti-gay stance like yours regarding women?Do you also think that it is necessary to eliminate, to take the voice of women?Do you want me to stop asking you?Do you want me to stop telling you?Europe loves Poland because Poland is Europe.And I represent the Poles just like you.And I think better.Can you answer me?

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- I was talking about the absurd rights of women.You have a grudge against the fact that women in Poland have the privilege that they may - do not have to - retire early.And you think that this is a violation of women's rights because equality is violated.But you talk about women fifty times more than men, so women's equality is also violated here.Yes or no?So I don't understand what's going on here.No women's rights are violated in Poland.Contrary.For example, more women work - if you are interested - for their own businesses than in the West.I am not really a supporter of this, but it is.What do you mean?

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, I am glad to be able to take the floor after that contribution. The first words I ever heard a Polish person say were ‘Be not afraid’. Growing up in Malta, Saint John Paul was our inspiration, and he still is. To me, Poland will always be the nation of my Pope of Solidarity, who stood up to be counted when it was easier to sit down – a land that inspires hope and has symbolised courage in the face of so much adversity. Poland joining the European Union was the crowning moment for the children of that revolution and it proved just how far the nation had come. We cannot allow it to take any further steps backwards. But Poland has been let down by those leading it, who are weakening the democratic institutions and safeguards in the country, and who think that having an electoral majority means they can now do what they like. That is not how it works in our European Union. The rule of law is important because it is our fail—safe to protect democracy. It is the basis of everything. In a time of free and social media, it is absolutely impossible to hide the truth and the true picture of the deplorable developments in Poland. We have eyes and ears. Nobody has to inform Brussels what is going on – we already know. Human rights and the rule of law are in increased danger – and no one is here to attack Poland. Poland is a country that must be at the very heart of our Union, but, to that end, it must respect the rule of law. Its leaders must engage with the Commission in a constructive dialogue, and must respect the people who are courageous enough to stand up to them. Yes, we still have serious concerns about the proposed law on the National Council for the Judiciary and about the proposed law on the Supreme Court. These must be addressed. We must send a message that we will not stand idly by while the very bases of democracy and the rule of law in Poland are being undermined. We must insist that the Polish authorities respect their moral and legal obligations as an EU Member State. In conclusion, I look to my Polish colleagues – colleagues like Mr Lewandowski – and I look to Poles demonstrating that the Polish nation and the Polish Government are not one and the same. I know that Polish courage is something which still inspires. These are Polish patriots, standing up for Poland, and I salute them. Be not afraid. (Applause)

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Mr Chairman! We are debating Poland as a rule of law. We do it among friends, in family, in our European family, not among enemies. "About us with us", and sometimes there was "about us without us" in the past. The essence of the debate is compliance with the law in Poland, an important country with its identity, culture and historical merits. Poles have always wanted to be in Europe and still want to be here in Europe. The Union gives us Poles a sense of political, social and economic security. European values ​​and the law are our values ​​and we also want to protect them. That is why we, the people of the left, are worried, firstly, by the seizure of the judiciary by one party, secondly, attempts to limit the dignity and rights of women, thirdly, the use of collective responsibility, an extreme example of which is depriving officers and soldiers of pensions, and fourthly, negating historical the merits of many organizations and soldiers fighting against fascism in Poland and in Europe. Tensions build up between the Commission and the government. We urge the Commission: take a step back! We appeal to the government: take two steps back! Poland and its citizens cannot pay for this dispute.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, I note that Mr Legutko is afraid to answer any questions – he just made his statement and left, and that is symptomatic. In a democracy, you have debate: you have dialogue, questions and answers and an exchange of positions, and he just gives a monologue and leaves. That is called cowardice. What I did not hear in his totally irrational seven-minute rant was one single word of condemnation of the fascist march and the fascist slogans of last weekend. It was just a rant, and I have not heard where he stands. I would also like to hear about the rest of the ECR Group, because by not speaking out they are tacitly agreeing with the position of the PiS Government. Think about it: do you want to distance yourself from this, or do you want to side with a government that does not condemn fascists and that is restricting the freedom of other NGOs? Think very carefully about where you stand.  The government speakers represent – or claim to represent – the Polish people, as if there is only one opinion and one truth. Do you know what that is called? Absolutism. This is an authoritarian government that does not respect pluralism and does not respect the opinions of others. We know better, because we have seen the thousands who took to the streets to protest against the government – thousands of very courageous people, many courageous women – who spoke out against the government and for pluralism, for democracy, and for civil society.  So, Mr Legutko – who is not here – if you are asking for respect, then why do you not respect others? You have no respect for women’s rights, no respect for LGBTI people, no respect for people who do not share your religion, and no respect for people who do not share your opinion.  What I find very striking is how much the agenda of the PiS Government looks like the agenda of Mr Putin. They are always saying ‘we don’t like the Russians’, but their agenda is identical to that of Mr Putin. (Applause) Finally, I would like to say that this debate is not about Poland; it is about the rule of law. I welcome the words of the Council, but now we need some action. We need a real, broad mechanism that applies to all the Member States and that does not leave it to the Member States to judge themselves. We need a broad, independent mechanism, as has been proposed by the European Parliament.  (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Mr Złotowski under Rule 162(8))

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: - Mr President! The situation in Poland and Hungary is extremely serious, and the Commission is talking about a systemic threat to the rule of law. We on the left share that assessment, just like many of our colleagues here, but we also see a systemic threat against women's rights, which was raised by some colleagues. This connection between the attack on democracy, the attack on women's rights and the increasingly fascist authoritarian regime is so obvious. However, not all colleagues in here actually see it. On the other hand, the many Poles who took to the streets and demonstrated in black protest this connection, and it is to them that I would like to send our support. We feminists here in the European Parliament want to send a clear signal of support and solidarity with those of you who are fighting for democracy, for the rule of law, for women's rights, against racism and against fascism in Poland. You have our support, and I hope that you will have the support of all colleagues here and that they will all realize the connection between women's rights, democracy and the rule of law. (The speaker declined to answer a question ('blue card') from David Coburn pursuant to Rule 162 (8).)

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, it really is a pity that Mr Legutko is not here anymore, because – I hate to break it to him – he is not Poland. He is representing one voice in the Polish debate. I actually asked my Polish friends what they would like to hear mentioned in this debate and, in no time, dozens of people answered by messages, emails and comments. Many points were brought up: amongst others, the government’s reaction – or non—reaction – to the fascist march last Saturday; LGBTI rights; minority rights; the question of free elections and free media; independent courts; the cutbacks to NGO funding; teachers’ rights; the question of Białowieża Forest; and also – over and over again – women’s rights and sexual and reproductive rights were mentioned by Polish citizens, and I wanted to bring this up in the debate.  But the story that took my breath away, I must say, was the story of Piotr – a middle-aged man from a small city in Poland who burnt himself in the middle of Warsaw in protest at this government. He wrote a manifesto, bringing up demands that he would like to see considered by the PiS government in Poland. One thing that he said really struck me. Despite the fact that he wants people to stand up against this government, he said, ‘remember, however, that the PiS electorate are our mothers, brothers, neighbours, colleagues and friends’. This is not about fighting a war; it is about creating a dialogue, and I think it is now on us and Mr Timmermans to create this dialogue and to stand up for the rule of law and for Polish citizens.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Surely Polish values are those of its democratically elected parliament and government, not those of other European nations. I speak as a homosexual: I do not agree with many of the things that the Polish Government are doing. I am also very pro-feminist, so I do not agree with a lot of the other things that the Polish Government are doing. But surely it is the right of the Polish people to make their own decisions. Britain will never forget what Polish pilots did for us in World War II, and if Poland is being dictated to by the EU, perhaps you should consider joining Britain in Brexit – would you agree with me, Madam? (Applause in some quarters)

name: Terry REINTKE
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Coburn, I do not know how many times this has to be repeated in this Parliament. It is not specific policies that we are discussing today, it is the breaching of the Polish Constitution, and that is the basis for how we are doing democracy all together. If the rule of law is not respected in countries then there cannot be a democratic debate. This is the problem, this is why we are standing up. We are not discussing policies here, we are discussing what the fundament is of how we discuss. If that is breached then there cannot be democracy and there cannot be a democratic debate, and that is the problem regarding the situation in Poland right now.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: - Mr President! As soon as you do not share an opinion with the EU zealots in this house, you should be branded as extreme. You simply do not have the same value as the rest of you in here. Unfortunately, it is you who are down in the front row who would need an intensive course in democracy, and who unfortunately lack a little upbringing from home. You sit there mocking and laughing at your inflated grandiose self-image of yourself. Poland has become one of your favorite victims of bullying. Respecting the outcome of a democratic election in a democratic country - it does not exist in your inflated egos. Then you should instead educate the people to follow your view of things. You see the appointment of judges in the Constitutional Court as something terrible. I would then like to say that we have the same system in Sweden. The judges in HD are called the Judicial Council, are sixteen in number and are appointed by the government. When do you start criticizing Sweden? When will you threaten Sweden with sanctions? You should all sign up for a basic course in democracy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: question (“blue card”).- I would just like to ask Lundgren a question.Do you see any problems with developments in Poland, where the government is praising a racist and nationalist demonstration?Do you see any problems with a government that politicizes the appointment of the judiciary?That is what is different, not the procedures themselves, they are in different countries.Do you see any problems in the development of democracy and the rule of law in Poland?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: answer (“blue card”).- Of course, there are problems - there are in all countries.We have the same problem in Sweden, where we appoint the highest judges and call them justices.We have problems in Sweden - just as Poland has problems in its country.However, I refuse to accept that Brussels and Strasbourg should become a comprehensive authority that should teach the countries because they do not share the image you have here.There must still be national self-government.I will never go back on that point.I will never sell my country to the EU elite!

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Colleagues, we are 15 minutes behind schedule so I want to remind you of this. If you agree, we could stop the blue cards, because some of them are not answered, others are rhetorical, so I think it would help if we stopped the blue cards. If you are in agreement with me in this respect, we will go that way.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - Poland has democratically introduced a number of legislative changes and Mr Timmermans, Vice-President of the European Commission, condemns those legislative changes and thus indirectly also condemns Polish democracy. Meanwhile, Spain is throwing an elected sub-government in prison. Mr Timmermans supports Spain and thus supports the Spanish version of a democracy. Mr Timmermans has just said that the European Network of Councils for the Judiciary considers the independence of judges the most important thing. But what Mr Timmermans does not mention is that the same organization also says that judges in Spain are much less independent than judges in Poland. In Spain, judges are regularly selected specifically and put under pressure so that the desired judgment follows. Why then does Mr Timmermans not think this is a violation of European values? Mr President, Poland is a functioning democracy. If the voters still want it differently, they can choose differently next time. That seems a lot better than that Mr Timmermans prescribes the law for everyone here.

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! In view of the real problems of corruption and violations of the rule of law in Malta, you, Commissioner Timmermans, remain silent and do not initiate the procedure. Is it because it is the government of your socialist political family? You did not have such inhibitions to bring false accusations against Poland, rewriting word for word, copy paste, false accusations of the Polish total opposition defending the pathology of past governments and the remnants of communism. I call it the Timmermans paradox: first, remain silent about corruption in the bosom of your own socialist family, and second, attack those who, having a democratic mandate, really fight corruption by reforming the sick, pathological judicial system in Poland, unreformed since communism, not illustrated, burdened with connections with the Warsaw octopus, thirdly, to stand on the side of those who want to protect and preserve the pathology of the Polish judicial system. It is indeed an inverted hierarchy of values. It is a profound misunderstanding that Poland is undergoing a reform of the sick state and the judiciary. It is the completion of the infinite revolution of Solidarity twenty-five years late, not a violation of the principles of democracy and the rule of law. (Applause)

name: Frank ENGEL
text: – Mr President, I will hand the floor to Mr Elmar Brok if he prefers, but otherwise I will relay it – I find it exceptionally funny, Mr Saryusz-Wolski, that somebody should use the language that you have just used after having spent virtually your the whole political life serving the very system that you now condemn. It is a little strange, but oh well. What I wanted to say is that Mr Timmermans really encapsulated it all when he started, when he said: ‘I hope I can have a dialogue with the Polish authorities’. But we are not having a dialogue with the Polish authorities; we are not having a dialogue with the Polish Government either. It is again a bit like yesterday – poor Mr Matti Maasikas who has to stand up for something which I am sure he would rather not have to stand up for. The Polish Government is just as absent as their loudspeaker in this House, who gave out a seven-minute statement about essentially not much and then left with most of his colleagues and spent the rest of the morning with the Polish press – his friends, I suppose – outside of the plenary hall. This is the way in which this Polish authority, this Polish Government, this Polish majority, acts. Sophia in ‘t Veld was totally right when she explained that. It is apodictic; it is absolute; we are all wrong; we have no idea what is happening there; we get it all wrong and they are all right. The problem in Poland is that they are trying to change the state and to model it so that generations to come will have no chance to change it back for the better. That is the thing that we have to be concerned about, because there are millions and millions of Poles – probably half of them, more than half of them – that would still make up a pretty big Member State who want a future in Europe; who want a democratic future; who want a future in a free society; who want a future in a society where they are allowed to think, to speak, to demonstrate and to be what you are – not what God supposedly wants you to be. Those Poles we are standing up for, because they have chosen to be part of the European society, and that is why we care. They are not only sovereign Poles; they are also sovereign Europeans, and they want back their sovereignty over thought, over speech and over behaviour.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! It's a shame that Mr Legutko is no longer here. I would have told him that Europe is not a supermarket where you can simply choose the goods. Europe is a common house into which we moved voluntarily and where the same rules apply to everyone. These are the Copenhagen criteria, first and foremost the rule of law and democracy and that includes the independence of the courts, especially the constitutional court. For two years there have been problems in this regard in different forms with mutual accusations. But it cannot go on like this. It's about solving this permanent constitutional crisis. All independent observers agree on this, such as the Venice Commission. The European institutions have the right and the obligation to point this out to the Polish government. For domestic political reasons, this government insists on being able to do what it wants. That runs counter to the Treaties and it is positive that the Commission takes its role as guardian of the Treaties so seriously. Repeated calls for dialogue were ignored. As elected representatives of the European population, we have an obligation to support the Commission in this process and, if necessary, to also demand unambiguous measures, such as the initiation of the Article 7 procedure in this specific case after the relevant committee has reviewed the situation. We do this because we love Poles.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - The terms of the rule of law and respect for democracy are interesting today here in Parliament, following Spain's aspirations to ban the referendum in Catalonia. The silence of the European Union institutions over the legal persecution of Barcelona politicians is also expressive. Even more expressive today are the accusations against the Republic of Poland, allegedly for violations of democracy, for the reorganization of its judiciary, for its clear and categorical position on refugee issues, for other decisions establishing independence. The principles on which the European Commission is based state that equal treatment of Member States is respected in all cases. If the leaders of the European Union keep repeating that the issue of Catalonia is a matter of Spanish internal affairs, then why is there now a rage over decisions by the Polish Government or Parliament? Let’s say it’s their internal affair and let’s not interfere. Efforts to curb national law, to curb national decisions of Community public authorities, are nothing more than the destruction of national autonomy.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Mr President, what crimes is Poland accused of in its legitimate government? On the crime of truth: Poland refuses to submit to the media and their false propaganda organized by the globalist and Europeanist oligarchy. From the crime of justice: Poland refuses the massive immigration imposed by Germany for its economic growth, while the Poles have to move abroad in order to find work. On the crime of sovereignty: Poland refuses to leave the sovereign power of the people to judges, because justice is done in the name of the people. In short, you reproach Poland for being Poland, for resisting as it knows how to resist the oppression of the new European order, disorder for our peoples and our nations. You reproach him for preserving his identity by opposing your globalist religion, destroyer of law, of justice, individualist, relativist, nihilist, religion opposed to the right of God and therefore to human rights. Poland will remain Poland. It was able to resist Nazi barbarism and communism, it will resist European totalitarianism. Long live Poland!

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the report is based on opportunistic, fragmentary, immoral and out-of-context objections. The Union is trying to intervene inside a country under the pretext of government threats against the rule of law. The powers which the Commission seeks to exercise fall primarily with the Council and the Member States. Instead of imposing Poland's punishment through a selective reading of the Treaties, I call on it to support the government authorities in eliminating any communist burdens of the past and to leave them unaffected in the exercise of their sovereign rights. The Union has proclaimed trust and hope among equals, but has ended up arbitrarily pursuing the interests of certain countries to the detriment of others. This is proven by the establishment of a permanent mechanism of absolute financial control and sovereignty in my country, Greece, with the blessings of the left-wing government. The government of an independent and sovereign nation must be accountable only to its citizens and, while serving them, must not accept any outside interference.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, today I express all my support for, and friendship towards, the people of Poland – this great nation and strategic neighbour to us across the Baltic. Poland was a respected partner in the EU but now its political clout is being tarnished. The new Government is busy justifying its unjustifiable breaching of the rule of law. The strength of our European family is the rule of law. It is about shared values and democracy, an independent judiciary, freedom of assembly and freedom to demonstrate, and women’s rights. Poland, like all of us, embraced those values, and the family cannot be fully functioning if one of the Member States breaches the trust between us.  With our resolution, we are reaching out to Poland. We call on the Government to listen to the voice of its own people and to the independent European institutions, to engage in constructive dialogue, to reconsider its action, and to address the legitimate concerns raised by the European Commission and the Venice Commission. These concerns are based on hard legal facts, not politics. It is not Europe against Poland – it is Europe with Poland. We want to cooperate with the Government, and it is in their hands to avoid further action by the Commission. Turning their backs on this opportunity is leading Poland, together with populists and Eurosceptics, nowhere other than marginalisation, and it is creating tension. We want Poland back as a key player in our European family, with the prominent role that the people of Poland deserve, a credible and active partner when it comes to resolving the challenges facing Europe. We need Poland in order to shape a better future for our children together. (Applause)

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Mister President!There is a saying 'all good things come in threes' and in fact there is now a third resolution on Poland.So is everything all right?But on the contrary!Because to this day the Polish government has refused to have any direct dialogue with the Commission, and especially with the judicial reform it is curtailing the independence of the judiciary, a cornerstone of democracy and the rule of law.There are also restrictions on civil society, the right of assembly and women's rights.It is very clear that the Poles have repeatedly stood up for democratic values - Solidarność, “my body, my rights” and many other protests - and we will not accept that the people in Poland are now deprived of democracy and the rule of law by their own government.So we keep putting our fingers in the wound.We stand by the side of the Polish citizens!

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - High omes of the European Union, are you not ashamed of calling out the Polish people here?That proud European people showed us the way out of communism at a time when, Mr Timmermans, as a good socialist you probably still thought that the empire of the Soviet Union and its satellites should be respected.That proud Polish people are once again teaching us how not to get caught up in the European Union.At the same time, the Spanish kingdom deals with the Catalan people in a brutal and medieval way, with methods reminiscent of the way in which the Spanish Inquisition in the 16th century wanted to keep the Netherlands, including my Land of Flanders, under Spanish rule against their will.Are you not ashamed, ladies and gentlemen?I am a supporter of William of Orange.For God's sake, stop that hypocrisy, be ashamed and get out of here.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Two things: the Spanish Government is respecting its Constitution... (Interjection from Mr Annemans: ‘You are not in the debate, Mr President.’)  ... and secondly, I would ask you to use normal terms. Do not offend the speakers before you. That is what I wanted to say to you.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President, this is a very heated debate, and it is sad and very disappointing to hear that some of our colleagues simply do not want to notice all the systematic problems that are destroying democracy in Poland. Mr Legutko left the debate – so much for dialogue. That is exactly what we are criticising: the lack of an open dialogue. We are interested in the situation in Poland, we are worried – that is why we are holding a debate today. I have many friends in Poland and I stand here today for them. We are calling on the Polish Government to respect democracy and constitutional rights, to ensure the freedom of the media and to defend the independent judiciary. We will call for Article 7 of the EU Treaty to be triggered. We will continue on our course for an open dialogue with the Polish Government. The EU is not à la carte, the government cannot just pick and choose. We are debating the rule of law and not rule by law. I sincerely hope that today we can send a strong message to our Polish friends and citizens: we want you in the EU, Poland has always been part of Europe and always will be.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr Chairman! I would like to make an appeal from here, from the European Parliament, to the Law and Justice government: you are a government that fulfills its election promises to an excess. In the campaign, you used the slogans "Poland in ruin". Poles in 2015, during the elections, proud of the country's great development, did not understand these slogans. Everything is clear today. The path that the government is following - appropriating the law by politicians, taking freedom from Poles, taking away the rights of Polish women, taking away common judgments from citizens, destroying schools, disregarding young doctors, letting in extreme nationalists from different countries with radical slogans on the most important day for Poles - Independence Day , calling this extremely nationalist demonstration by members of the government "a beautiful sight, a joyful holiday" - this is the way that fulfills the promises to bring Poland to ruin. Even those less than 19% of entitled voters in Poland, voting for PiS, did not vote for such Poland. Don't make this road for us today! Do not be afraid to give up this path. We have a wise society in which you can pursue wise politics responsibly. It's high time to do this.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr. president; Commissioner Timmermans, every time we in this European Parliament discuss the rule of law in Poland, it becomes clear that this European Parliament has no problem with either Poland, a much loved country, or with the Poles. It has a problem when the extreme right, fascist, white supremacist and full of hate speech and discrimination, demonstrates in Warsaw - do it in Warsaw or do it anywhere in Europe. And it has a problem when the independence of the judiciary is undermined. Because, if in Spain, whoever breaks the law, who breaks the rule of law, responds criminally, it is because there is an independent judiciary, and what is happening in Poland is exactly the opposite, that the independence of the judiciary is under attack. And whoever does not understand that this European Parliament, when it speaks of Poland, represents the Poles, is an attack against European values ​​and European integration. Each one of the European parliamentarians represents 500 million Europeans. And this European Parliament is not extraterrestrial in Poland: it represents those millions of Poles who have the right to trust their institutions, the rule of law and the prevalence of the law and the Constitution, also protecting the Poles in the name of the European law.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, since the victory of President Duda and the Law and Justice Party in the Polish elections, European institutions have been trying to create the impression that the country has gone in the wrong direction, violates the fundamental human rights of its inhabitants and is about to become a dictatorship. The reality is of course different. All research shows that Poles are practically as enthusiastic about EU membership as they have been all these years, and the Law and Justice Party enjoys the support of 45-50% of voters. It follows that the problem is something completely different from what is being served to us. The pro-European Polish people have a different vision of the Union than the European establishment, and the current government enjoys great support from Poles because it seeks to put that vision into practice. If we continue to send messages to Poles from Brussels, let no one be surprised tomorrow if Poland becomes the new United Kingdom. You can ignore the will of the citizens and reject their ideas or fears, only as long as they allow you to do so.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, a key component of European Union membership is supposedly shared sovereignty. At no point, to my knowledge, have Member State citizens been told that the European Union is now supreme, that Member State governments are subservient and that European Union dictatorship is now in place. This morning a veiled and bullying threat to invoke Article 7, to punish Poland, was made. I would welcome this as full and final proof that European Union membership renders democratic national general elections and associated pledges, promises and outcomes by the winning party, absolutely meaningless. I will voice one warning: be careful what you wish for when you invoke Article 7.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Vice-voorzitter van de Commissie. – Sta mij toe eerst een woordje in mijn moedertaal te zeggen, en wel rechtstreeks tegen mijnheer Annemans. Dat hij mij persoonlijk aanvalt, vind ik geen enkel probleem. Dat ben ik gewend, dat raakt mij niet. Maar dat hij de beweging waaruit ik voortkom aanvalt en de sociaaldemocratie beschuldigt van collaboratie met totalitaire regimes, kan ik niet laten voorbijgaan. Sociaaldemocraten waren de eerste slachtoffers van de bolsjewieken. Sociaaldemocraten waren de eerste slachtoffers van de fascisten. Sociaaldemocraten waren de eerste slachtoffers van de nazi's. Ze hebben zich altijd verzet tegen totalitaire regimes. Ik laat dat dus niet passeren. Zeker niet uit de mond van iemand die misschien eens in de geschiedenis van zijn eigen beweging kan duiken voordat hij de geschiedenis van andere politieke bewegingen durft aan te kaarten. Mr President, we are talking today about the rule of law in Poland. If you want to play football you abide by the rules of the game and you accept the fact that there is a referee that makes sure that those playing the game abide by the rules. If you join the European Union, you do this as a sovereign decision. You sign and ratify a treaty. Once you have signed and ratified a treaty, the rules of that treaty apply to you. Then if you simply say ‘I am a sovereign nation, I don’t care about the rules’, it is like saying: ‘I want to play football but I will determine for myself which rules I will apply and which rules I will not apply’. Then you cannot play football!  The European Union cannot function if Member States start saying ‘We pick and choose which rules we have adhered to, are applicable to us, yes or no’. I think this should be the starting point of our debate. Concretely, in Article 2 of the Treaty, all Member States have said very clearly that they will respect the rule of law. One of the fundamental elements of the rule of law is that you accept and maintain a separation of powers. An independent judiciary is essential in the rule of law. You cannot pick and choose and use the argument that you have the majority to simply ignore the law. You can use that majority to change the law. You can use a majority to change the Constitution if you have one, but you cannot simply say ‘I ignore it because I have a majority’. You cannot use democracy against the rule of law and this is the argument that is often used in this debate.  Just imagine, I would say to those of the European Conservatives and Reformists Group (ECR) who still remained in the room, just imagine the shoe were on the other foot, and in this Parliament a majority would say, ‘Hey, we have the majority, we don’t care about the Rules of Procedure of Parliament, we have the majority, we dictate what happens!’ In what position would you then be? The rights you now claim for yourself as a majority might not be granted to you once you no longer are a majority. This is a fundamental problem for Europe because, as some of you have said, once you have destroyed the independence of the judiciary, even if you lose an election, the new powers that be will have no other option but to try and revert it and then it becomes a perpetual machine of not respecting the rule of law. This will never stay limited to one Member State. If it happens in one Member State it affects the Union as a whole, and this should never be disregarded. Had Mr Legutko still been here I would have said to him: you took seven minutes to say nothing, not one word, about the points I made about the independence of the judiciary. And I would also have said to him, after his vile attack on Mr Lewandowski, I would suggest to Mr Lewandowski to wear this as a badge of honour. Why? Because in the last two years, I have learned that if you have no arguments, if you have nothing to say, if you don’t know how to react, you start with personal attacks. This is also my experience in the last two years. So every personal attack on me is proof that they have no arguments, that they don’t know what to say and that they don’t have a point at all.  Finally, you know the old joke about the ‘ghost rider’ [driving the wrong way on the motorway]. Somebody is sitting in his car listening to the radio, and on the radio the announcer says ‘Be careful, on the A2 there is a ghost rider driving the other way’ and the person sitting in the car says: ‘One? I see hundreds!’ This is how I would react to Mr Legutko. It is not the European Commission only. It is not the European Parliament only. It is organisations of European judges, it is the Venice Commission, it is the United Nations. Are all these people wrong? Are all these people wrong? Is the only one who is right the PiS government in this? They will say yes! But if you want a real dialogue, at least have the courtesy to go into the points that are made.  And a final remark about what Guy Verhofstadt and others said about last Sunday. There is a very thin line between proud patriotism and terrible nationalism. It is a very thin line. I admire proud patriotism but I also believe that all those who believe in proud patriotism have a responsibility not to let that slide into terrible nationalism, because if we fall into the trap of nationalism we bring back to life the most terrible parts of European history, and some of this was seen on the streets of Warsaw last Sunday. I do applaud the fact that President Duda clearly said that he distances himself from the expressions of extremism, of anti-Semitism, and other expressions.  (Applause)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me assure you once again that the Estonian Presidency, and the Council as a whole, attach great importance to upholding the rule of law and fundamental values within the EU. This debate of today has once again reminded us that the EU is better at solving problems between its Members than within the Members. That is what the EU was created for. It is also worth recalling that the effectiveness of the EU rests on the delicate balance between respecting the sovereignty of its nation states and pooling the sovereignty to make those states stronger together. Nevertheless, it is clear that all Members have to comply with fundamental freedoms, democratic standards and the rule of law. I am not in a position to state more at this stage. I speak as the Presidency of the Council and therefore in the name of all its Members. The Council will, however, continue to follow this issue very closely. Now a more personal remark: I have heard some comparisons between Moscow and Brussels during this debate. Having lived myself – having had to live myself – in the Soviet Union, I find these comparisons utterly inappropriate.  (Applause) Those who make these comparisons do not know either Brussels or Moscow, or do not want to know, or do not want to remember. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I report that I have received two motions for resolutions, pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure.The discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday 15 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: in writing. - I was not in the hemicycle during the next debate about my country. I did not want to participate in a show of hatred without any substantive foundations. G. Verhofstadt's statement only confirmed the rightness of this decision. At that time, I decided to lay flowers in KL Natzweiler, a German concentration camp set up near Strasbourg in occupied France. Over 50,000 people passed through the camp and the sub-camps scattered around it. prisoners, over 22 thousand. was lost. Among the prisoners from 30 nations, Poles were the largest group, including those of Jewish origin (13,606 prisoners). The museum was burnt down by neo-Nazis after the war. Although there was a collaborative government in Vichy in France during World War II, no one tries to attribute to the French participation in the Holocaust, as it is easy for Poland to do. Such "random" mistakes do not happen in the modern world. I pay tribute to the victims of the KL Natzweiler concentration camp, which was one of the thousands of links in the extermination industry planned and consistently implemented by Nazi Germany. Information about the medical experiments carried out here must shock every sensitive person. Poles were victims of Nazi Germany, they fought against the German and Soviet occupation. They never formed a collaborative government. The Polish Underground State sentenced to death anyone who handed over a Jew to Germany. In Verhovstadt's statement, I consider the allusive link between the Auschwitz extermination and Poland to be despicable.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: in writing. - The functioning of the rule of law in Poland is not limited only to the mechanisms of the functioning of the law in the last 2 years, to which the European Commission refers; it is an internal problem of legal institutions and only practice can show whether there has been a breach of the Convention rights and what should be corrected in these mechanisms. There is an important question: has there been no breach of the European Convention on Human Rights in previous legal solutions? I answer: yes - it did. Here are some examples: 1) Polish law does not guarantee a minimum standard of protection to individuals evicted from their real estate. Selling premises with tenants in Poland leads to a real violation of basic human rights; 2) Polish law tolerates depriving Polish citizens of their acquired rights regarding pension rights, which recently applies to officers of uniformed services, mainly those who ended their service in the People's Republic of Poland. This also applies to those people on disability pensions.
