The principle of collective responsibility for the so-called "Communism", that is, that they lived in those times and that they honestly served the state of that time; 3) for years, the Polish Executive Penal Code in the case of prisoners has not guaranteed them a humane area of ​​serving a sentence of not less than 4 m2, as it is often 2 m2. I will support the resolution, provided that the threat contained therein to impose economic sanctions on Poland is rejected by the EP.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – It is because we love and admire Poland and the Polish people that we must react to the ongoing attack by the Kaczyński/Szydło Government of Poland against the independence of the judiciary, including the Supreme Court. Because not respecting the independence of the judiciary amounts to abuse of power and violation of the rule of the law, and we are already seeing many other grave implications: in the muzzling of the media, in the intimidation of political opponents, in the obscurantist gender discrimination against Polish women, etc. To the point that Piotr, a Polish Jan Palach, recently felt he had to replicate in Warsaw the desperate self-immolation of Prague, 1969, under totalitarian occupation. Ominously, alarmingly, 60 000 Nazis marched in Warsaw last weekend and the Minister of the Interior of the Kaczyński/Szydło Government lauded them and echoed their racist, white supremacist slogans. I urge Vice—President Timmermans and the Commission: Do not delay triggering action under Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union against this Polish Government. Before these Nazi fascists further disgrace Poland! And the European Union!

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing.- The European Parliament wants to apply to Poland the disciplining article 7 of the Treaty on European Union.Frans Timmermans' accusing violations of the rule of law in Poland is met with my strong opposition.It is an anti-Polish, European campaign aimed at destabilizing and harassing the Law and Justice government, which does not fit in with the left-liberal trend.This is why we are being persecuted.It is a form of European dictatorship.A situation in which the European Commission is ready to expect the government of a sovereign state to disregard the will of voters and to comply with its expectations leads to a distortion of the principles of democracy.It is not really about Poland and the state of Polish democracy, but only about supporting the Polish opposition, which scandalously defames the image of Poland and Poles.I cannot agree with this and will definitely vote against this resolution.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. – In his opening remarks in this debate on the situation in Poland, Commission Vice-President Timmermans said that ‘an issue pertaining to the rule of law never affects only the country concerned: it affects the whole construction of the European Union.’ The debate has also referred to the requirement that independence of justice systems and courts must be maintained. Frequently, in our debates, we demand that the fundamental rights of people be respected by governments. Why is it that the Commission and the Council have not expressed similar concerns over the situation in Catalonia? It is outrageous that the government of a Member State can inflict violence upon peaceful citizens on their way to cast a vote. It is unacceptable that the Spanish Government can sack the legitimately elected government of Catalonia, and utterly incredible that elected Catalan ministers are sent to prison for exercising the democratic mandate given to them by voters in Catalonia. Surely this is a situation which demands a response from the leadership of the EU, at the very least offering to facilitate dialogue and a return to democratic order, and seeking guarantees that voters in Catalonia will be allowed to democratically determine their own constitutional future.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. - There is a growing number of countries where we need to have a debate on the rule of law. The symptoms that arise are broadly similar: governments continue to violate the principle of separation of powers, systematically dismantling power constraints, brakes, and counterbalances. In the information society, one of the most important and unavoidable counterweights to power is the threat to press freedom and media pluralism. Freedom of the press is also under threat in more and more EU countries: Malta’s country’s most respected investigative journalist is being killed for coming too close to embarrassing cases such as the Azerbaijani bribery scandal. In Hungary and Poland, the media market is being government monopolized by government, degrading a significant part of the press into a simple propaganda tool. Russian propaganda and false news are spreading across Europe, influencing elections and referendums. The European Commission, meanwhile, is spreading its hand to apologize, this is a Member State competence. But without a free press, there will be no democratic Member States, and without them there will be no democratic or any other European Union. There is no escaping the EU's active role in preserving and promoting independent media and fact-finding. Indeed, the Commission must be tasked in part with protecting the rights of journalists, it must protect media pluralism: both through legal means and financial resources. The 2020 long-term budget needs to find a way to support media pluralism in the long term and on a large scale, but in the meantime, urgent action is needed within the available framework.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - The EU Treaty should not be used by the Commission and the various political forces of the European Parliament as a means of intervening within a Member State, especially when peoples, on the basis of the principle of popular sovereignty, have made their own their choices highlighting governing majorities that must implement their program. At the same time, the EU must respect the constitutional structure and traditions of the Member States. In addition, it should be noted that the governments of the Member States must also respect democracy, the rule of law, the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, as well as the acquis communautaire.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: in writing. - The rule of law is a fundamental principle of the European Union. If the rule of law is jeopardized, democracy is jeopardized and human rights are jeopardized. The rule of law guarantees the independence of the judiciary, freedom of the media and freedom of expression. Today, all this is in danger in Poland and in Hungary as well. We cannot avoid the question of what the European Parliament, the European Union, should do in this situation. First of all, we need to negotiate and try to persuade the competent governments to return to Europe. However, if this does not work, we cannot shy away from stronger, tougher measures. What awaits Europe if we are not consistent is well illustrated by the events of last week in Warsaw. Where 60,000 neo-Nazis marched screaming, demanding a “white Europe,” “pure blood”. The darkest traditions of European history have come to life and have feared many millions of European citizens. I am ashamed that Hungarian politicians also took part in this event. And this disgraceful event was called a “patriotic act” by the Polish government. But it is precisely in this way that an introverted, exclusionary neo-Nazi policy becomes accepted. It is a fundamental political and moral duty for us in the European Parliament to condemn such events in the strongest possible terms and to resolutely oppose governments that confront Europe using such events.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - Since coming to power, the Conservative Party has been working to dismantle all checks and balances necessary for democracy. The powers of the government have been greatly expanded with the reform of the judicial system which grants the executive discretionary power over judges and the constitutional court. The government is also attacking individual freedoms, media freedom and overly critical civil society. The justice ministry has notably refused funds to women's rights organizations, while funding religious movements. I am very concerned about the abuse of women's sexual and reproductive rights as the government tries to toughen or even ban abortion altogether. Over a year ago, we all welcomed the Commission's decision to initiate, for the first time since its creation, the European framework for the rule of law. But this has had no significant effect and the Union only recognizes the gravity of the situation. Parliament is now assuming its responsibilities with this resolution. We call on the Civil Liberties Committee to prepare a report for the activation of Article 7.1, leading to sanctions. This illiberal regime, at the heart of the Union, is intolerable.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. – In his opening remarks in this debate on the situation in Poland, Commission Vice-President Timmermans said that ‘an issue pertaining to the rule of law never affects only the country concerned: it affects the whole construction of the European Union.’ The debate has also referred to the requirement that independence of justice systems and courts must be maintained. Frequently, in our debates, we demand that the fundamental rights of people be respected by governments. Why is it that the Commission and the Council have not expressed similar concerns over the situation in Catalonia? It is outrageous that the government of a Member State can inflict violence upon peaceful citizens on their way to cast a vote. It is unacceptable that the Spanish Government can sack the legitimately elected government of Catalonia, and utterly incredible that elected Catalan ministers are sent to prison for exercising the democratic mandate given to them by voters in Catalonia. Surely this is a situation which demands a response from the leadership of the EU, at the very least offering to facilitate dialogue and a return to democratic order, and seeking guarantees that voters in Catalonia will be allowed to democratically determine their own constitutional future.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Every government in a Member State of the European Union must respect and protect the division of power that is characteristic of democratic countries.Any interference with the independence of the judiciary threatens the rule of law and the security of citizens and businesses in a fair trial.Likewise, freedom of the media and the exclusion of their political influence is a cornerstone of democratic establishment.I am watching with concern how these pillars are gradually collapsing in Poland.On the other hand, there are areas in which the European institutions must not intervene.These include cultural and family policy.As the text presented contained unacceptable interventions in these areas for me, I could not support it.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: written. - The situation in Poland is very complex and the EU has taken too clear a position for an interpretation of the situation. Of course, threats and violations of human rights cannot be accepted, but in this the EU has forgotten the history of Poland with a totalitarian repression from communism. Part of the measures implemented by Poland is a way of processing this dark part of Poland's history and ensuring a democratic form of government. It is very possible that everything that has been done in Poland is not in line with the values ​​that the EU has developed and is now using to justify a series of measures against Poland. However, this does not justify the EU criticizing and punishing Poland for decisions taken in accordance with Poland's democratic system; this is too early and constitutes a far too gross violation of Poland's self-determination as a nation. If something is to happen in the form of an intervention in the international arena concerning Poland, it is individual states through organizations such as the OSCE and the UN that can and must pursue these issues and issues of a similar nature, not the EU. I do not believe in supranationalism, and this is unfortunately perhaps the best example of a Europe that has gone too far.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the winter plan for asylum seekers.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, last winter we all saw the press reports about the difficult conditions and the vulnerable situation of thousands of refugees and migrants facing severe weather conditions in European reception centres. We cannot allow this situation to happen again. We have to make full use of all resources and instruments that are at our disposal. According to the data supplied by the Greek authorities more than 15 000 migrants are present on the Greek islands as we speak. The hotspots are overcrowded, and living conditions could become very difficult due to winter conditions. Furthermore, there are still thousands of refugees and migrants stranded in the Western Balkan countries that may face a difficult situation if the weather conditions worsen.  No single country is able to handle this kind of situation alone. Efforts should be made not only by the most affected countries, but also by all other countries in order to support them. The Commission is the EU institution best placed to coordinate and help in such situations. The Commissioner will brief you on the current plans to mitigate the situation, as well as on other forms of support that can be provided to the most affected countries or planned ahead as contingency measures. Funding and concrete plans alone are, however, not sufficient to help us tackle this difficult situation. Lasting stabilisation of the situation on the eastern Mediterranean route will be key to improving the situation of these refugees and migrants. We need to further implement the EU-Turkey statement. Continued support for countries along the Western Balkans route is also key. In addition, we will pursue all legislative proposals on the reform of the common European asylum system, building on the work carried out so far. We need to gradually put in place a proper and sustainable asylum and migration policy.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the situation of refugees and migrants facing potentially harsh winter conditions has always been a key concern for our Commission. Our clear priority is to provide all Member States and our neighbours with support in their task and efforts to protect the refugees and migrants during the winter season. We all know that this is not a new issue, and the Commission has been proactive in assisting and supporting the authorities on the front line throughout all previous winters. But our collective preparedness has to be structured because – yes – winter comes every year and nobody knows or can predict how heavy it may become. We all know this is a demanding exercise for national authorities, notably in those countries which host a large number of migrants. Looking first at the situation in Greece, it is indispensable to recall the enormously positive and stabilising effect brought about by the activation of the EU—Turkey Statement in March 2016. Since the very beginning of the crisis, the European Union has made available around EUR 1.3 billion in support to Greece for tackling its migration and refugee challenges, making Greece the largest beneficiary of EU home affairs funds, as well as the exclusive beneficiary of the new EU emergency support instrument. This EU funding enabled the upgrading of the hotspots and ensured the operation of the open accommodation site of Kara Tepe on the island of Lesvos. Necessary services such as washing, cleaning, catering and food provision, housing, transportation, legal aid, medical services and educational activities are not a luxury. They are a must. They are essential for the dignified treatment all migrants must enjoy. Without EU financial support directly to the Greek authorities or via implementing partners such as the UNHCR and the IOM, many refugees and migrants would have been deprived of their fundamental human rights. Last year, the Commission also funded the purchase and installation of prefabricated houses and heating devices. This has also significantly contributed to the overall improvement of the reception conditions on the islands. But today we are again facing a situation of severe overcrowding on most of the islands. Yes, the situation has become very difficult. This is due to a combination of factors: the recent increase in arrivals on the Greek islands since the early summer of 2017 – even though limited – together with the still insufficient and not always adequate reception capacity and the still limited returns to Turkey. We cannot have a repetition of last year. The shocking images from last year must not return. Effective solutions must immediately be found. I have personally just come back from Greece, where I had constructive discussions with the Greek authorities. My colleague in charge of humanitarian aid, Commissioner Stylianides, has also been in close and regular contact with the Greek side. Solutions have been identified and we will continue to assist Greece in addressing the situation, notably on the islands of Lesvos, Chios and Samos. This is why, in order to tackle the situation on the islands effectively, the Commission has also taken concrete steps to expand the scope of the rental scheme funded by the Emergency Support Instrument. By the end of the year, the rental scheme will reach up to 2000 places, adding thereby up to an additional 900 places to the 1 122 places already available on the islands. To do this, the full engagement and cooperation of the local authorities is essential. EU funding was mobilised during the summer under the Greek AMIF National Programme specifically to support winterisation works in the hotspots on the islands, but there are winter-related works which still need to be completed. More precisely, electricity grids in hotspots should be upgraded, all housing units should be connected to electricity and further heating appliances should be provided for those housing units that are not equipped for winter conditions. Additional prefabricated units should be transferred from the mainland where possible. The Commission has also been calling for the creation of appropriate reception facilities, including closed facilities, on the islands. Let me add at this point that the cooperation of all actors, at all levels and in particular with local authorities, is key. They are the ones who are most closely confronted with the dire situation on the ground. They all have to work together and support each other in the efforts to exit the crisis mode and move towards sustainable migration management. Only if everyone does their part and all parts of a comprehensive strategy are fulfilled will the situation improve. The continuous, full implementation of the EU—Turkey Statement is key for the situation on the islands to improve. Again, let me repeat that continuous support and timely delivery from all partners – the national authorities, the Commission, EU agencies, the UNHCR, the IOM and other implementing partners on the ground – is essential. It is equally key that the Greek authorities continue to invest in swift asylum and return procedures, which contribute to further improving the situation on the islands. The emergency support instrument is providing accommodation in rental apartments all over Greece, not just on the islands, and we are ready to finance up to 30 000 places. As of 7 November, 15 458 refugees are already living in rental apartments, whilst the Greek Government is in the process of organising more transfers from the reception centres. Furthermore, all 21 long—term Commission—funded reception centres in mainland Greece are winterised, with the Greek Government having undertaken to close substandard temporary reception centres before the end of the year. I would like to emphasise that our clear objective is to ensure that most people on the mainland are living in rental accommodation. The Commission is also ready to fund additional places should such needs be confirmed. But our joint efforts on this matter are not just about Greece. We, as Europe, as a continent, have to remain prepared. We are closely following the situation in all Member States, in particular the front-line Member States, including Italy and Bulgaria, where there seem to be no imminent challenges concerning refugees and migrants for the winter. The preparation of the authorities and funds we have provided since last year have yielded clear results. For example, in Bulgaria, the International Organisation for Migration has implemented an action for the purchase and distribution of winter clothing kits and shoes to migrants in all reception centres in Bulgaria. According to information from Bulgaria, these kits have already been available since October. Regarding Italy, no specific winterisation needs have been identified, but progress is being made in swiftly mobilising EUR 35 million of emergency assistance to support Italy in further catering for the needs of those arriving in the country and improving the efficiency of procedures. Work is also under way on the possible mobilisation of up to a further EUR 100 million to assist in meeting needs on the ground. Any emerging winterisation needs could then be supported in this framework. Let me now turn to Serbia and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The European Union has been using all possible tools to help cope with the refugee crisis in both countries and is providing significant financial and technical support. Last winter, the Western Balkans faced considerable difficulties due to cold weather and heavy snowfall, especially in Serbia. We all recall the images from last year. Expanding reception capacities and ensuring that existing centres are adequate for the upcoming winter has been one of our priorities, and we are working closely with the Serbian authorities to this end. A special measure adopted in March 2017 with a budget of EUR 23.5 million aims, amongst other things, to cover accommodation costs; both running costs and refurbishment. Under the EU Trust Fund, an action of EUR 21 million was approved in June in response to the Syrian crisis. It includes a EUR 16 million direct grant for Serbia also covering costs related to the running of centres, including staff and utilities, education and health care. Signing off on this by the end of this year is a priority. Until then, humanitarian aid has allowed us to support the provision of food and non-food items, as well as protection to refugees and migrants in formal education and transport to schools. The more than EUR 83 million allocated to Serbia overall, both through humanitarian aid and pre-accession assistance, makes European Union is the largest donor to Serbia. In total, more than EUR 118 million has been allocated to Serbia in past and planned EU financial and technical support in the field of border migration and asylum management. For instance, IPA funding for the current deployment of 50 guest officers from EU Member States has been extended until the European Border and Coast Guard Agency can deploy teams with executive powers. Negotiations to allow for such deployment are ongoing both with Serbia and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Since the crisis broke out in the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, the Commission has allocated EUR 19 million specifically to help that country cope with the refugee crisis. This is part of over EUR 50 million allocated in past and planned EU financial and technical support for the country in the field of borders, migration and asylum management. We will consider additional funds as needs arise. More generally, the European Union is looking into providing additional support based on the needs agreed with our partner countries. We are all sensitive to this issue. It is, above all, a matter of our humanitarian duty. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, for four months there has been an increased flow of refugees and migrants from the Turkish coast to the Northeast Aegean islands. In September we had 6,000 new arrivals and about the same number in October, ie within two months more than 10,000 foreigners came to Greece. In the first ten days of November we already had 1,603 new arrivals. You realize that every day hundreds of people are added to the existing ones, while the country is no longer able to provide them with decent care and living conditions. In Lesvos, which has 32,000 inhabitants, there are 8,000 foreigners, while the infrastructure is only enough for 2,000. At the same time, 1,500 people live in tents, risking their lives when the weather changes. A similar situation is observed in Chios and Samos. As you know, the resettlement programs ended on 26 September, making it impossible for new refugees to move from the country to other Member States. At the same time, the renegotiation of the Dublin Regulation, which is based on a permanent relocation mechanism, strikes at countries that refuse the proportional distribution of refugees in accordance with the principle of solidarity. Therefore, the timing of the adoption of the new regulation is unknown. Ladies and gentlemen, do not forget that my country, Greece, is on a program and has huge financial problems with increasing poverty, but at the same time, nevertheless, it has made superhuman efforts to manage the immigration problem satisfactorily so far. But I am describing to you a situation that is currently on the verge of a humanitarian crisis. I call on the Commission to draw up an emergency decongestion plan for the islands immediately, here and now, otherwise we risk facing dire situations that will be difficult to deal with.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Winter is just around the corner. In the Greek islands, the situation with refugees and migrants is unbearable. We have allocated a good billion euros to Greece, why do refugees and migrants still not have decent living conditions? There are no suitable reception centers on the islands, registration procedures are slow. People are actually trapped there. The coming months can therefore be fatal for the numbers, especially for the most vulnerable, women and children. I therefore call on Greece, the Commission and the European governments to act together with a number of humanitarian and humanitarian organizations that are literally saving lives on the islands. Member States must stop returning migrants to the Greek islands. People from the islands should be relocated to the mainland immediately. This agreement with Turkey does not really work in anyone's favor. With the closure of the Western Balkan route, organized human trafficking has grown, and criminals are making money at the expense of human destinies. Moreover, five countries, including Austria and Germany, have once again called for an extension of internal border controls without argument, and this is not a return to Schengen, as you announced, Commissioner, but an even greater departure from freedom of movement on European soil. The reform of the asylum system is at a standstill. And as long as we only here understand the dimensions of migration and refugee flows, and at home leaders work differently, we can forget about effective migration management in Europe.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Greece has been receiving increased migration flows in the last quarter. The Aegean islands can not stand other refugees and illegal immigrants, as more than 15,000 people are now trapped there. And all this is happening while at the end of September the famous relocation plan has been completed, which was implemented by Germany and France only by a third. At the same time, in Greece, NGOs are partying with the European funds allocated to refugees, instead of allocating these funds to carry out a winter plan for asylum seekers. Mr Avramopoulos, in view of this situation, the process of immediate decongestion of the Aegean islands, which no longer have the necessary reception infrastructure, must begin. to continue the relocation program and to modify Dublin III in order to stop Greece from becoming a storehouse of souls, to strike the slave trade circuits that transport thousands of illegal immigrants and, finally, to send a decisive message to Erdogan to stop playing with the post .

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I should like to thank the Commissioner for his words. Commissioner, I much agree with you and I am grateful to the Commission for the work it has been doing in this area. I would also like to extend my gratitude and my respect to the people on the Greek islands who have shown immense responsibility and humanity in meeting the refugee crisis, and I think others should take an example from that. Commissioner Dimitris Avramopoulos said we cannot have a repetition of last year, and yet we seem to be having that repetition. The point is here: we do not have a technical, practical problem; it is not that people are stuck on the islands because there no boats and planes. It is the direct result of political decisions taken by the national governments. I cannot hold the Estonian Presidency responsible for all the Member States, but it is an absolute disgrace that on the richest continent in the world, we are worried about whether people are going to make it through winter. I cannot remember the exact figures, you mentioned all sorts of figures, but we are talking about tens of thousands of people. Are we seriously saying that there is a practical problem for 500 million citizens in the European Union to somehow provide decent shelter to a few thousand people? Honestly? It is an absolute disgrace! All the talks about deals with unsavoury regimes – that is just escapism, distracting from what should really be done. There has been a very decent proposal by the Commission sitting on the desk of the Council for a year and a half. Parliament has done its homework. Yes, we represent different political views in this House too, it is difficult. But you know what? In the treaties, there is no longer the unanimity rule. If the Council is pretending that it can only decide when there is unanimity, it is actually violating the treaties. I suggest that the Council gets on with it and that we get this asylum and migration policy up and running as soon as possible, and make sure that the most civilised and prosperous continent in the world is actually going to give civilised and dignified shelter to people in need.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! I agree with my colleague. It is not just a matter of Greece, Italy and the Western Balkans being responsible for the situation that has arisen, we ourselves stand as a whole as the European Union - including the member states including the Commission, including ourselves, who have political responsibility here in the European Parliament - a duty to prevent events like those of the previous year from happening again. That, I think, should bind us all together and shouldn't lead us to somehow blame anyone, but rather to make us very clear about what to do now. First of all, we have to say: We have a problem with the implementation of what has been concluded as a deal, as an agreement between the EU and other countries, that we now have a situation such as that of Greece Islands certainly also on the part of the EU - certainly not with bare intent, but it is still allowed - to be treated as, for example, Australia, Papua New Guinea, as an island, in order to ultimately dump the refugee problem there. We can no longer allow that to happen. Much has been funded through the Commission. But we also know that, for example, a large part of the money cannot go directly to the Greek state, but to refugee initiatives or the UNHCR. We also know that part of what you have committed yourself to ultimately could not be implemented. 2,000 homes were to be built on the Greek islands. They weren't created, it's only 1,100! There is also a lack of commitments that have been made on the mainland. 28,000 places in homes were to be created by the UNHCR. 9,000 are still missing. The funds for this are already there, they have been made available been! The Greek government was obliged to create permanent facilities with 12,000 places. She almost achieved her goal: I think 200 places are missing. We should really start by saying: we need concrete practical solutions. There is a suggestion to rent hotel rooms, for example. But now the rules say - both on the part of the UNHCR, but also for the Commission: That is not possible. We cannot finance hotel rooms. But! We have to find a solution! Because the apartments will not come so quickly. Nobody can tell me that, for example, a hotspot like Moria, which is permanently overcrowded - instead of 2,500 there are 5,000 to 6,000 refugees there - can be winterized. That will not do! But if I can't create the apartments on the islands either, then I really have to see how I use the potential of free rooms there that can be rented, and then I have to change the rules! There has to be a way to do this, it's a practical solution! So: besides what has already been done, more has to be done. Secondly, I would like to point out that the problem is exacerbated precisely by the fact that the many Member States are not complying with their rules. I saw a short report on German television yesterday. Several refugees were shown on hunger strike because of the conditions in the camp. In the meantime I have noticed: They were on a hunger strike - thank God they have now ended it - because they are supposed to go to Germany and Germany will not accept them. But German television doesn't say that. It gives the impression: It's the Greeks again, they're too stupid for anything, they can't do it. But we as the Federal Republic of Germany are not fulfilling our obligations. And so it affects many other countries as well. That is the point where I would ask the Council to start and say: Let go Don't talk to us about general things, let's get specific.It's about human life.We all have a joint responsibility here.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (NL) Mr President, the colleagues are right. This is not about whether there are enough beds or blankets. This is about something else. The Greek government is letting refugees on those islands because it is afraid of a draw-in effect. There are plenty of shelter places on the mainland. The Turkish government says, under the Turkey deal, we are only taking back people who are on the Greek islands, not those on the mainland. The other Member States think: that is actually useful because then we will not have to resettle so many people. The fact that 12,000 refugees and migrants are trapped on the Greek islands while only 5,000 people are accommodated does not have to remain that way. Bring those people to the mainland and then transfer them to other Member States. But that does not happen. And what is the actual European policy? The actual European policy for this winter is to hope for a warm Christmas. Mrs. Zimmer and Mrs. In 't Veld are right, but the political question behind it must be asked. We cannot keep the Turkey deal as it is now. Indeed, we cannot continue to make these kinds of deals with other countries. We cannot blame the Greeks alone. We must take our own responsibility. But it is certainly not possible to abandon the Greek islands in this way.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: for the EFDD Group. - Mr President! The temperature is currently 25 degrees in Damascus, 30 degrees in Lagos and 30 degrees in Bangladesh. No one should have to sleep in tents as the migrants in Sweden did in the winter of 2015. However, there is a simple solution: We say no from the beginning. Europe, and especially Sweden, has taken its responsibility - a responsibility we have never had, because Sweden has not started a war in over 200 years and has not had any colonies in 300 years. When does the responsibility end? I ask. There is a simple solution to this: Put the resources on travel home for the economic migrants in question. Say no before they go over so we do not have to be blackmailed by Turkey. I will now present the solutions, and we'll see what you do with them. Maybe you need to think a little more and write reports. However, we all know that it will end with Australia's migration system. Therefore, I will soon go there and learn more about this. Then you can ask me instead of these liberals who are currently ruling the EU. Free asylum and open borders for the whole world do not work. It's time to face it now.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over the last five years 700 000 immigrants, presumed to be refugees, have landed in Italy. More than half a million, that is 80%, are illegal immigrants who are not fleeing any war. These false refugees take advantage of the European asylum system and the inept Italian government, with the complicity of Brussels, offers these immigrants years of free room, board and services. All this cost Italians 14 billion euros: a senseless madness, a scandalous injustice. The Italians are rightly pissed off at Europe and with the Letta, Renzi and Gentiloni governments, which have opened the doors of our country to the invasion of illegal immigrants. The situation is unsustainable and the reform of the Dublin regulation is going in the wrong direction. Clear and firm rules are needed, as is the case in the United States and Australia: stop legal immigration, forced repatriation of all illegal immigrants, immediate closure of borders, life imprisonment for human traffickers. Only the few who truly escape the war are to be welcomed. All the others are illegal immigrants and must be expelled immediately, no ifs and buts.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Even if words, let's say a little heavy, perhaps it would be better not to use them in this House.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: - (NL) Mr President, I think it is an understatement that there are different views in this Parliament about the agreements between the EU and Turkey. At the same time, I am convinced that we all agree that implementation is crucial no matter which side you are on in this debate. I can only conclude here today that the implementation still leaves a lot to be desired, especially when it comes to the situation on the Greek islands. More people arrive every day than leave and so many more people arrive at the hotspots than ever intended. This has all kinds of consequences for hygiene and housing and leads to mutual tensions. We all still have those images from last winter in our retina, with appalling circumstances for very vulnerable people. Citizens all over Europe have seen those images and were shocked. How can we explain to them that money and resources are available, that hotel rooms can be rented, that prefabricated houses are ready, that there are sufficient stocks of blankets, stoves, etc., but that we somehow fail to deal with all those means to give 15,000 people a warm place in winter? Where exactly is it going wrong and what are we going to do to prevent it? I welcome the commitments made by the Council and the Commission that all means and instruments will be used to avoid a repeat of last year. But Parliament will hold them to those commitments. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Lenaers, you mentioned the terrible situations and conditions that the migrants were facing. It seems that each and every time when winter approaches, we come up with this winter plan for asylum seekers. Don’t you think that, besides general conditions like stepping up the relocation of asylum seekers and supporting family reunification and integration, the Commission and the Council should have to come up with a blueprint, a plan for long-term solutions for asylum seekers? So that we do not just have this kind of situation where we try to address these terrible situations that we are facing, don’t you think?

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, of course we need a long—term solution, and if I remember correctly there wasn’t even much of a plan last year, but what I wonder most of all is how it can be that we have still such a massive backlog, for instance, in the appeal procedures in Greece. If we want to have these kinds of policies working, we need to do something about that. How can it be that, as the Commissioner explained here, we have given EUR 1.3 billion in aid in order to fix the solutions for these people, but not much has happened yet. I think these are the crucial questions that need to be answered in order to come to that long-term solution. These are the basic conditions that we need to fulfil in order to have a proper solution and, yes, relocation. All these things are important, but it begins with having the power to do the things that we have agreed so far.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Mister President! The winter plan for refugees. I find it unbearable that we obviously have to say every year: Winter is coming! But on the Greek islands, for example, we are still seeing overcrowding, refugees are housed in tents and thus exposed to cold temperatures. Another humanitarian catastrophe is looming in the middle of Europe. Winter is approaching, but the pictures from last winter must not be repeated. There are solutions: the Commission and the Greek government must move more refugees to permanent accommodation on the mainland. Dublin returns must be suspended and the fair distribution of refugees across all Member States must finally be implemented. Winter is coming! Together we can prevent a catastrophe - we should tackle it. Allow me, Mr President, to make a personal comment. European asylum law is not only aimed at war refugees. It applies to anyone fleeing political persecution and torture. It is a claim that we have to implement. Even if we have not started a war in recent years, we are at least partly responsible for poverty and other developments in African countries of origin, not only because of our colonial history, but also because of our current politics. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you Ms. Sippel.I was in the hotspot in Moria on Saturday.I don't want to add anything to the description of how miserable and dirty and overcrowded it is.But I have also heard that the EASO authority there is working very slowly and not working well, so now the European Ombudsman decided in June to accept a complaint about administrative misconduct.Do you not agree that, on the one hand, you have to support the work of EASO, but also have to follow up more closely, that it works well, that there is also individual protection?

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I believe that precisely with the aim of supporting and advising the work on the ground and ensuring that the asylum conditions are respected, we have strengthened the European Asylum Support Office and, of course, it is the Commission's job to ensure that expectations are also metthat we have linked to this strengthening.In this respect, I am very much in favor of us reviewing this and organizing any support that may be required for the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Mr President, we can welcome much of what the Commissioner has said this morning in terms of preparedness for many of the countries that have been spoken of. There is a question about whether the Commission considers that the absorption capacity of those funds is adequate and the difference will really be made. I also want to add my voice to others that have talked about the importance of relocation, especially from the Greek islands to the mainland, and that we have to get rid of this agreement with Turkey that keeps people stuck on the islands, puts additional pressure on the local population there and prevents real solutions happening for those people. We also need our Member States to step up and implement more in terms of relocation. The speeding up of family reunification is still absolutely necessary; it is lamentable what is happening. What other Member States could also be doing is not trying to return people, whether it is to Bulgaria or Greece, countries under pressure, they do not have to do this under Dublin, they can take responsibility for those cases.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr Commissioner, Dear Colleagues, for the benefit of some and the misfortune of others, the summer has been prolonged throughout this Europe abroad, particularly in the south, but let us be clear, winter will come and again, we fear the worst. Earlier this year, the appeals of those on the ground echoed in this Parliament: in Greece, in the Balkans, refugees were dying and - literally - from the cold. Then, as now, we were faced with this complex puzzle of the so-called refugee crisis: lack of European solidarity, lack of human resources and financial means, a common European asylum system that is shaky and a tragedy that is happening before our eyes in the Mediterranean. But in January 2017, as now, the funds to deal with the problem had already been made available. In front of this Chamber, the European Commission said that there were flaws in the field that did not allow money to be used in the best way. After almost a year, neither the same answer is acceptable, nor is everything the same. Therefore, Commissioner Avramopoulos, in order to find solutions, we cannot be afraid to identify neither responsibilities nor the causes of problems. The question is therefore clear: who is responsible for the fact that we are still facing the same problem? Is the Greek government failing? Is the European Union not providing sufficient means? These are the questions we have to answer.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr. president. You have noticed how cold it is in Strasbourg, right? Can you imagine having spent the night with your families in a tent prepared for summer, not winter, and that this will be your reality for all this winter, for a year and for two years? For that is the harsh penalty that, by action of some or omission of others, Europe is inflicting on human beings whose only sin is trying to survive. So we demand that the Greek Government no longer keep these people on the islands. That their transfer to the continent is urgent, to be able to attend them. And we demand from fellow Council Presidents that, once and for all, the solidarity and responsibility that Europe has towards these people be developed. To the Council. I would very much like you to hear it. In reality, the original sin of all this probably lies in our agreement with Turkey, but the culprits are not the citizens who are being held on the Greek islands. Now it is OK. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: blue card question.- Mr President, Mrs Valenciano, I agree with you that we must do everything we can to improve the conditions for refugees, but, as far as I know, the relocation of refugees from the islands to mainland Greece is hindered by a Commission interpretation.on the European Union-Turkey Agreement.If so, is it not unfair to ask the Greek government for something, instead of asking the Council and the Commission?

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: "blue card" response.- No, it doesn't seem unfair to me.Here everyone has their responsibility.I do not want to hold the Greek Government responsible: I ask the Greek Government that, at least, these people be transferred to the continent in order to be treated.It is clear that the responsibility does not only lie with the Greek Government.The responsibility lies with all of us, with all the governments of the European Union and within the European Union itself.And in us, who are incapable, with the institutions we have, to serve people who have not committed any crime with dignity.Let's share the responsibility and find the solution.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: - Mr. president; Well yes, indeed, it is about preventing history, tragic history from repeating itself this winter. Look, I was in Moira and Kara Tepe and, unfortunately, I can confirm that the room containers are freezers in winter and ovens in summer. See what an asylum seeker told me: “Living in Moira makes us sick; in winter it is freezing, everything is soaked; Last winter we burned papers and plastics to warm ourselves. It is as if we are not human beings. End of quote. We are aware, Commissioner, of your efforts and your commitment to solidarity, but we must give an effective response based on the principle of solidarity, as required by Article 88 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The institutions and the member states must work together to achieve decent living conditions for asylum seekers. Above all, we must manage and ask for explanations about the incorrect management of the funds that are applied for this purpose. We must call on the Member States to move the relocation process forward effectively. The reality is that Greece alone cannot. There are fifty thousand people inside Greece and they must receive community aid. And finally, Mr. President, special attention for the most vulnerable groups: children, women and the elderly. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: blue card question.- Mr President, I would like to ask my colleague Díaz de Mera what balance he makes of the implementation of the relocation and the quota that Spain had assumed.Because, obviously, we are all talking today - you have also spoken - about the lack of solidarity of the Member States, but one of the most unsupportive countries that has been in this matter has been Spain.I would like to know your evaluation of the implementation of the relocation program in relation to Spain.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: "blue card" response.- Thank you for the question.Well, actually, I affirm that Spain's commitment is unequivocally firm.Recently, in an appearance of the competent minister in the Congress of Deputies, he said that they are willing to fulfill all their commitments and that the problem is in the hotspots, that they are not able to react in time.That is why I have spoken of management;management that means identifying, distributing and transferring.When that is resolved, of course, Spain has to be willing to honor its commitment.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, it’s not just the containers and the freezing conditions mentioned by Mr Díaz de Mera García Consuegra: over 12 000 people are now stranded in the hotspots on the Greek islands. I visited them recently in these hotspots, and the capacity is for half those numbers: there are around 5000 places. So we have a problem.  Many have mentioned what that problem is, but it boils down to two things. One, of course, is the wider political question to the Council, which is: what are the responsibilities that Member States will take on relocation and ensuring that we quickly manage the system’s Dublin III – the asylum system – to ensure that Member States meet their responsibilities. We all know that is critical. But coming back to what the Commissioner has said in detail, he admitted to the severe overcrowding and that the situation has been difficult, but he was very detailed in his response, and this is the clear focus: that funding from the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) is now coming instead of the European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (ECHO) funding by the Commission. But what is the absorption of this? Can the Commissioner say more about how effective this can be in the freezing conditions that we are about to meet, because that is very important? Can he say more about this?

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the last speech gives me the opportunity to say that we must eliminate the discourse of the emergence of winter, autumn, extreme heat in summer, but make a structural change, above all with two issues . The various systems must be homologated throughout the territory of the Member States and the quality of the standards must also be raised. Many colleagues have talked about hospitality, qualifications, that is, the possibilities we have to distinguish if there are refugees, if there are climatic people, if there are economic ones. We are doing it, the Commission is doing it and Parliament is doing it, because we are revolutionizing, for example, Dublin, and we need to know this. So the appeal is not to frustrate the work that we are doing, that Parliament is doing, that the Commission has done, and above all to tell the Council to do quickly and really not to frustrate this revolution and the change that we are making, overcome the emergency, because the humanitarian crisis is not an emergency but it is a fact that we must live with, and ultimately also increase bilateral agreements.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, more than 12 000 people are stranded on the Greek islands, in completely inhumane conditions which we have personally verified last May, in overcrowded and inadequate camps where we are often reported to be abused and cases of violence. The situation, with the arrival of the cold, is destined to be even more catastrophic. Last winter, six people died in Moria camp in Lesbos due to cold temperatures, they slept in snow-covered tents and not enough food arrived. These deaths weigh on the consciences of those who wanted the cynical agreement with Turkey. The European Union must ensure decent reception conditions and for this reason European governments cannot leave Greece alone, they must immediately expand and speed up relocation and family reunification, and above all stop sending people back to Greece according to the hypocritical criterion of the first country of access to the Dublin Regulation. Indeed, it is time for the Council to start seriously discussing the reform of the Dublin Regulation, perhaps taking an example from the strong and ambitious position expressed by the LIBE committee of this Parliament.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Mister President! Commissioner, I do not want to attack you personally, but I cannot help it. If you had given your speech here in September, I would have said: weak speech, Commissioner. But to tell us in November that we have to do something immediately - I have no words to answer you. It is not a question of you telling us here today how much money you have spent. You could have sent your accountant for that. It's about what you do to ensure that this money reaches the people effectively, wherever you step in when a national government may not be able to do it on its own. We want to know that - not how much money the Commission has spent. I know that it’s a lot. It is only of no use to us if it does not help in crucial areas. Therefore, Commissioner, I would like to tell you today: next year it will probably be winter in December. Perhaps in August or September we'll talk about what schoolwork you've finally done by then.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, today Parliament and the Commission express our concern about the inadequate preparation of the Greek authorities for the coming winter. At the same time, in Greece, the ruling party is torn by disagreements with the Minister of Immigration Policy, Mr. Mouzalas, over whether there are maritime borders, whether it is necessary to register the incoming and whether a joint statement with Turkey is useful. A statement that, precisely because it is not being implemented by us, for bureaucratic, administrative or other reasons, results in refugees and economic migrants accumulating on our islands and creating inhumane living conditions. And, just the day before yesterday, the Deputy Minister of Finance in charge of funds, Mr. Haritsis, assured us - and I read his own words - that "the implementation of the projects for the hotspots is proceeding normally". I accept that our concern is excessive and we must show confidence in the Greek government, but with one reservation. If we experience a repeat of last year's tragic situation, to demand from the European citizens the immediate resignation of the responsible Minister of Finance and the assumption by Greece of its specific responsibilities for its administrative weaknesses. With the 1.3 billion euros that have been allocated to Greece, we can not guarantee humane conditions to a few thousand people.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, setting up tent camps for incoming refugees in the Greek islands was to be a temporary solution.The decision on the redistribution of asylum seekers between Member States should also have been temporary.Unfortunately, today we are witnessing how these camps are becoming permanent and how their desperate inhabitants are losing hope of a normal life.And tomorrow, we will be voting on Parliament's mandate for negotiations with the Council, which will include a request to make the initially temporary automatic redistribution of refugees a permanent part of the European asylum system.Let us not allow Europe to resign and come to terms with a state of permanent provision.Because such a makeshift is paid for by the loss of human dignity and solidarity.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every year winter comes - it seems to me an indisputable fact - just as summer comes every year.Here, we cannot find ourselves at every beginning of the season discussing how to deal with the climate emergency of refugees.It is true, Commissioner, that the technical and financial assistance provided by the Commission in Greece and Italy has been important for many social security aspects, but once and for all we go beyond the emergency, otherwise in a few months we will find ourselves debating the plan.summer.Rather, let us discuss why, to date, over 15 000 people are living in extreme conditions, because they have not been relocated.We question the rotating presidency on how it intends to manage the negotiations on the Dublin regulation.Enough with the emergency plans, let us rather work on ambitious legislative reforms.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, severe winters in Member States with colder continental climates take their toll on people's lives every year.Every society has an obligation to take care of its most vulnerable, and homeless people in difficult weather conditions certainly are.I think it is not good to distinguish between asylum seekers and domicile residents in this matter.The extreme cold equally endangers all people who do not have accommodation and heating, regardless of their origin or legal status.But when we are already discussing a winter plan for asylum seekers, we must also ask ourselves why we receive so many people who we cannot adequately care for.How did we get into the situation of offering these people freedom and ultimately giving them illness or death in the cold?It is a question that requires an urgent answer because winter is at the door.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, Amnesty International warns that 2017 will be the deadliest year for migrants in the Mediterranean. The inhumane conditions experienced by refugees in the hotspots of the Aegean islands confirm the failure of the Union. Member States must stop denying refugees and thus violating the fundamental principles of the Union and at the same time reinforce the forces of xenophobia and racism. To stop the crime against refugees, we must oppose the inhuman nature of Fortress Europe. We therefore demand the abolition of Dublin II, the immediate abolition of the refugee exchange agreement with Turkey, the establishment of a common just asylum system based on practical solidarity, the establishment of legal and secure routes, and a permanent, binding and law-abiding system. refugees and finally impose sanctions on Member States that insist on failing to assume their responsibilities. Special care must be taken for children, as well as for the protection of the right of family members to be reunited.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: - Mister President!I would like to take up Ms. Zimmer's question from this morning again, what about Germany bringing people together who are already qualified to have families reunited.That is 4,500 people, but whose cases are being dealt with more slowly by mutual agreement with the Greek government and with the consent of the German government.I think this has to stop.Addressed to Mr Avramopoulos: You have asked the Greek government to return the country to Turkey quickly.A question for you: How can you assume that Turkey is a safe third country, where after the referendum by Erdoğan the human rights situation is extremely worse and where the number of Turkish refugees from Turkey on the EU border river Evros is increasing?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the debate we are having at the moment is the epitome of hypocrisy. They all pretend to be humanists and shed crocodile tears over the tragic situation of illegal immigrants and refugees in the winter, and this debate is taking place now that the cold has already begun. What have we done so far? We just watched the illegal immigrants coming from Turkey to Greece and we were happy because they were only a few thousand and not hundreds of thousands, as has been the case so far. Has the European Union pressured Turkey to end this unacceptable situation? The European Union tends to interfere internally, as it does now with Poland. Has it pressured the governments of non-accepting states to take their share of immigrants in order to meet their obligations? In addition, the European Union wants to turn Greece into a place of residence for these unfortunate people. He gives money and wants them to stay in Greece and not to leave Greece and, unfortunately, the slave-owning Greek government and the official opposition accept this. And one last thing: the war in Syria is over, because we are not sending again ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this is a very important discussion. At the outset, I must say that the European Union deserves credit for what it has been trying to do in relation to refugees and asylum seekers. If you look at non-EU countries, they do not do half as much as the European Union, and while we have deficiencies, that is the starting point. Definitely, countries like Italy – and especially Greece – deserve great credit because, despite the economic travails that they have had over the last number of years, they are still taking in the refugees and trying to deal with them. We should be giving them every support possible to help the situation. If migrants are illegal, they should be sent back. If they are legal, they need to be given the best possible care – especially with the onset of winter. It would be tragic that anybody who comes here looking for freedom and is legal would die because of the lack of warmth, clothing and comfort that they deserve. I am with the Commission: cooperate with Greece.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for your sensitivity and for your commitment. However, once again we find ourselves talking about the potential tragedy that threatens to affect tens of thousands of people with the arrival of the winter frost. The extreme seriousness of the situation and the current criticalities of asylum policies make it essential to intervene by adopting concrete and effective measures to guarantee immediate access to shelter for all asylum seekers, and I am thinking in particular of women and children, the most vulnerable. The unsatisfactory data on relocation and family reunification, even today, show how necessary it is to provide support, and not just economic, to the Member States of first arrival, and I am thinking for example of Greece. A renewed commitment and an effective action plan are therefore required to adequately address the serious humanitarian crisis in progress, to guarantee a dignified shelter for refugees and migrants, and secondly, finally I hope, a criterion of shared responsibility between the states.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: - Mr President, today, November 2017 and for the third consecutive year, we remember - now that the cold is beginning - the thousands of trapped refugees who live in miserable conditions. In accommodation on the Greek islands that accommodate more than 15,000 people when the infrastructure is sufficient for only 5,000, with the sea washing away corpses again and the European leadership hiding behind the joint statement with Turkey. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, tackling the refugee problem is not a meteorological phenomenon, it is a sign of the permanent European winter we are going through, especially in recent years, where humanity, culture and refugees are buried in the snow and mud. The rights of refugees, according to international law, are being violated and the illegal agreement between Greece and Germany for a numerical ceiling in the process of family reunification has caused outrage. So, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, can the procedures for recognizing refugee status be speeded up? Will a permanent European relocation mechanism finally be established? Will family reunification be implemented without shame quotas? These are the main questions that need to be answered and not to find emergency solutions to the weather.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr. president. Winter plan for asylum seekers: winter for refugees. This European Parliament cannot stop the seasons, nor can it ensure that it is not cold in winter, but it can and must change European policy and the way it is run. And the measures to increase personnel - doctors, lawyers, interpreters -, particularly for vulnerable people, are palliative. What really needs to be changed is the policy that prevented the rehousing plan from being implemented. And it must order the transfer to the continent and, therefore, to a safe, stable and lasting place, all those people who suffer horribly overcrowding in those hotspots located on islands, and particularly of the most vulnerable people: women and children. . That is what must be changed, and it cannot be subjected neither to conditions of impossible fulfillment, such as those imposed by the last rehousing plan, nor to resignation, to the absence of political will of the Member States and their governments to comply with European law.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me take the opportunity to repeat that our commitment is to help all affected countries to be ready to respond in situations like this. With winter already on our doorstep, curbing efforts is not an option. Funding at EU level is not an issue, and I know that we can count on your support for this. Through our various funding instruments, we are already responding, and we will continue to do so for any additional needs. We cannot keep having these discussions over and over again. We need a structurally ingrained response system. This is why we need to speed up the reform of our Common European Asylum System, which includes better and more adequate reception conditions across the European Union. The current system is not sustainable in the long run. We cannot continue to leave responsibility for the vast majority of applicants, whether in law or practice, to only a few Member States. We need to be ready for the future and to design a system that is effective but fair to all. This includes the Dublin IV Regulation, which Ms in ‘t Veld mentioned, and I could not agree more with her remarks. It is important that the European Parliament sends a strong message on the need to revise the Dublin Regulation, and it is time for the Council to advance it. Many of you mentioned relocation. Ninety per cent of the relocation requests submitted by Italy and Greece become effective relocations. This is a success. Thanks to the cooperation of Member States, EU agencies and international partners, we have relocated more than 30 000 people, reaching an average of 2 200 relocations a month. This is a success. Through the implementation of the scheme, we have managed to build trust among Member States, and I can tell you that this was not one of the easiest tasks I’ve had. For the future, our first priority is to relocate all those eligible under the two Council decisions. The potential for solidarity with Italy and Greece has not been exhausted, and the European Union should continue relocating. We continue to provide financial support to those Member States sustaining their relocation efforts beyond the current schemes. I hope we will not have to repeat this discussion again in the future. We are all working to achieve the same goal: decent living conditions for all migrants immediately and better, sustainable migration management in the long term. Now allow me to say some words in Greek. Mr President, as I said before, we are all working and must work together for the same purpose; all over Europe, because this phenomenon will not stop - have no doubt. We must therefore approach it with prudence, strategy, cooperation and coordination. First of all, we must continue to wage war against traffickers, destroying their business model and severely punishing these criminals. As for the European Union-Turkey declaration, I would like to note that it has contributed substantially and effectively to this. Its full and continuous implementation will contribute even more, as has been agreed. We must all contribute so that the Greek authorities can intensify the implementation of the declaration, speeding up all the procedures provided. Of course, and I agree with what has been said before, we must send a clear message that no one should risk their lives at sea to reach Europe illegally, because they will simply return to their country. This, ladies and gentlemen, does not mean that we turn a blind eye to the human tragedy taking place in the wider Central and Eastern Mediterranean region. Instead, we encourage, we support politically, we take initiatives and finance the resettlement of refugees. It is already worth noting that, of the 50,000 new posts we have announced, Member States have stated that they are ready to fill almost 35,000 of them, and we expect even more commitments. In the near future we must work together so that none of the people we are temporarily hosting find themselves again unprotected in weather conditions like the ones we experienced last year. I would like to note something else; there is neither room nor time for mutual accusations. It is true that the geographical location of Greece exposed it to great refugee and immigration pressures. This is the reality and, as I have said repeatedly, at the beginning of this unprecedented crisis, both Greece and the whole of Europe were unprepared, and I would say that they were also unprotected. Europe, however, did not leave Greece alone, just as it did not leave Italy alone, from the very first moment. Assistance has been, is and will continue to be, in the future, substantial and continuous, in means, possibilities and money. But the pressure has not stopped and we do not know when it will stop. The unpredictable weather changes and the heavy winter that broke out last year, showed a dramatic aspect of this issue. Unacceptable conditions for civilized Europe and images of shame that must not be repeated. That is why, in cooperation with the Greek authorities, all the necessary measures I mentioned above are now being taken, in order to complete the preparations without further delay. We must continue to prepare for winter and manage to do so. We must intensify cooperation at all levels. Special mention, however, must be made of the local community and the citizens of the islands who, by their attitude, have sent a message of humanity, sensitivity and culture to the whole world. Ladies and gentlemen, the A Europe of prosperity, culture and humanity cannot fail to offer protection to 10,000 people.We all share the responsibility for this: European institutions, Member States, civil society.So the responsibility is collective, the collective and the work that we have to do to fulfill this humanitarian duty.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, the Presidency, like all of us, is aware of the difficult situation that the refugees and migrants are currently facing and may face in some regions of Europe. We are committed to do everything possible to improve the situation and to help frontline countries, both in the short and in the long term. As you heard from Commissioner Avramopoulos, the Commission is indeed working with the Member States concerned, and with other international actors, to be prepared in case the winter conditions worsen.  There were references, some quite emotional, to the reform of the Common European Asylum System. First, I warn against reducing this issue – the whole reform – to just one piece of legislation, the Dublin Regulation, and within the Regulation to just this one issue of relocation, when making these statements here. This reform consists of seven pieces of legislation, of which three are already in the trilogues with Parliament. The work is ongoing, the Presidency is well aware of the urgency and of the importance of this reform, in particular the Dublin Regulation.  As for relocation from Greece and helping Greece, work has been done and the work is ongoing. The Commissioner referred to some particularities there, such as the eligibility issue and the issue of returns, and these need to be taken into account as well. But again, in broader terms of helping Greece at this moment, I want to refer once again to the thorough report by the Commission on the ongoing work.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.(The sitting is suspended for a few moments pending the formal sitting) Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - Winter is here and we continue with the same or greater deficiencies than a year ago in covering the basic needs of thousands of migrants and asylum seekers - among them many women and children - trapped in the Greek islands. On Samos and Lesbos, prepared to host 3,000 people, more than 8,000 are crowding, without adequate access to water, food, medical care or even a roof. We Socialists have managed to introduce this debate in plenary session but, unfortunately, a majority made up of political groups both on our right and on our left, have prevented a resolution from being passed in which Parliament demands concrete measures from both the Commission and to the Council. We ask the Greek Government to end the policy of containment and urgent transfers to the continent that allow dignified treatment and prevent a new tragedy this winter, and we demand from the rest of the European governments, once and for all, a minimum of solidarity to alleviate the pressure on Greece and give a dignified outlet to these thousands of human beings who have not committed any crime and who require our protection.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - These days I am receiving emails from many solidarity groups and associations, asking for urgent actions, to prevent the death of other refugees due to the cold, since winter is coming again. Last winter, six people who sought refuge and protection in Europe died from the cold in Moria. And yet the conditions in the camps of Chios, Samos, Kos and Lesbos are still beyond the limit of endurance. In recent days, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees has also asked the Greek government to quickly adapt the refugee camps on the islands, in view of winter, but the Greek authorities do not seem to have any plans to manage the new emergency. Faced with this situation so far Europe has witnessed without intervening and winter has arrived again. I'll probably be rhetorical, but what's unpredictable about this situation? The only unpredictable thing, after tens of thousands of deaths, is that Europe and its Member States wait for tragedies to grieve and I don't know what, to show a minimum of common sense and love of neighbor.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I support the call for a winter relief plan for asylum seekers.We need a plan that will help us live up to our responsibilities in the long term.Winter is just around the corner and more than 15,200 refugees and migrants are waiting on the Greek islands, with a capacity for 8,000 people.Another humanitarian catastrophe is looming.I hope that all speeches and words will soon be followed by actions, such as implementing the fair distribution of refugees among the Member States.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: in writing. Assurances that the European Union-Turkey agreement and the presence of NATO and the European Border Guard in the Aegean are dealing with refugees have collapsed. The alternating phases of refugee development follow the phases of the imperialist wars and the anti-Turkey-European Union, with refugees becoming a tool of blackmail. Refugee flows skyrocketed again. Refugees are stacked in inhumane conditions - despite the millions given to NGOs - in island camps, with a capacity to accommodate well below the number of refugees. The risk of death in winter conditions, like last year, is immediate. The situation is dramatic for refugees, construction workers and prison islanders. This was recently confirmed by the KKE MEPs through their field visits. The parody of the relocation program and the Dublin policy with the slogan "refugees away", followed by the European Union and the Greek government to discourage the arrival of refugees, in addition to confinement, also blocks family reunifications, which led to a strike refugee famine in Athens. This barbarism must stop; the immediate abolition of refugee and immigrant camps and the improvement of hospitality. To open the roads for refugees to go wherever they want.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President Kiska, it is a pleasure to have you here in the European Parliament today. The European Parliament is the heart of our democracy. Your speech is important for us, to have your ideas, your proposals. We are in the middle of the debate on the future of the European Union. To have the leaders in this Parliament is important because we want to have very good debates, very good meetings with European leaders.
