The demand for batteries is about to spike all around the world and create a gigantic market worth EUR 250 billion in Europe alone by 2025. So this is our chance to capture this market in a sustainable way. We want to be leaders in green batteries. This means clean production, sustainable and responsible mining of raw materials, recycling and reusing.  Last month I launched the EU Battery Alliance with industry and interested Member States in order to develop strong manufacturing capacity here in Europe and regain competitiveness throughout the value chain. The European Parliament and its Members have an important role to play, so I would like to invite interested MEPs to support this strategic initiative, perhaps by forming the Friends of Battery Group with us. With this package, we are sending a clear signal to the industry and investors, to public authorities and to consumers. It is also sending a message to our global partners about our ambition and continued commitment to lead in the fight against climate change.  Let me conclude by saying that this is a package that has only winners. Drivers will save thousands of euros in fuel and maintenance costs. We will see 70 000 new jobs of the future created in Europe. Investors will benefit from lucrative new opportunities, and EU car companies will be able to retain their global market share and regain consumers’ trust. We will benefit from lower dependency on external energy providers, and we will all start breathing clean air once again, saving thousands of lives which are currently lost to pollution-related diseases. The proposals are now on your table, and we hope that, together with the Member States, you can adopt this swiftly so that we can continue to demonstrate this global leadership. Mr President, if you allow me, I will now give the floor to my colleague Commissioner Bulc.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, transport is crucial for our economy and for our citizens. It employs more than 11 million Europeans and generates five percent of Europe’s GDP. But, as Vice—President Šefčovič has just underlined, transport also has negative impacts on climate and air quality, which require robust reforms. Today transport accounts for a quarter of all European greenhouse gas emissions. In addition, transport contributes to air pollution, which causes the premature death of 400 000 Europeans every year.  That is why we are taking unprecedented actions in response to this ever—growing challenge. We are reconciling the mobility needs of Europeans with the protection of our planet. Today we are addressing all dimensions of the challenge in a comprehensive, coherent and synchronised way. After the first wave of our mobility package, presented in May, we put forward a second set of measures to accelerate the transition to low emission mobility. We are delivering on all three pillars in our low emission mobility strategy: first, improving the organisation of our transport systems; second, promoting cleaner vehicles; and, third, making alternative energy more accessible for transport.  Let me address these three areas in a little more detail. First, a more efficient transport system. We strongly believe that we can significantly decrease transport emissions by further integrating the different modes of transport. For freight, we propose to revise the existing European rules on combined transport to provide further incentives to shift long—distance freight from road to rail, but also to inland waterways and short sea shipping. For passengers, our goal is to support the development of long—distance bus and coach connections throughout Europe. Citizens should have access to more public transport, with more affordable and better quality services. Decarbonising transport implies offering passengers alternative solutions to the use of private cars.  The second area is cleaner vehicles. A key element of the package is the proposal for new CO2 standards for cars and vans post—2020. Vice—President Šefčovič has already presented this but I would like to underline now that, besides the supply/manufacturer side of this problem, in this package we are also addressing the demand side. Public authorities can – and are ready to – make a strong contribution to the market uptake of low and zero-emission vehicles. So we want to make it easier for cities and local authorities to purchase, rent and lease those vehicles for their provision of public transport services or for other public use. To provide more certainty in their visibility to the market, we propose to set minimum public procurement targets at national level, which will also generate predictable demand for European industry.  That brings me to the third area, alternative energy. Consumers must have confidence that they will be able to use alternatively powered vehicles throughout Europe. For most, after a home, their car remains the second biggest item of expenditure so it must work in all conditions and everywhere. Charging an electric car along European motorways has to be as easy as filling up at the petrol station. We are therefore proposing an action plan to speed up deployment of charging points. Investment in clean transport is crucial for this to work. As part of this plan, we are now investing another EUR 800 million from the EU budget to roll out additional alternative fuels infrastructure. In addition, we propose new standards for plug interoperability, the same standard throughout Europe.  There is no single magic solution. This is why in today’s package we are combining different legislative and financial tools to maximise the impact of our measures and deploy cleaner transport sooner rather than later. The range of measures announced today means that transport will continue to play its part in tackling climate change.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - First of all, I would like to congratulate both Commissioners on the fact that the second mobility package has been presented. You know I think that is too late. We should have had it sooner. But it was a tough delivery and I am glad it is here. We will see what we can do before the elections. In particular, the emissions part of this package has received a lot of attention in the European press and would not be ambitious enough. The criticism from the NGOs is frequent. I notice that the car industry and the Member States are fairly calm. So the question is whether the Commission has struck the right balance. In any case, the European People's Party, to which I belong, stands for the right balance. Emission reduction and electrification are very important, but we would also like to stick to a technology-neutral approach. I dare to say here that the interests of industry, workers and consumers can play a major role. We will have to find that balance in the coming months or the coming year, respectively, with the aim of reducing emissions. Furthermore, the directive on the bus and coach market is of great importance. This has received little attention in the press, but this is a sector with a lot of passengers and a lot of safety issues. Finally, I would like to point out the importance of combined transport, an old wish of the European Commission and the European Parliament. This offers a lot of future, a lot of employment and can be very clean. I therefore also ask for the necessary political attention for those two dossiers.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner! On behalf of the Socialist Group, too, I would like to congratulate you on presenting the mobility package. It is not a contradiction in terms, on the one hand, to become ecological in the transport sector and, on the other hand, not only to maintain the industrial base with millions of jobs within the European Union, but also to expand it. It is also undisputed that the transport sector as a whole needs to become cleaner. For that we definitely need more efficient vehicles. We also have to help ensure that alternative drive technologies such as electromobility, fuel cells and others are expanded. And we mustn't forget that the potential of digitization is being exhausted and used. Networking will also make it possible to save unnecessary traffic. We must also try to make local public transport even more attractive and - not to forget - to support autonomous and networked driving. Now this debate about the internal combustion engine has flared up not only in Germany, but across Europe. I believe that the debate about the combustion engine is just as ineffective as it is to artificially extend its life. In this respect, I still believe that we should invest courageously in the future. And if we look at the European Union and worldwide, we see that we are very dependent on exports. We must not forget that other power centers in the world such as China, such as California - we were there recently - are making great strides when it comes to these bans and internal combustion engines. That is why I say: We really have to see that we don't throw out the baby with the bath water here, but also set ourselves ambitious goals for ourselves the future in order to become even better in the future and to make transport with lower emissions.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Ertug, you just said that the debate about the internal combustion engine and its end is an artificial one.Did I just get you wrong?I'm not so sure about that, to be honest.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you for the question.The debate is not an artificial debate; it is perhaps being discussed in the wrong direction.For me it is more about: When we talk about such topics, we have to be clear that we are also looking at the entire value chain.What does that mean if the combustion engine is ultimately banned early on?Millions of jobs depend on it.That is why I advise you not to let yourself be driven crazy, not to prolong it artificially, to invest in new technologies, to use all the levers that we already have today in order to ultimately make transport with fewer emissions.There are many components that we can discuss.That's just one of them.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Before handing the floor to the next speaker, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that our gallery is largely full.This means that the topic is important and that our guests simply want to listen to the debate from the gallery.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Dear Commissioner, Dear Commissioner! Road transport enjoys particular attention of the European Commission during this term of office. Work on the first part of the mobility package has not started for good, and we already have its second part. It takes time to change consumer habits or convince manufacturers to opt for electric cars. A system of incentives for manufacturers of low-emission cars and investments in infrastructure for charging these vehicles are needed. Only then will they not be a curiosity, but a conscious choice. I have the impression that in this proposal the goals are very well defined, but the very calendar of their implementation outlined by the Commission is extremely ambitious and will pose a problem in achieving real progress in the field of ecological mobility in the near future. On the other hand, the announcement of the revision of the Combined Transport Directive as well as the Passenger Coach Services Directive should be viewed as positive. However, I wonder if it will be possible to look at these provisions objectively in the context of our experience with the social part of the mobility package. I hope that this time, behind the promises of opening the market and facilitating cross-border transport companies, there is no protectionism and the will to further divide Europe into the East and the West.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am glad that the Commission is delivering a second package which fits very well with the first package. I am also glad that the Commissioner is presenting it under the Energy Union umbrella and that there is an integrated approach as concerns both sectors.  But let me go a little bit further. What we really need in the European Union is a change of mind-set. If we manage to change the mind-set, we will be in a better position to tackle what I see as a weakness in the European Union, and that is the complete ecosystem: it is transport, it is energy, it is industry, it is consumption but it is also research, it is a question of where we really focus and we put the utmost effort in the financial means that we can deliver. Already California has been mentioned today, China has been mentioned, and the fact is that we are not necessarily well placed today to be the leaders. We are still well placed to be highly competitive in the future if we get the ecosystem right. We need to do it on the European level, we need to do it on the national level. I would hardly find a single policy on the European or national level which would not be affected if we are to meet the objectives that we are setting in this package. I very much encourage you to pursue that direction.  Having said that, the package is one that we have to appreciate, it is well balanced. There are a number of issues that will require clarification, fine tuning, maybe higher ambition, but I would like to say that if we look at the package purely through the optic of emission targets, then we will be failing. It has to be a very complex policy approach, getting the right balance but also getting the right ambition. And that is my final remark: why are the Americans, at least in Silicon Valley, and the Chinese, successful? Because they do not update or upgrade by 10% or 20%, they want a real change, they want a revolution. This is not about the limits – this is about the complex approach that I have mentioned.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (FI) Mr President, Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I consider the objectives set out in the proposals to be fully achievable. They cannot be said to be impossible, as it has been shown that the technology could have been developed for years, but there have been no real legislative guidelines for it. As Europe's largest export sector, the car industry has always been concerned about ambitious emission reduction targets. The reality, however, is that nothing will happen in climate work with regard to transport unless the targets are strong enough and in place. Unfortunately, the emissions scandal showed us in the area of ​​transport how ruthlessly the loopholes in the legislation have been exploited for decades. I am positively surprised by the fact that the Commission now boldly dare to take the bull by the horns. I think it is a smart solution that the Commission did not set quotas for car manufacturers to make electric cars, but remained in a technology-neutral approach. With regard to public transport, it is extremely important to take action so that we can combine modes of transport and their multifunctionality, because climate change is not really waiting, but we must work together. The EU can be a “Trendsetter” in the fight against climate change, but it needs guiding legislative action. Thank you to the Commission for gaining momentum. Nothing but daring - let's move forward boldly together!

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, global greenhouse gas emissions are on the rise again. The COP 23 for the climate is currently being held a few kilometers from here, in Germany, and what are we hearing there? That we must act. Everyone knows we have to act. But what are we doing concretely to meet the objectives of COP 21 and limit warming to two degrees by the end of the century? Everyone knows that, in order to do this, the transport sector must finally reduce its CO2 emissions, which have increased by 30% since 1990. So everyone knows it. Well no, because there is a small group that resists, it is the car manufacturers, they alone refuse to see reality in the face. Unfortunately, with your unambitious proposal, they can sleep peacefully. Why settle for setting a target of 30% reduction in CO2 emissions when several European countries are calling for this 40% reduction by 2030? Why just encourage manufacturers to produce 15% of these clean vehicles by 2025, when there should be a mandatory quota, like China, which will produce 10% by 2019? Why offer them the right to pollute more as a reward, if they produce these clean vehicle quotas, and set no penalties, if not, if they do not? Your proposal is not up to the stakes. Issues that concern citizens, since the issue of pollution is not resolved, employees, since the foundations for a sustainable conversion of the sector in Europe are not laid, and European consumers, who still cannot not benefit from real clean mobility. So, I am not talking to you about future generations, I am talking about present generations, my dear colleagues, of these children who are in your schoolyards and who breathe pollution, of these people who discovered two years ago that they were the victims of a massive diesel scam and who you are asking the automakers today to trust.The climate emergency is here.We all know we're dancing on a volcano.If Trump has decided to do nothing, well Europe must be able to be the leader in action, then we will accompany you in your action, because we can no longer talk about global warming, butclimatic peril.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I have listened to the Commissioner’s speech with interest, and you may be surprised to know I have been calling for railways to be electrified. Unfortunately, many of these projects have been dropped in the UK. I see all the benefits of electric vehicles; however, I do have some concerns. Currently in the UK, we do not have enough rapid chargers to support the growth of electric vehicles. We need industry leaders to speed up the rollout of chargers. Our local planning authorities should streamline this process.  The best way to encourage the public to adopt electric vehicles is to allow nation states to cut taxes and import tariffs. Let’s remove red tape and allow the market to take its course.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the Union's policy is to develop ever more trade between Member States. Cars produced in Romania or the Czech Republic go to France or Spain, which sends its tomatoes to Denmark or Germany, which sells its pigs to Italy or Greece. This policy willed and financed by the Union has an overwhelming environmental and social cost. It is good to want to promote combined river or rail transport while social dumping has increased the transport of goods on the road. The reduced emission standards for light vehicles will not change that. We have to change the paradigm. It is local production and consumption that would significantly reduce polluting emissions. Then the Commission will be able to seriously propose its five-year plans to create, with billions of dollars, supply points for alternative energies, energies which pollute as much as conventional fuels, starting with electricity, largely - and for many years to come - produced by coal, fuel or even nuclear power plants, with their waste with a millennial lifespan.

name: Andor DELI
text: - Mr President, Vice-President, Commissioner. I would like to welcome the second mobility package presented by the Commission, which, like the first, sets forward-looking, forward-looking goals. We all agree that we need to reduce emissions from transport, but let me highlight two things. First of all, it is very important that the goals set are ambitious, but at the same time we need to stay on the ground of realities. It is not worth formulating objectives that we can assume from the outset that we may not be able to achieve them. In the meantime, we are causing a great deal of confusion in the car industry. Many of the developments that have begun and been supported so far could become futile, threatening thousands of European jobs. There is no denying that current efforts to achieve climate targets are not enough, but if we break the competitiveness and economic performance of the European car industry, losses and damage could divert resources from what is being achieved, and that emissions will be efficient. reduction. Secondly, it is very important that the goals set are achievable in all the Member States of the European Union. There are huge differences in the impact of transport on the environment between regions of the Union, due to the age of the vehicle fleet and the level of development of the infrastructure. It is therefore very important to map out the current situation and catch up with some regions.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I greet Commissioner Bulc and Commissioner Šefčovič. We are finally starting to work on the mobility package. The time is right, road transport is, as has been said, the most practiced in Europe and it is necessary to intervene to block situations that lead to distortion of competition, but also to intervene on environmental issues and road safety. We know very well that road transport is plagued by serious problems, such as illegal work and social dumping and it is our job to find the right solutions. In Europe, the cost of labor varies from country to country. Many companies take advantage of this to enter national markets at the expense of workers, their safety and with very serious repercussions on the national labor market. In Italy, to give an example that I know, under current conditions, many transport companies have to close because they are unable to be competitive in labor costs, with many companies in other countries taking advantage of regulatory gaps to offer the same work at lower costs. advantageous. Abuses and distortions must be corrected. I also ask everyone to pay close attention to the definition of cabotage, because that is where the future of many small and medium transport companies is at stake.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - (NL) Mr President, I absolutely support the fact that the Commission wants to make the transport sector greener.This is important.It is also important to invest in alternative fuels.We must strive, for example, to be able to drive electrically from Amsterdam via Strasbourg to Naples.I think there are also instruments, such as the TEN-T program, to support this from the EU.I just think that the ambitions could be a bit firmer when it comes to emissions reduction.New cars and vans must be at least 30% cleaner by 2030 than in 2021. But that ambition could be stronger for me.The new Dutch cabinet, of which my party is also a part, has said that by 2030 all new cars must be emission-free.I would also like to convey that ambition in Europe.So put it down a bit more firmly and make that 30% at least 50%.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Mister President! Thank you for submitting this package. We have to do something in the transport sector to make mobility cleaner - we all know that. Much right has been said, which I think is good. That is why I am looking forward to the discussion between the various groups. Merja Kyllönen said: We need technology neutrality. I feel the same way. Quotas to forbid something are wrong. Ismail Ertrug has pointed out that it is also incorrect to simply ban the internal combustion engine immediately. Pavel Telička said that the Chinese and the Americans don't set quotas, they just do it. Of course, that's easier said than done. In this proposal we have fixed quotas within a certain period of time, and of course it's always good to have something like that because it can then be measured. But it is absolutely correct: we have to turn a great many adjusting screws. Just banning the diesel engine, which we introduced to reduce CO2 emissions, is not the way to go, although of course it is not particularly clean - perfectly clear. With e-mobility, the only question is where the energy comes from. We have to think about platooning, we need different materials, and seaweed fuel may be able to fly airplanes in the future. We are in the process of making a number of adjustments, including in research. I think we have to follow that up, not just in the Transport Committee and the Environment Committee, but in all committees. Then we can make good progress.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr President, this second part of the package of measures for road mobility is a great opportunity to define the type of transport we want in Europe, and from my group we will work to collect some aspects that we consider essential to transform the mobility of our fellow citizens in a more efficient, smarter, more sustainable and safer mobility. First, improve the efficiency of the transportation system as a whole. The road should serve for short and medium distance distribution, as a complement to a quality regional, national and cross-border rail network. Despite the attacks and the lack of investment from many institutions, our commitment to a public and social train is irrevocable. Second, bet on safe and quality collective transport, especially in urban and interurban environments. Third, improve the conditions of workers in a sector so badly affected. And fourth, promote research and innovation in one hundred percent renewable energies. And we speak not only of economy, employment or pollution; We also talk about security, about 25,000 lives that we lose every year in Europe and that we could be saving.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: - Mr President! We are currently discussing what the future transport policy in the EU should look like. During the year, a number of proposals were put forward under the heading Europe on the way - An agenda for a socially just transition to clean, competitive and connected mobility for all. If we are to meet the climate goals, the transport sector must be restructured. Now the real work begins to ensure that it is actually carried out. The idea that all people should own their own car and that the roads should be filled with freight transport is part of history. The mobility of the future is based on trains, shipping, cycling, e-mobility and new solutions in the sharing economy. Should we hand over a sustainable and habitable planet to our children and grandchildren? Should we be able to breathe fresh air in our cities? I am convinced that we all want to, but then the responsibility rests heavily on us politicians, on companies and on civil society. We must show leadership. We Greens demand that the transport sector have ambitious, concrete and measurable goals that live up to what we promised each other in Paris. It is a policy for child-friendly cities with clean air and safe streets. However, it is also a policy for a viable countryside with efficient and accessible transport. In the cities, bicycle, walking and public transport will take up space from the cars, so that in rural areas they can still drive in the future. The fossil-free fuels we have must be enough for those who actually need the car. We Greens will work for a higher level of ambition, stricter requirements and mandatory requirements for the Member States. In our opinion, the proposals that are now on the table are far from what is actually required for us to go all the way to Paris. We Greens will fight to get there.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the Commissioners. As already mentioned several times, we are more than in favor of the modernization of the traditional transport system, which is still based today on a technology that is over a century old. However, however much we may try at the level of research and technological applications, we will not be able to make CO2 emissions acceptable by using a combustion engine and going beyond Euro 6. We must be realistic. Therefore, we must necessarily proceed with a decarbonisation of the sector, abandoning the fossil, but we must do it in an intelligent and thoughtful way, as the decisions we make today will have an impact on the industry for the next decades, with important social and economic repercussions. We cannot afford radical rethinking, as happened, for example, in the case of biofuels, and we must avoid that some unscrupulous company can fake their products to make them falsely comply with existing directives, as in the case of Volkswagen, which unfortunately we know . The transition to alternative vehicle propulsion systems cannot be one-way, but must take into account all new technologies and develop them in an equivalent way. This means that it is okay to push for electricity, but let's not forget also hydrogen and other types already widely tested, because until the source of electricity production is totally sustainable, we cannot speak of true decarbonisation. As long as the environmental cost of producing the life cycle of an electric vehicle is not always really lower than that of a traditional vehicle, we cannot be satisfied and talk about a real energy transition.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here today and for the package we are discussing because Europe, as we have said, really is lagging behind when it comes to clean energy and its associated relationship with cars and with vehicles. I very much welcome the package because it sets targets and also provides encouragement and support, as well as financial grants in some areas, to ensure that we reduce our carbon emissions and improve air quality for all citizens. I particularly welcome the focus on public procurement. I think it is very important in encouraging public authorities to use and to purchase clean vehicles. I am thinking of buses. All our major cities have buses, in fact most cities in Europe depend on buses for public transport rather than any other form of transport. It is very positive and whether it is for electric vehicles or for whatever type of renewable energy that may be used, I can see the real value in that and I can see it being very effective. Also, the EUR 800 000 for an action plan to ensure that we have charging points along our infrastructure is very positive and will encourage that. I also think that the battery initiative is good, because there is so much potential in that area where Europe are not the leaders, but Europe can lead in that area. I look forward to signing up for that package and to encouraging it, because these are the very practical measures that we need to ensure that we move in this area, because all around us we see the impact of climate change, and now is the time to act.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: - Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen Commissioners, COP 23 opened last week in Bonn, just before the publication by the Commission of the rest of its "mobility" package. The stars seem to be aligning to produce effective legislation to combat greenhouse gas emissions. The urgency is all the more glaring given that we have just learned that emissions are on the rise again this year, increasingly threatening our ability to stay below the two-degree average warming mark. But now, if the Commission package contains several interesting elements, the fact remains that the overall ambition is far below what the climate crisis requires. The establishment of emission standards for heavy goods vehicles was essential, as was the definition of low emission vehicles. But we can only regret the flexibility provided for in the quantified targets for the production of clean vehicles. The Emissions Fraud Investigation Commission finished its work in April of this year, and the way is already being paved for further exceedances of emission limits. Moreover, the Commission has still not indicated that the measurement of CO2 emissions will be carried out under real driving conditions, as will be the case for nitrogen oxide emissions. It is very regrettable. The European Union is a leader in the fight against pollution and greenhouse gas emissions, but if we rest on our laurels, if we let immediate economic contingencies dictate long-term political priorities, then who will be the driving force behind the exit from fossil fuels so harmful to health and the climate?

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Commissioner, I have followed the presentation of the second mobility package with mixed feelings. Yes, it contains interesting proposals. But I am not convinced that the package provides sufficient guidance to meet our climate commitments. By 2030, our Member States must drastically reduce emissions from the transport sector. This will not work without the necessary technology. The Commission should therefore have proposed stricter CO2 standards for 2025 and 2030. So I regret that you have not made the most of the only tool you have to encourage investment and innovation. These investments are essential if we want an innovative economy in the EU that can compete with other major economic powers. But as I said before, there are also a number of interesting proposals to be found, for example on the competitiveness of combined transport and a solid infrastructure for alternative fuels. Only through a modal shift and a switch to green cars will our mobility become cleaner. The ball is now in the court of the European Parliament. As far as I am concerned, the glass is half full, and I want to get started with this package soon because I see room for improvement.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: - The future of our earth is at stake, because the climate is changing.We must reduce emissions in transport, while the demand for transport and mobility is only increasing.The challenge is therefore very great to make our mobility sustainable.But that also offers new economic opportunities.However, transport will not be sustainable simply by publishing new proposals on paper.Transport becomes sustainable through rapid decision-making on those proposals and proper implementation in practice.Climate change does not wait for us in this Parliament to reach agreement, perhaps after months, on which parliamentary committee should be responsible for what.The outside world expects us to do our work quickly and ambitiously.So let us not waste time with each other, because our public health, our climate, our mobility issue and also our industry now require action.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, I believe that the two mobility packages are a major challenge for the EU. We now have the opportunity and, in my judgment, the obligation to ensure that workers have the strongest possible rights and that all citizens have sustainable transport and the best possible road safety. We can, of course, perceive these issues ideologically, but I am primarily of the opinion that the implementation of these points is fully in line with the remit of the only directly elected institution of the European Union, namely the European Parliament. It is therefore highly desirable for the position of the European Parliament to be as progressive as possible and to look to a future in which the interests of citizens and the planet are not put on the other side. We are dealing with complex problems here, which, if not solved, can lead to catastrophic consequences. We can make a big contribution to a better quality of life, and I hope we do not take this opportunity. What the Commission has said is a start. We have to do better.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - Mr President, the Commission's mobility package is indeed an expected and welcome package. We know that transport is, in fact, the only sector where emissions have only increased. The volume of traffic is constantly increasing, so now really effective measures are needed to stop the growth of emissions. On the one hand, we must strive to have more efficient, low-emission vehicles, we need to find more environmentally friendly fuels and, on the other, we need to design the whole transport system more efficiently, and here digitalisation offers many opportunities. It is good that the Commission has taken a technology-neutral approach in its own proposal. In my view, quite ambitious targets are being set for car manufacturers, but within a timeframe that is achievable. And car manufacturers themselves can apply for the best technology with which that emission reduction can be achieved. This is the right starting point. It is also good that the Commission wants to support research and development into the development of alternative fuels, including battery technology, and to continue to promote the construction of these recharging and refueling points across Europe. At the same time, however, it is important to remember that it will take time for the car fleet to regenerate, and therefore the fastest way to achieve now rapidly reduced emissions is to increase the use of advanced renewable biofuels, as they can be used in an existing car fleet. I am therefore quite disappointed that the Commission, in its own Renewable Energy Directive, set a really low target for renewable biofuels, these transport fuels, and there is now a debate in Parliament that it is precisely that target that should be able to be raised. It is possible to do it in a sustainable way and it is the fastest way to reduce emissions now. It will take time before traffic becomes electrified, but it is it makes sense that it should also be promoted.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, the new proposals from the European Commission to strengthen European leadership in the field of clean and sustainable vehicles are of vital importance to all citizens of the Union. Indeed, with these proposals new targets are set for the average CO2 emissions of newly manufactured cars and vans in Europe. The proposals are ambitious but at the same time realistic and accelerate the transition to zero-emission vehicles. They will stimulate both innovation in new technologies and business models, as well as efficient use of all types of transport of goods and people. I agree with the Commission's thinking, namely that in Europe there must be a clear change of pace and mentality and that the 40% reduction of CO2 by 2030 will also take place mainly thanks to transport. New types of non-fossil fuels and the use of cleanly produced electricity can make a difference. The future is not only to reduce car emissions but also to encourage the use of less polluting vehicles, develop intermodality in transport and push for digitalization to become a tool that allows us to travel seamlessly with a single ticket. . What is obvious is that the proposals presented must also be promoted by targeted financial instruments. Let us not forget that all this will benefit not only better mobility but also the health of all European citizens.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, the ever-increasing traffic in Europe is a reality and this trend can be expected to intensify. Economic growth will only increase the indispensability of transport capacities, both in the freight transport sector and in passenger transport. Of course, it is important to minimize the negative impact on the environment. The big challenge is the huge growth of digital technologies that can be used in transport. Automated systems offer amazing procedures in optimizing the management of individual vehicles. However, from the point of view of transport support, we should not give too much preference to one direction, as is the case with the preference for electric cars. Already at present, complications of sufficient electricity capacity in one area are showing with a more massive increase in electric cars, but also other aspects. Whether it is the current technological barriers of existing battery systems, their recycling, unbeatable prices and the like. It is certainly very important to support research in this area and in the whole spectrum of transport. Maintaining a degree of technological neutrality is essential, because the winner of a future battle, whether it be electric vehicles or hydrogen drives or completely different, now unknown power units, will be fundamentally decided by a tough economy and a competitive environment.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, Commissioners, we need the rules on new CO2 emission standards, the revision of the Clean Vehicles Directive, the Combined Transport Directive, the Bus Passenger Directive and the Battery Initiative. But they will only work if they land on people, knowledge and the industrial fabric capable of turning cleaner and more efficient mobility into a fertile quarry of quality employment on European soil. That is why I hope to see this legislative work accompanied by three efforts that must be noticeable in all European programs. The first is to guide industrial policy so that the Union is a world leader in the technologies and manufacturing processes of these clean vehicles, their batteries and the intelligence that connects them with each other and with the infrastructures. Second, to stimulate the appearance of new businesses and developments that evolve the concept of transport modes towards that of integrated mobility. And finally, connect the demands for new skills and businesses linked to these changes with the training offered in universities and professional schools.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioners, in fact, we are facing a mobility package, a second mobility package, which, alongside the first, also sets ambitious objectives for transport at Union level. Being responsible for one of the reports of the first mobility package, I will obviously endeavor to achieve positions that are common and balanced, which, on the one hand, will safeguard the free movement of services and goods, but also, on the other hand, will make the transport sector more competitive. We clearly need to reduce unnecessary burdens - it is a fact - but we must not give up that is the guarantee of upholding the social pillar. The goal of real decarbonization of transport within the Union must therefore be regarded as an opportunity. An opportunity, because it opens doors to innovation and research. With regard to the proposal on the trans-European implementation of alternative fuel infrastructure, we know that each country assumes its priorities and its strategy. Despite the mandatory nature of the directive in force, we are also aware that there is no coherent policy in the Union, there is no coordination of policies, and there are even differences in cross-border connections. I therefore left two questions to the Commissioners. Given these diverging priorities in the Member States, how does the Commission really want to create this European alternative fuel area? Finally, being from an outermost region, how can the Commission guarantee that these regions will not be left behind when it comes to attracting investment for alternative fuels, particularly in port infrastructure and when Member States do not have In some cases, this topic as a priority?

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: -Mr. president. First of all, we welcome this highly anticipated and long-awaited package, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner. The commitment to reduce 40% of CO2 emissions by 2030 is a goal that is built on reality, which is sometimes stubborn. We just visited Tesla in California. An extraordinary plant, but one that builds 25,000 electric cars and is still very expensive - between $ 70,000 and $ 30,000 - compared to the capacity, for example, of the Opel Spain plant in my city, close to half a million small cars and cheap. So you have to think that while we prepare and prepare infrastructure and alternative electric vehicles, hydrogen, etc. there will be a key transition period in which to replace not only the cars that pollute with others that do not pollute, but also the adaptation of thousands of workers and their jobs. And always taking into account the ecological footprint of the total life of the vehicle, be it low or zero emissions. Regarding national bus services, Commissioner, what do you think of providing a competitive and competitive service of high quality but at a very affordable price and that ensures at the same time guaranteeing the territorial cohesion of large countries or countries with difficult terrain such as mine and at no cost to public administrations, since the system is balanced and is sufficiently attractive and profitable for the private companies that assume the service? It's not a dream? Well, that dream, that system, exists in Spain. Commissioner, let's try not to spoil it, please.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is no secret that lobbying and the pressure exerted by specific companies in the Member States to make the European Union's proposal so one-sided and sometimes visibly detrimental to the interests of the parties and of carriers and entrepreneurs from Central and Eastern Europe. In recent years, a number of lobbying, a number of protectionist laws have been passed in France, Germany and Italy, which patronize local companies and hinder the common market. And this is not right and contradicts the contracts. In an attempt to help these companies, the Commission is proposing things that could endanger the lives of drivers and all road users. For example, a weekly holiday should be in a hotel, provided there are no car parks in the Member States, and these drivers must choose whether to break the directive or to protect their cargo from attacks by migrants or organized crime groups. We put these drivers in an absurd situation and then the argument to protect their social rights fades very much against the background of the real threat to other road users. I call on the Commission to listen to the positions of the Member States. It has a duty to keep the contracts and work to ensure that all entrepreneurs from all Member States can work in a way that has the same income, without such a large income gap between Eastern and Western and Central Europe.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Looking at air pollution, especially in large European cities, and the costs it entails, especially in the area of ​​health, I think no one doubts that it is necessary to introduce clean energy smart mobility. And I agree with those who say that we should not only focus on electric drives, but also look for other alternative drives and innovative solutions so that we can move away from internal combustion drives. As we all know, on the one hand, transport is pollution, CO2 emissions, but on the other hand, there are hundreds of thousands of jobs. Therefore, I think the Commissioner takes into account that the pace of change is important in order to enable companies in Europe to retrain and adapt to new challenges. We must also remember that investments in the car recharging infrastructure, which are sorely lacking today, are essential, as well as investments in energy networks, so that they can cope with the increased load. And we must also remember, Commissioner, that if we want to achieve the intended target, electric cars, for example, must meet the financial capacity of consumers, if we do not want the European market to be flooded by cheap Chinese electric cars. And it is important in all of this that the entire decarbonisation process becomes an opportunity, not a struggle for survival, for European automotive companies. We must all take this into account as well.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: - Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, the second mobility package is indeed an ambitious one which is in line with the wider strategy for renewing the European Union's industrial policy and the objectives of achieving modern European transport. . Our goal is to enable our industries to become a world leader in innovation, digitalisation and decarbonisation. However, I would like to address only two issues today: the battery initiative is of strategic importance and I welcome the Commission's decision. In the long run, we need to reduce dependence on other states, and this can only happen if vehicles and their components are designed and produced in Europe; standards for reducing carbon dioxide emissions: we will need to think carefully about the optimal level. I support the idea of ​​drawing a clear direction to support investment, but also to take into account the possibilities of each Member State. With regard to the mobility package as a whole, things remain sensitive and once again call on the Commission and colleagues to carefully weigh the impact of the new measures on the single market, but also on companies in Eastern Europe. Clean mobility is essential for our future, but it is equally important not to close down companies that provide this mobility.

name: Lara COMI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the entry into force of the Paris Agreement, the international community has committed itself to achieving a reduction in carbon emissions, moving towards a global energy transition. This transition goes far beyond the fields of transport, agriculture, construction, waste management and emissions, as it should be seen as a further element of our commitment to modernize the economy and to make it always a so-called green. economy. The proposals contained in this second "mobility" package have three main objectives: to prioritize energy efficiency and to achieve global leadership. This is a key point, because we must pay close attention to Chinese development on this issue, which already in 2020 want to be ready and the first on the market from the point of view of renewable energy and also of full-fledged electric mobility. However, we must also be able to reconcile the needs of citizens. Not all national infrastructures are ready to have truly green mobility, electric mobility and even with the use of renewable energy. Precisely for this reason, I am convinced that the objectives you have set for 2025 and 2030 can and must be an excellent deadline to involve all Member States. So absolutely good luck because it is our future that must be more ecologically sustainable.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, Commissioners, I welcome the interinstitutional agreement reached to achieve a new stage in the emissions market. It was another step towards bringing the European Union closer to meeting the Paris goals and reinforcing our potential to lead the energy transition. Soon, we will be called to new steps: the revision of the renewables directive, energy efficiency and the regulation of “governance”. These are critical steps in which mobility plays a key role and we cannot risk failing. The clean electrification of transport, combined with intelligent management made possible by new digital technologies, makes mobility one of the biggest challenges of economic and social innovation for the next decade. That is why the European Commission should be even more ambitious in the mobility package now presented: more ambitious in terms of priorities, policies and targets. We cannot hesitate in choosing. Whoever loses this battle will be irretrievably left behind on the platform of knowledge, wealth creation, employment and quality of life that intelligent mobility means. Let us, gentlemen, have the lucidity of daring. Without ambition, we will stick to the road to mourn our collective failure.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: - Mr President, honorable Commission, ladies and gentlemen!After three years of stagnation, global CO2 emissions will rise again in 2017.That is a sad certainty.The hope that the trend reversal has finally been achieved gives way to disillusionment.The transport sector is still the main source of harmful emissions in our cities and is responsible for a quarter of the greenhouse gases in the EU.The Commission sees what needs to be done.Strict emission limits for trucks and cars, infrastructure for clean drives and funding for research and production in Europe are absolutely essential.And we need to move forward with the shift to rail and ship.Dear Commission, I can assure you that with the Social Democrats you have allies for more and faster action.I know: the mobility transition is coming - with Europe's auto industry at the forefront or without it.

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: - Mr President, it is disappointing that the European Commission has failed to propose specific targets for zero-emission vehicles in this package. We are witnessing how such a policy with specific objectives in the field of energy efficiency, in European emissions trading and in renewable energy sources is yielding concrete results. It is good to have such quotas in the future so that we can have targets at both Community and Member State level. It is also good to have incentives in public procurement for electric vehicles. For example, imagine that companies that clean cities have more electric cars or trucks. As a matter of fact, there are already many countries that are actively investing in their public transport, such as China. And we can give a good example from the European Union, such as the Netherlands, where they invest, among other things, not only in electric mobility, but also in hydrogen-powered vehicles. It is also good to encourage tax relief on electric mobile vehicles by reducing taxes on such electric mobile vehicles, by giving bonuses to buyers who buy such devices, and also, for example, by providing free parking spaces in cities.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Two important topics are currently being discussed at the climate conference in Bonn. First, it is about how states can reduce their emissions in a comparable and transparent manner. Second, it becomes clear that we need ambitious reduction targets very quickly in order to be able to limit the global rise in temperature. Both are also important for regulating or limiting greenhouse gas emissions in the transport sector, which could soon be the largest sector in the EU. I will therefore work to ensure that the limit values ​​for CO2 emissions are set in absolute terms on the basis of tests on the road and that the reduction targets are ambitious and comparable. Our European automakers are very innovative and they can do more than we are currently asking for. Consumers are rightly insecure because car manufacturers have massively violated the trust placed in them. Drivers pay kilometer for kilometer on top, because the manufacturer's information on consumption sometimes deviates significantly. As a manufacturer, you should have the greatest interest in finally regaining trust. Therefore, I urge you: Stand up for ambitious goals! Let yourself be checked with transparent procedures and earn back your trust!

name: Claude TURMES
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Ms Bulc and Mr Šefčovič. I know that you are personally very much involved in bringing forward the modern logistics sector and the modern transport sector. Mr Šefčovič is fighting for batteries. Our problem is that the Commission as a whole, and especially Mr Juncker and his Head of Cabinet, have produced a very weak paper, a very weak proposal. What is the discussion in Bonn? If we want to be at zero in 2050, we also need to do something in the transport sector. When you look at the emissions in the transport sector, you will see that while in the housing sector and the power sector we have been able to go down, in the transport sector there is nothing! Why? Because the Commission and Member States have established impunity for the car industry not only as regards diesel, but also as regards CO2, for 20 years now. In 1996, Ms Merkel – then Minister for the Environment under Helmut Köhl – prevented Europe from having binding legislation on CO2 and cars. Then we had ten lost years. The last decade they have tricked us, as my colleague before has said, by giving golden cars in the laps and much fewer golden cars on the road. Now let’s look at the proposal from last week. The Commission’s own documents show that if transport is to be on track, cars need to reduce by 60%. That is according to the Commission’s own papers. On the table, only 30%! If we want to be at zero in 2050, given that the car has a 15-20 year lifetime, the Dutch government is right when they say the last moment to allow a fossil car on the road will be in 2030. What has the Commission proposed? The Netherlands has a 100% electro mobility quota for 2030. The Commission has a 30% quota, just to show you the level of ambition. In 2025, it will be 15%. VW is saying that we will have 22% of our sales in 2025. The Commission is less ambitious than VW. Then comes the big trick. Given that the Commission has only made a 15% quota, if 22% of the cars that VW sells in 2025 are electric cars then Volkswagen can take the 7% as a credit to bring more of its gigantic polluting diesel cars onto the road. Understand, we have been fooled by the German car industry and, in part, by the Commission. Therefore, colleagues, it will be our task to negotiate this upwards. I am quite optimistic. We have an alliance with a lot of governments who will not accept this unacceptable and weak document as proposed by the Commission.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Mr Vice-President Ševčovič! Commissioner Bulc! Let me say that I am pleased that you have submitted this document. Maybe it is a bit of a bad thing that the first and second packages go almost parallel and sometimes overlap in the debate. What do I build my satisfaction on? Firstly, the Commissioner, in particular, was realistic about the matter: yes, we will need transport, we will have to carry more and more and we will want to be transported more and more. It is unavoidable. And yes, it is also important socially, as an element of quality of life, but also from the point of view of jobs - when changing technology, we do not have to lose jobs. Secondly, you referred to a kind of new situation - the post-petroleum era and post-petroleum. And I believe this day and today's debate that perhaps this will turn out to be such a historic starting point. Another remark: if there are any percentages, dates, numbers in this document, I immediately come with the conviction that it will not be true, but the direction you are giving is what we mean. This inspiration to go towards research, development, batteries, engines, intelligent transport systems, energy supply, i.e. a kind of refueling system, finally the rules of movement, an intelligent system - this is what can create this quality, beginning, impulse. And for that there is recognition.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - I welcome the initiative, in particular the proposals to reduce emissions, incentives for change in the car industry and among users, and greater use of rail in freight transport. In Europe, as many as 12.6 million jobs are related to the automotive industry, and in Slovenia it employs 24,000 people. We can't care what her future holds. The new standards and targets give the industry a clear signal and incentive to adapt to the new situation in order to remain competitive and retain jobs. The shift of freight traffic from roads is not only necessary due to emissions, but also due to congestion and destroyed roads and traffic accidents. This is especially important for transit countries such as Slovenia. The possibility of financial incentives is good, but many members, including Slovenia, will have to do their part of the homework to establish an appropriate railway infrastructure. Finally, the public sector must be the bearer of positive change. However, there will be no major expansion of clean vehicles as long as travel with them is inflexible and must be adapted to the location of charging stations.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, of course, some of you have said here that the Commission's proposal is too unambitious, others that it is too ambitious. I will say that it must be realistic and I want to make some arguments. I'm glad you have this concern, I'm glad your proposal is moderate because we need to think with a broader vision of how we can make these changes without disrupting not only the car industry - here we are talking about an entire industry: suppliers , small and medium-sized enterprises that make semi-finished products, that make accessories, that make spare parts. So I agree that transport needs to reduce the percentage of 4% that is currently contributing to pollution, but we need to think that we need investment, technology, we need to talk here about a missing infrastructure and maybe, Commissioners, you are not thinking about how to get to cars, but how to get on electrified railways, how to get from road transport to rail and, of course, how we think of national and local budgets as those means of transport that make service for public transport to be the first to change the fuel, be it electric or alternative fuel.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the link between mobility and transport and the environment and energy is interesting. In this context, the rights of passengers, not only buses but also airplanes, are central. Mrs. Bulc, I would like to inform you that, according to today's publication of the newspaper "Proto Thema" and the website, by decision of the German government, passengers from Greece will be quarantined until May 2018. Thus, the use will be prohibited disembarkation bridge (bellows). Those passengers coming from Greece will go by bus to a special checkpoint, where the federal police and security services will check them thoroughly and then they can go and pick up their luggage. There is a serious issue of the rights of European Union citizens and passengers alike, and I want you to see that. We denounce it because it is a decision of the German government with effect from 12 November 2017 until 11 May 2018, in the context of Schengen exemption decisions. Please see it, because it is a serious issue of violation of passenger rights.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - This is an extremely important topic, in fact it is about our future in many areas as well, and I think that what has been presented touches on many areas. Of course, in the field of the environment, in the field of energy, infrastructure, transport, of course, but it will also have an impact on the field of social affairs and many other areas. So, of course, I am mainly interested in how the Commission will be able to coordinate all these segments, this whole sector into a cohesive whole, which can then lead to meeting the goals we set, which in one part could of course be more ambitious. Above all, I would like to draw attention to another aspect that is extremely important, and that is also the area of ​​security. I think that all these efforts that are being made must ultimately have a significant impact on safety, in addition to, of course, emissions and other elements. Therefore, of course, I sincerely wish that this freight transport be put on the railways as soon as possible, and thus reduce the risks that arise and all the accidents that cause it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I appreciate the ambition of your proposal.Of course, we know that the car sector employs 12 million Europeans and is therefore the main force in emissions, greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union.At the same time, therefore, it is the potential where it is possible to reduce emissions.The automotive industry is already following this trend.On the one hand, it reduces emissions and, on the other hand, it is gradually leaving internal combustion engines.Of course, this applies not only to the European Union, its institutions, but therefore also to the car manufacturers themselves.Nevertheless, I think that the proposal for those binding limits is perhaps too ambitious.Reduce CO2 emissions by 30% in 9 years, it really won't be easy.However, I appreciate the certain flexibility you have left for the solution to both manufacturers and Member States.Thank you and I wish you much success.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: - (The speaker speaks without a microphone) ... I am delighted with your report.I have been involved in carbon policy for 25 years and I have to honestly confess to you: I expected worse.I think the report is a step in the right direction.But let me remind you that for the past 25 years we have had constant horse-trading with the automotive industry.You have to be tough.It is good that you prefer technology neutrality.Some colleagues will see it differently.I think that's a good thing.One question: why didn't you introduce a malus system in your bonus system?Those who want to push away are positively motivated.That would be my quick quick remarks.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would also like to thank the honourable Members for a very rich debate. I would like to express my appreciation for the fact that in most speeches we felt very strong support for our proposals. Together with Ms Bulc and our energy union team, we are very much looking forward to working with you at such a pace that we will not only make this proposal and have a debate on it, but we will definitely adopt the whole package and make it law before the end of our mandate. The word which was probably used most frequently in this debate was ‘more’ and we very much appreciate your support for more ambition, more investment in the infrastructure and more focus on future technologies. I think that if we look at the long—term vision, we would of course like to have mobility with zero emissions, where we would have zero accidents and there would be zero congestion. I think that all this is possible if we kick—start our car and transport industry right now. This is what we are trying to do. Therefore we propose the most realistic path, namely the curve of a 30% reduction in emissions with a benchmarking system and with very harsh penalties if this 30% reduction is not met by 2030. But we also wanted to offer the industry incentives to give them the flexibility to be technologically neutral because we can see how quickly the science and research is evolving. I do not think we can really say today what the winning technology will be. We just know that it will be emission—free technology in the end. I would also like to highlight the fact that we are really working here on this cross-cutting basis because by 2030 we want to have more than 70% of our electricity carbon—free. I want to use this clean energy to power our clean cars and to give them the ability to store that energy in green batteries. That is the paradigm change that we are pushing for and we would very much like to achieve. When it comes to experience from the past, I believe that we can learn from this and therefore we are proposing very rigorous systems of controls, market surveillance, real—driving emission tests and in—service conformity checks, which would really tell us if we are on the right track or if we are deviating from it again. I can assure you that we in the Commission – and I am sure this House as well – will be very vigilant in order to make sure that we achieve the target we have set for ourselves. If you will allow me, I will now pass the floor to Ms Bulc, but I would like to thank you all very much for your supportive spirit and for all the dynamism which I believe we will need to make sure that this package is adopted before the next European Parliament elections.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you, in my name too, for a very rich and engaging debate. I am particularly happy to hear that there is a broad consensus on the need to take a comprehensive approach to reach the necessary level of ambition. Let me really quickly summarise the package and I hope you will recognise this in our proposal as well. First, we do address vehicles, infrastructure and necessary changes in the use of fuel or ‘energies’, as we are probably going to call them in the future. We do address demand and also the supply side at the same time. We do address passengers and freight at the same time. We do address CO2 emissions but also noise and other emissions. We do address road transport but also other modes. Why? Because all modes of transport have a role to play in achieving low emission mobility. Public transport must be a real alternative on the European transport market. This is essential for the environment but also for territorial and social cohesion for our entire Union. Decarbonisation, I believe, is good for all of us; it is good for citizens, it is good for businesses and it is good for all Member States. So I am really looking forward to constructive discussions but let us also move as far as possible under your mandate.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing.- The second part of the mobility package presented by the Commission today is an ambitious set of legislative proposals.As a general rule, the proposals put forward are a step in the right direction and can facilitate the transition to low-emission and zero-emission vehicles, which could have a positive impact not only on the environment but also on the European industry, which will maintain its competitive position in the global market.However, it should be borne in mind that introducing the proposed changes will not only be a burden for the authorities of the Member States, but also, especially in the case of the revision of the Public Transport Directive, for local and regional authorities.For this reason, in the course of work on the package, solutions should be sought that will avoid overburdening local governments with excessive costs and administrative procedures and will retain some flexibility in the selection of funds.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Marlene Mizzi, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the Annual Report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2016 (2017/2126 (INI)).I take this opportunity to welcome Mrs Emily O'Reilly, European ombudsman.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the importance of the role of the European Ombudsman in protecting citizens’ rights and strengthening citizens’ confidence and public trust in the European institutions cannot be emphasised enough. This is the only mechanism that holds the EU administration to account and investigates cases on behalf of our citizens. The European Ombudsman is the guardian of good administration, ensuring that the EU institutions function properly and do not encroach upon citizens’ rights. In this regard, I would like to congratulate the Ombudsman, Emily O’Reilly, for her excellent work in improving the quality and accessibility of the Ombudsman’s services and for increasing the visibility and impact of the work of the European Ombudsman. Ms O’Reilly, has accomplished a lot since her election by this House as European Ombudsman, back in 2013. The quality of the Ombudsman’s Annual Report has been improved. Now the report is clearer and easy to read. Public administrations need to become more citizen-friendly, and I think that you have achieved this milestone with your Annual Report. You have also improved the role of the Ombudsman’s strategic inquiries and initiatives by pursuing, on your own initiative, important topics in the public interest of the European citizens, such as the transparency of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. New working methods were introduced and case handling procedures were streamlined. This enables greater flexibility and efficiency of the Ombudsman services, aimed at deepening the dialogue between people and institutions. You have also maintained excellent cooperation and a positive engagement with the European Parliament and in particular with the Committee on Petitions. And last, but certainly not least, you have made the Ombudsman services more visible. According to the Flash Eurobarometer survey of March 2016, 9 out of 10 EU citizens are familiar with their status as European citizens and their right to complain to the Ombudsman. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their valuable input during all stages of preparing this report: our cooperation was very fruitful and I did my best to accommodate most of their contributions. I think we all share the view that in such turbulent times, when the European Union is facing unprecedented challenges – such as the unemployment crisis, the migration crisis, Brexit – the role of the Ombudsman in bridging the gap between people and the EU institutions is crucial. Unfortunately, transparency, openness, access to information and documents, respect for the rights of citizens, and high ethical standards are still the top citizens’ concerns in the cases investigated by the European Ombudsman. The level of quality of our institutions needs to be reflected in the level of support from European citizens. Trust between citizens and the institutions is of paramount importance. We need to work on that if we are to get a mandate from our citizens to do what needs to be done to protect European citizens and Europe. Achieving the highest possible level of transparency and access to documents must be the rule. Whenever there are any exceptions to this rule, they should always be weighed against the principles of democracy. I would just like to point out that 100% transparency will probably never be possible in the light of certain legal considerations. However, my report strives to have the highest possible level of transparency and access to documents, in particular when it comes to the EU’s economic and financial decision-making process, trade or trilogue negotiations, and even on the ongoing negotiations between the EU and the UK. The report also notes maladministration with regard to the Code of Conduct of Commissioners. When it comes to ‘revolving door’ phenomenon of conflicts of interest, it is clear that the highest moral and ethical standards need to apply to all EU institutions. We need to secure respect, and this can only be done through absolute integrity and full independence from the private sector. We want to see a revision of the Code of Conduct of Commissioners. In view of this, it is also time to comply with the Ombudsman’s suggestions for improving the EU Transparency Register by making it a mandatory central transparency hub for all EU institutions and agencies. In view of the emphasis on good governance, I also want to support the Award for Good Administration, which acknowledges best practices in the EU administration and which brings them to the attention of our citizens. Finally, I would like to say that I am very satisfied with the report of the Ombudsman and I wish her the best in her future work.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: Ombudsman. – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Mizzi and all the shadow rapporteurs for their work on this report and to thank them once again for their strong support, which I greatly value. This is my fourth time of addressing the honourable Members in plenary. We draw inspiration, honourable Members, from your work as you reflect the concerns of the citizens that you represent and it is my role also to try to deal with similar concerns of citizens. I also very much welcome the presence again of First Vice—President Timmermans to this debate and I thank him for his support for my work. As you know, a majority of the complaints that we receive are directed at the Commission, given its role and its high level of interaction with citizens. The Commission continues to engage positively with my office and, while no relationship is ever perfect, we both do our best to deal with challenging issues.  This report, however, shows that increasing attention is being paid by my office to the Council. Rising public awareness of its role and greater demands for transparency have prompted this additional scrutiny and perhaps in future years Parliament might consider inviting a Council representative also to attend this very valuable annual hearing. Today’s draft report expresses support for my strategic inquiry into the transparency of the Council’s working parties and Coreper committees and a positive outcome would help, I hope, to dispel the perception that EU institutions are not transparent and therefore not sufficiently accountable. Citizens are not always aware that the Council is not just a so—called ‘Brussels institution’. As the French President Macron said recently, ‘Brussels is us’ and greater Council transparency will, I believe, lessen the temptation to blame Brussels for decisions taken by Member State Ministers and Governments as citizens will see precisely where responsibility lies.  I fully appreciate how hard it can be to get consensus or a majority vote on some matters, but when Parliament and the Commission are clear on where they stand, it can be frustrating to citizens when the failure of the Council to reach a common approach, or even take a vote, means that some proposals remain stalled, sometimes indefinitely. It is, for example, now over a year since the Commission made its proposal for an improved Transparency Register and Parliament agreed its negotiation mandate earlier this year. However, the Council is now delayed in agreeing its mandate to enter talks. I very much welcome the efforts of the Estonian Presidency to unblock the impasse and I very much hope that agreement can be reached before the elections in 2019. Transparency in itself, of course, cannot deal with every Union problem, but it can throw light not just on the respective responsibilities of the EU institutions, but also dispel some of the false facts and fake news that increasingly impact on the way in which the EU is mediated, and I note and welcome First Vice—President Timmermans’ announcement this week of a public consultation on this matter.  Fake news is ultimately about influencing, with a view to undermining, the democratic process. Lobbying transparency can help to reassure citizens that when it comes to the influencing of the EU institutions, measures are in place to help to mitigate its more negative impacts.  Other transparency work by my office in 2016 included an exchange with Eurogroup President Dijsselbloem, encouraging moves to open up the work of that very important group. Obviously, as the Eurogroup is not officially an EU institution, my mandate is limited, but I did welcome the President’s initiative in attempting to further the transparency of its decision-making.  Many citizens were concerned about what they perceived as the lack of accountability of the troika and similar concerns are at times expressed about the Eurogroup and indeed about the Council. Greater accountability through transparency is an obvious way to help to rectify this citizen alienation. I continue to raise awareness among my colleagues in the European Network of Ombudsmen about important EU issues.
