Last June, I hosted our annual Network Conference in Brussels at which we discussed open government, populism in Europe and, of course, Brexit. I wish to thank First Vice—President Timmermans for his keynote speech. It meant a lot to colleagues from all of your Member States to be able to have that direct engagement and I have rarely heard such lively post—seminar conversation. I would also like to thank Ms Cecilia Wikström and other MEPs for their support for these events and their much appreciated contributions to them. This report today also recognises the work of my office in several other areas. These include the transparency of the Brexit talks, continued work with the ECB and the EIB, an ongoing inquiry vis—à-vis the Commissioners’ Code of Conduct, improvements to which the Commission has already proposed, a new Ombudsman’s guide for EU officials on dealing with lobbyists, our work on the EU whistle—blowing rules to protect EU staff, an inquiry into the Commission EU pilot programme for infringement, the ongoing work with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the European Citizens’ Initiative, which the Commission is now revising.  Let me also briefly mention some routine cases dealt with in 2016. There was a complaint from the Polish Research Institute, which undertook three EU co—financed projects. The Institute turned to us after the Commission decided to recover some costs related to the subcontracting of the work. However, following our inquiry and a document inspection, the Commission agreed to waive the recovery of around EUR 86 000.  A Spanish citizen complained about the lack of translation of Commission public consultations. The Commission agreed that public consultations relating to their work programme priorities will in future be in all EU languages. Another case in 2015 was when the European Chemicals Agency agreed to our proposal to require those seeking to register chemicals to show that they have tried to avoid animal testing. These are just three of the over 1 800 complaints we dealt with in 2016. We have also been revising our internal working procedures and working methods. I wish to thank both the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control for recognition of this work. We will soon be launching a fast-track procedure for dealing with access to document complaints so that we can get answers for citizens within weeks instead of months or even, in some cases unfortunately, years.  Next year we plan to request a moderate budget increase to hire extra multilingual staff. This is due to the fact that we are experiencing a sizable increase in complaints this year. We believe we have implemented large efficiency reforms internally and now need that extra capacity to really improve again our service to citizens. Finally, I wish to note again the high standards of the EU civil service. Indeed to recognise that work and to share best practice across the institutions, we launched in 2016 the Ombudsman Award for Good Administration, receiving over 90 nominations. The award ceremony was particularly memorable and I was struck by the great pride of the officials in their work and their joy in having it recognised at a time when so much of what they do is either unseen or criticised.  Thank you again to the rapporteur Ms Mizzi, the shadow rapporteurs, their staff and the secretariats for all the work on this year’s report, which I and my staff greatly appreciate. Thank you to the Members of Parliament who, through their active engagement with the office, helped make our positive work more effective.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Marlene Mizzi for a really excellent report which helps us improve the service we provide to our citizens. It also gives me the opportunity to join Marlene Mizzi in expressing my admiration for the work done by Ms O’Reilly as our ombudsman and the progress she has made with her office in 2016. She has helped us to prevent, identify and solve instances of maladministration by the EU institutions, and every citizen has a right to good administration. It is indeed a fact that the Commission is one of the main addressees of the Ombudsman’s inquiries and that we comply with her recommendations or suggestions whenever possible. Sometimes we disagree and explain why, but such cases remain limited. The overall compliance rate is very high at 82%.  Both the ombudsman and the report call for greater transparency. I am in full agreement on this. The EU institutions must meet the high transparency standards that citizens rightly expect. We live in a different society. We are no longer in a ‘trust me’ society. We are in a ‘show me’ society, and our citizens ask us to explain what we do in full transparency on a daily basis.  As you know, this Commission decided to apply the highest transparency standards upon itself. A key principle is that lobbyists can only meet Commissioners, their staff and Directors-General if they are in the Transparency Register. No registration means no meeting. But we need to go further. The register must become mandatory for lobbyists. This can only happen if that same principle is applied across the board in all three institutions – the Commission, Parliament and the Council. For example, a lobbyist who is not in the register should not be able to meet a Member of the European Parliament. Only then would registration become truly a sine qua non for lobbying the institutions. So I call on both the Council and this Parliament to commit to the same standards in the forthcoming interinstitutional agreement following the Commission’s proposal of September 2016.  As Ms O’Reilly has explained, we are still waiting for the Council to adopt its mandate, and it really is high time for us to be able to start negotiating about this. It would really be a shame if we did not finish this before the next European elections.  The report also touches upon access to documents and publication of information. Each year we proactively make public tens of thousands of new documents on our web pages, but we plan to go further, for example, by publishing an overview of each Commissioner’s mission expenses every two months.  I also fully agree that transparency in trade negotiations is essential to ensure public trust in the EU’s trade policy. This Commission took major steps right from the very beginning of its mandate. President Juncker announced, in the 2017 State of the Union speech, that the Commission would publish all its recommendations for negotiating directives for trade agreements. He added that the European Parliament, as well as national and regional parliaments, would be kept fully informed from day one of the negotiations.  Finally, let me stress that the Commission is making sure it abides by the highest standards of ethics and integrity, including by updating them when necessary. The draft new code of conduct increases transparency and sets higher standards for Commissioners, including on post-mandate activities. It incorporates several suggestions made by the European Parliament and the European Ombudsman. Without her, we would not have been able to reach where we are now.  Let me conclude by saying very clearly that this work is never finished. We will always have to improve our standards, improve the way we perform and apply the most forward-looking standards in the quality of administration we deliver for our citizens, and an integral part of that is a maximum level of transparency and accountability. I really want to thank Ms O’Reilly for helping us to reach that level.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to take this opportunity to thank Ms O’Reilly for her efforts and for the fact that she and her staff are constantly good to cooperate with, but also for the excellent quality of her work. I would also like to thank the rapporteur for her work: she managed to prepare a very balanced, well-structured report that tackles all the areas of the important work carried out by the European Ombudsman. I have been closely monitoring the activities of the European Ombudsman from the very beginning, and I greatly appreciated Ms O’Reilly’s work last year. I say to her: you managed to make the post more visible, and your communication strategies, your ideas have contributed to making this office more citizen—friendly, and I really thank you for that. You have proved to be a very efficient Ombudsman, which I also appreciate. You undertake many important initiatives which tackle the current policies of the European Union. This annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman serves not only as a summary and approval of the work of the European Ombudsman in a given year, but it is also a reminder to us and to all the European institutions to be more service-minded, to be more open-minded regarding our citizens. It is very important to encourage the European Commission in its efforts to facilitate access to documents and information, especially with regard to EU pilot procedures. It is very important to provide as much transparency and communication to our citizens as possible, especially because many myths have been created, particularly regarding trade negotiations. However, we have to keep in mind that this transparency should never undermine the negotiating position of the European Union – there is a balance there. Ms O’Reilly, once again, thank you very much for your work, and good luck. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the "blue card" procedure.- Dear colleague, I totally agree with what you said, but I would like to ask you about the last part of your speech: do you think that there are too many rules - and I am referring now to the proposal made by the Commissioner - regarding the possibility of MEPs meeting?with citizens, with professional associations does not create an obstacle in communication?After all, we meet to talk and inform each other.I see this as a barrier to communication between us, the elected - it is not about the commissioners appointed, I am talking about MEPs and citizens and professional associations.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: blue-card answer. – You tackled a very important point, but I think Mr Timmermans said it best: this work will never end. We will try something at one point, if it works then will to try to improve it further. But if it does not work, then we will have to change to something else. In our committee, the Committee on Petitions of this House, we are the closest to the people of European Union. As such, we are the best advocate to see how best to improve communication between us, the institutions of European Union and European citizens. So, yes, this is an ongoing process, and I believe that only together we can make it better.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, first of all, I too would like to thank the Ombudsman Ms O’Reilly for her excellent work, and also our rapporteur in Parliament and First Vice—President Timmermans for his very important remarks on transparency. Let me just stick to that topic – transparency – because I think we live at a time when many citizens feel very alienated with regard to institutions, to politics, to governance. I think one of the most important issues here for regaining trust, including in our institutions and our democracy, is actually access to information – transparency, accountability – and therefore the work that the European Ombudsman is doing in this field is so important.  I am looking at the Council side now and I have to say that the Council and many of its working groups are keeping us in the dark. Many of us have had concrete experiences of this, for example the Code of Conduct Group for business taxation. They are supposed to phase out cross—border harmful corporate tax regimes in Europe. They work in secrecy. They work in unanimity; we do not know which countries are blocking or deluding this very important work to ensure fair corporate taxes in Europe. Things like that are alienating citizens and also cause the European Union to be blamed for not acting on very important societal issues.  Therefore I just want to say to the Ombudsman: full support for your work on transparency and we need to stand together to push the Council to open up and become democratically accountable to its citizens. We need to be much more blunt and they need to change their attitude, because if they do not do this, then mistrust of the European Union will continue.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, let me begin by congratulating the European Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly, on her excellent work. The role of the European Ombudsman is crucial for the transparency and control of maladministration within the European Union. At this stage, it is crucial to extend this control to other institutions, such as the Eurogroup, the Troika and the ESM. We tabled amendments, which were unfortunately rejected by the other political groups. With regard to the Troika, it should be noted that the European Ombudsman should investigate the conflict of interest in the Commission, between her role in the Troika and the responsibility of the Commission as guardian of the Treaties of the European acquis. The same applies to the conflict of interest between the ECB's current role in the Troika and its mandate to act as an independent monetary authority. In addition, an investigation is needed into the Troika's compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Accountability and transparency must also be strengthened at European level, in relation to the Eurogroup and the ESM, which make painful decisions and impose austerity and violent fiscal adjustment, as has happened with Greece over the last seven years. Finally, there needs to be further substantive research into the public-private switching phenomenon, as in the case of former Commission President Manuel Barroso, who took over as executive chairman of Goldman Sachs International. I wish Mrs. O’Reilly good luck in her work and she knows that we support her struggle.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, it is lawful to congratulate Mrs O'Reilly for the magnificent job she is doing of her as an ombudsman. It is not courtesy, it is sincere recognition. There is something that, in any case, worries me, which is the low number of people who turn to the ombudsman to be able to present their complaints, compared to what happens in the Member States, where the number of complaints does not correspond with the institutions in the Member States being worse than those of the European Union but, perhaps, with a greater and easier practice. I think this is an issue that we should examine. There is something that is important, I think it is fundamental: that there is collaboration between the ombudsman of the European Union and those of the different Member States. There are issues in the report that seem extraordinarily relevant to me, for example the issue of transparency. Transparency should be the norm, not the exception, and this is how it stands. But transparency should not be linked with what I would call "naivety." We cannot be so naive that, on issues such as, for example, the Brexit negotiation, we are of such a level of transparency that we are giving all the arguments to our counterpart in the corresponding negotiation. Transparency is one thing, naivety is something else entirely. Let us, therefore, be responsible for our own limits on transparency, which I certainly claim. There is something also important, which is the clear and defined position that exists with respect to lobbies of all kinds, from the tobacco lobby to the medicine lobbies. We all know that the lobbies are there to try to influence the deputies, but there have to be limits, which is the code of conduct, which has to be rigorously implemented. The same applies to the code of conduct of the president of the European Commission when he ceases to be so, or the commissioners themselves or the advisers.The revolving door story has to end, and it has to end for good.And if the code of conduct has to be reformed, reform yourself, because it is an outcry in the face of certain scandals, no matter how legal, however legal.In any case, this is a report that you have made, which is not complacent.It is a sincere report and it is a report that has audacity, and I want, in that sense, to acknowledge your work and your role.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Ombudswoman on her clear, detailed and user-friendly report for 2016, while noting her constructive co-operation with Parliament's Committee on Petitions. Undoubtedly, all the institutions and bodies of the European Union must continue to respond within the deadlines and improve their degree of compliance with the Ombudsman's recommendations and decisions. In particular, I urge the Ombudsman to step up her efforts for full transparency and access to information and documents relating overall to EU Pilot procedures, tripartite dialogues, trade agreements and BREXIT, and financial decision-making processes. At the same time, I call on her to insist on a mandatory Transparency Register and the effective protection of witnesses in the public interest. Finally, on the occasion of the episodic recognition of the European initiative "STOP TTIR", I call on it to shield the institution of the European Citizens' Initiative with an immediate review.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - I am sorry that today the hall is more empty than full because it is an extremely important topic. I think that these reports that we are receiving in Parliament are extremely, extremely important, and that the role of the Ombudsman in this world we live in today is all the more important in the light of all the challenges, all the discrimination that is happening and all the risks. . Above all, in a way, this report also represents a mirror of the functioning of the European institutions. Many European institutions, as well as in some cases countries, can see where the citizens of the European Union see the biggest deficit and thus the gap between the expectations of Europeans and, on the other hand, of course, the European institutions. I would like to point out a few things that I find extremely important. One of the things is transparency and the so-called democratic deficit. It is simply because we cannot have and live a democracy if we do not have adequate transparency, if we do not have adequate transparency, and here the role of the ombudsman is all the more important. Therefore, of course, I very much want greater transparency of governance in trilogues as well, so that documents and positions of individual countries are publicly available when voting on individual pressing issues in the Council, which would help citizens understand the origin and history of certain decisions and thus also to consider how individual countries have actually reacted to important things. Of course, I also call on the Ombudsman to continue his inquiry into the functioning of the European Union agencies, focusing on the Food Safety Agency and the European Chemicals Agency on Monsanto and the possible consequences of sustainability and conflicts of interest. Above all, I think it is important to lobby, the registers must be known here, including whistleblowers, including people with disabilities, and I think that these are many issues that we want to make the functioning of the European Commission and the European structure clearer. But I would like to point out something else, namely in a way, the importance of the European Citizens' Initiative as an essential form of democracy available to citizens.Therefore, I think that it would be necessary to consider how to make this initiative as operational as possible, also so that the Commission does not decide for itself which initiatives it recognizes and which it does not, and I think that there is still much room for improvement in this area.we want to really make the European Union and, of course, the European institutions democratic and closer to the citizens.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for Italy today is an important day. The law proposed by the 5 Star Movement on whistleblowing has been approved. From today, the fight against corruption will be given new life and whistleblowers and witnesses of crimes in the public and private sectors will be protected. At European level, it is also thanks to the tireless work of the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, that I want to thank, that this fight is going on. And I also thank the rapporteur Mizzi. Her report contains a clear recommendation on the protection of whistleblowers who play a crucial role in uncovering instances of maladministration and calls for the introduction of whistleblowing legislation at European level. We have an excellent relationship. However, I want to reiterate two concepts that I wanted to express by means of amendments that we will vote on tomorrow. When we talk about access to documents and transparency, we must remember that these are basic principles on which to build the house of institutions, a house of glass. Today, however, this is not the case, as the citizens' complaints and the Ombudsman's inquiries show, today the rule is opacity and transparency is the exception. We must reverse this situation and make full and complete transparency the rule of the functioning of institutions, of decision-making processes in trilogues, of information relating to infringement proceedings, of commercial negotiations and so on, and only sensitive and privacy-protected data must be subject to restriction and protection. Finally, as regards the transparency register to monitor lobbies, the commitment to improve it, required by the report, to make it mandatory and transparent for the EU institutions and bodies, is good, but it is not enough. We need a legislative act, therefore a regulation, so that the register is legally binding not only for the institutions, but also for the stakeholders.This, by the way, is exactly the recommendation of the European Ombudsman.Tomorrow, by voting in favor of our amendments, we can make it fully reflected in the text of the report.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The good cooperation between the rapporteur and the other political groups and our EPP rapporteur Jarosław Wałęsa has produced a good report. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs. Again this year I would like to thank our Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly, for the good and trusting cooperation and to congratulate her on her good work. Due to time constraints, I would like to address two things that are important to me. The first: You said that yourself, Ms. O'Reilly: You are working on a fast procedure. If you have a good solution, we are interested in it ourselves. As a member of the Petitions Committee, it sometimes takes too long for our petitioners to get an answer. If you have found the Philosopher's Stone here, please let us know so we can work together there too. The next problem area has already been mentioned several times: transparency. So I turn to my colleagues on the Petitions Committee once again: Here we all have to rework together, as the saying goes: everyone sits down without foaming, without ideological prejudices! Perhaps it would be much, much easier for us here if we first set the limits, and then we could plow the vast field of transparency together. Tomorrow - this is a small flaw - we will also notice the differences in voting behavior in the field of transparency. But once again my appeal to everyone: In terms of transparency, we all have homework to do again. But I also recognized the nuances, including from my colleague Evi, that she might be thinking in the same direction. Transparency is important and good, but there are also limits. With that in mind, I look forward to continued good cooperation.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Ombudsman is one of those figures who, like our committee, really bring citizens closer to the institutions, making them not distant and gray bureaucratic realities, but communities of people who work for well-being and for the protection of every European citizen. The Ombudsman reminds us to respect the rules, it is one of the tools that allow the Union institutions to improve the quality of their services. One of the key elements of democracy is precisely the principle of good administration enshrined in the Charter of Rights of the European Union. In 2016 - I like to recall these data reported by our committee - over 15 700 citizens were assisted by the European Ombudsman, 12 000 people obtained advice through the interactive guide on the website, over 1 200 cases from the Ombudsman's offices that they proceeded to forward information and reports that were treated as complaints. Significant numbers such as the topics covered in the strategic initiatives that the Ombudsman has published. Let's take a few examples: the need for greater transparency in controversial negotiations, such as the TTIP, the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the transparency of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. So, I congratulate you on this report which acknowledges all this to the Ombudsman and which recognizes his role and high value, a role that we must safeguard.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mr President, dear Ms. O'Reilly! “I would like to support the EU institutions in becoming more effective, more transparent and more accountable by strategically strengthening the profile of the European Ombudsman.” This is how you formulated your goal in June 2014 yourself. You did your job very well. Europe needs speakers like you to amplify the voice of its citizens. They take action in the event of unfair treatment by EU authorities, problems with EU tenders and late payments, denied access to EU documents and no replies, as well as appropriate or unpublished lobbying activities. I myself have called for the legislative footprint for all MEPs here in the House, and I would therefore like to thank you for your guidelines on dealing with lobbyists. It should also be on the desk of each of us. Last but not least: With your seat here in this house, you are also giving the European capital of citizens Strasbourg a face - a face that I would like to see in the European Parliament from a single seat in Strasbourg.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, tugann oifig an Ombudsman Eorpaigh guth do ghnáthdhaoine agus molaim go hard í. Ach má táimid dáiríre mar gheall ar Eoraip Shóisialta a chur i gcrích, ba chóir dúinn an tOmbudsman Eorpach a fheiceáil mar dhroichead i dtreo na físe sin. Léiríonn na riachtanais ró-iomarcacha riaracháin a theastaíonn ó na gníomhaireachtaí Eorpacha an easpa cumarsáide, ceangail agus tuisceana atá ann idir maorlathas na hEorpa agus na Ballstáit, agus gnáthmhuintir na hEorpa. Tá pobail agus comhlachtaí in Éirinn fós ag fulaingt de bharr easpa airgid agus de dheasca an riaracháin iomarcaigh seo - Leader mar shampla. In 2011, thug saoránach Éireannach a cás chuig an Ombudsman maidir le rochtain ar channabas míochaine dá hiníon. Agus cé go bhfuil sé lasmuigh d’imscrúdú an Ombudsmain, is ceist an-mhór rochtain ar chúram sláinte do shaoránaigh na hEorpa, go háirithe nuair atá cearta difriúla ag saoránaigh, ag brath ar an mBallstát ina bhfuil siad. Tá cailín óg Éireannach, Ava Twomey, scartha óna clann faoi láthair agus ina cónaí san Ísiltír, áit ina bhfuil rochtain ar an gcannabas míochaine seo atá ag teastáil uaithi. Tá éagóir ollmhór á déanamh ar an gcailín seo agus ar a clann. Agus arís is gnáthshaoránaigh phobail agus comhlachtaí atá ag fulaingt.  Úsáidimis an tOmbudsman chun cabhrú réiteach na bhfadhbanna seo a aimsiú.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! Thank you to the Ombudsman for an excellent job. It is really good to hear the great support that we have for what I believe is the key for the European Union to fight the so-called democratic deficit, namely openness in the Council. As it is now, the Council can operate in complete secrecy, and national parliaments have no idea what their governments are doing. Nor can the national press keep up. Therefore, it continues to be perceived as a distant and inaccessible institution, and it affects us all. Therefore, it was very promising to hear from both you, Emily O’Reilly, and from Frans Timmermans that this should now be at the center, and I hope we can keep the Germans a little at a distance. They are quite afraid of openness, I have noticed. It is absolutely crucial! Imagine that we had openness about Paradise Papers so you could hear which countries are actually holding the hand over tax evasion. Then we could have created credibility about this here. That would be a huge win for all of us. I think we need to be very specific so that you can see what the gain will be in the national debates as well. If the closure of the Council very quickly becomes a thing of the past - and I am very optimistic after hearing you today - then it will provide an all-time chance for real democratic participation in the codecision process. Finally, let me just mention two things very briefly: we need to have the statute changed so that the ombudsman has access to investigate the fulfillment of 1049 himself, and then we need to have the whole concept of good governance right into the law and not just as soft wording. We must have openness provided by law, also with regard to conflicts of interest.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Mr. President, Madam Mediator, before addressing you on a serious matter, I too would like to congratulate you on the excellence of your work and thank you for it. During the last session, here, we voted for an extremely important resolution on the means that the European Parliament will take to better combat sexual harassment. I imagine that you have witnessed, like us, in shock, this scandal which is shaking the whole of society concerning the facts of harassment and sexual assault. Unfortunately, I say it and I will repeat, I am not saying that this Parliament is full of harassers and full of harassed, but nevertheless this phenomenon exists and, despite the vote of this quality resolution, I already feel the brakes and the resistance internally, including from the administration. We need precisely, here, this excellence and this objectivity which is yours. Therefore, could you help us to do this work of study, investigation, analysis and foresight, not to judge the European Parliament, but above all to help us improve, to help us be better? ? We already have, it is true, the merit of having an anti-harassment committee, but I find it inappropriate for sexual harassment. Therefore, we need your gaze and - I appeal to you - I would like you to help us do this work as well. In the next few days, I will take the liberty of sending you an email to give you some elements of analysis and I will obviously be at your disposal if you deem it useful. But, please, also share with us this excellence and this remarkable work that you are doing to make us even better tomorrow.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, let me add my thanks to the Ombudsman and her officials for their work in this past year. I want to raise the ‘B’ word at this point in the debate, and I hope colleagues will forgive me, because that process – whatever views we take on it, and I deeply regret the course that history appears to be taking – must carry public confidence and legitimacy. Fundamental to securing that public confidence and legitimacy will be transparency and the ability of citizens in the UK and other Member States to have access to the right information to shape their views as this process unfolds. That will, of course, happen through democratic institutions like this Parliament and, indeed, in the House of Commons in the UK. Democratic legitimacy in the Brexit process did not end on 23 June last year. In many ways, that has to be the start of democratic legitimacy and scrutiny of what is happening. So, without further delay, the UK Government should publish the sector impact statements on Brexit. I also ask the Ombudsman in this coming year to give particular focus to ensuring that the highest levels of transparency are secured throughout the Brexit process in order to give citizens in all our Member States the right to make their own judgments about what is happening. I specifically ask the Ombudsman to consider releasing specific resources in her good offices to support that and to make sure that the highest levels – I stress the highest levels – of transparency and democratic legitimacy are heard and realised all the way through what will be a difficult and challenging process for all of us.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I would like to focus on a very important aspect of the European Ombudsman’s work, which many of my colleagues have already mentioned, namely the so—called revolving door phenomenon. This refers to a situation in which an industry sends its people to a government position in order to gain political support for their private firms and, in the other direction, in which industry hires people from an EU institution in order to gain access to officials and federal legislation, as well as to get inside information on what is going on in EU institutions. The Transparency International report ‘Access All Areas’ finds that 15 out of 27 Commissioners who completed their mandates in 2014 entered employment with organisations on the EU lobby register at the end of their 18—month cooling—off period. The bright example is, of course, José Manuel Barroso, who was President of the Commission until 2014 and who became Chairman of Goldman Sachs International for the bank’s UK and European operations. I think the Ombudsman should pay more attention to the revolving door phenomenon in the European Union. The Ombudsman should insist on the creation of an independent ethics body which would decide which professional activities are subject to a conflict of interests and continue her work to ensure publication of the names of all EU officials involved in revolving door cases.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Mrs. Spokesperson! Mr President Timmermans! Let me first congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Marlene Mizzi, on her report, although I must admit that she did not have such a complicated work, because the matter was defending itself. How it works and what the spokesman was able to submit is the subject of a good report. I would like to admit here that I am perhaps one of the few in this House who records many years of cooperation with the spokesman. We met with the College of Quaestors of the European Parliament before, and then we even settled the cases that Mr Martin was just talking about here, such as the issue of harassment (a special committee was set up to deal with complaints of harassment in the European Parliament). On the other hand, the spokesman always presented this approach first: we are to serve citizens, that is, respond to people's needs, so that what people need is here. Let us remember that the concept of transparency or transparency is evolving. We understood it differently five years ago, a little different now, so here I appreciate that the spokesperson has always been oriented to the immediate needs. The three areas you mentioned, namely the shortcomings of cooperation, namely the European Council, the troika and fake news. These are the areas on which - I think - we should focus our cooperation and here we will be grateful for contact in order to implement an effective undertaking together.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the European institutions are complex, intertwined organisations that can – to many citizens – seem impenetrable and faceless. As a result, we are often misunderstood by those we aim to serve. Now with the chaotic Brexit negotiations, the rights of so many UK and EU citizens are in the balance. The continued drive of the European Ombudsman towards better transparency, communication and working practice in response to citizens’ concerns about the institutions and bodies of the European Union is particularly crucial during difficult times such as these.  Our European organisations must be continually shaped by the feedback of our citizens, and there must be more opportunities for young people and children to participate meaningfully in our institutional workings and to offer up opinions about the decisions that will affect them. In that respect, I would like to recommend the work of the children’s ombudsman in Poland, whom I recently met and who is certainly following best practice in his department and across the country.  I am particularly pleased that you, the Ombudsman here in Europe, have been making inquiries into complaints by persons with disabilities. It is gratifying to hear the work that they have been carrying out as an independent mechanism to protect and implement the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities so that everybody may access, engage and question the institutions in order to make our practices align better with our principles.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President Timmermans, I would like first of all to thank Mr Mizzi for the excellent report which addresses the key points of the work carried out by the European Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly, whom I also thank for the presentation of the report annual 2016. The report emphasizes the various aspects of the public administration's activity, underlining how the work of public institutions must always be based on high standards of correctness and transparency in decision-making processes and this in the interest of citizens. The Ombudsman's cooperation with Parliament has been and is of fundamental importance to also increase the transparency of our own work. The progress made, through the recommendations of the Ombudsman, by the European institutions is of particular importance also because it constitutes an important signal in terms of prevention and with regard to situations of maladministration. It is therefore necessary to continue along the line drawn by the Ombudsman, whose work is essential not only to do justice to citizens who complain of maladministration, but also and above all to restore just trust in the European institutions to all citizens.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Mr President, the report calls for transparency. Its lack characterizes many institutions of the European Union. Even the European Parliament is in the fourth place of the institutions under investigation and, yes, in some cases the lack of transparency is intentional. Even we MEPs and our collaborators fall victim to bureaucracy. We sometimes ask the services in the European Parliament: are what you are asking us for legal? Which regulation says so? Can we read it too? Do you interpret it correctly? And the answer is: we say it and that is enough. And so the bureaucracy of the European Parliament's service gains more power than that of the European Union's only elected body.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, Mrs O'Reilly, from the position of European Ombudsman, adheres to the principles of proportionality and proportionality fully and exclusively in the exercise of the powers conferred on her. However, the implementation of several recommendations is pending, the adoption of the Code of Good Administrative Behavior is incomplete, the Transparency Register is not practically binding, the European Central Bank President's public interest meetings are not made public and features of opacity are found in the negotiation and decision-making process. Union as a whole. Obviously, opacity, lack of ethics and inadequate management of conflicts of interest are inherent and systemic in the Union institutions. Unfortunately, her determination, vigilance and experience are not the only guarantees for a full investigation of cases and the protection of European citizens from cases of maladministration.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me repeat what I said earlier, I have to say the Spanish translation of ombudsman is the one that appeals most to me ‘defensor del pueblo’, which is a very nice expression of this function.  I want to conclude by expressing once again my gratitude to Ms O’Reilly for her constructive approach and the consistently good cooperation between the Commission, the Ombudsman and her office. The Commission has also greatly appreciated the launch in 2016 by the Ombudsman of an award for good administration. This ‘name-and-congratulate’ exercise is very rewarding for all those EU officials who are doing their utmost to serve citizens and the general EU interest.  I reiterate my call for delivering real change on lobbying transparency in all three institutions. Citizens have the right to know who is trying to influence the legislative process. So we need a mandatory transparency register, not just a voluntary one. We should not miss the opportunity to deliver this before the next European elections. Let me be very clear about some apparent misunderstandings. The onus will not be on MEPs. The onus will be on the lobbyists to register, not on the MEPs they see. This will in no way limit the possibilities of MEPs to see their voters. We are talking about people who represent specific interests in lobbying when we are making legislation. This could perhaps take away some of the worries that I have registered, because transparency and trust are essential in public institutions, certainly at the European level where the distance with our citizens is too big. But also, more generally, society needs more transparency and trust in public institutions. Strengthening the protection of whistle-blowers is an essential aspect of this.  Following the public consultation, the Commission continues to assess the scope for further EU action and we will finalise this work in the first part of 2018. Once again, a big thank-you to Ms O’Reilly.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Ombudsman. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for all of their comments and observations, but most of all for their support for the work that I do. We are a very small office with just 80 people, but we have a big mandate and I rely on Parliament, as a big institution, to support me. It is wonderfully gratifying to get the support from right across the Chamber and I deeply appreciate it. I thank Ms Mizzi again for the report that she has done, which has also received such support among colleagues. A number of very interesting issues have been raised which we will follow up in the days and weeks ahead. Just briefly, as we have gone round Parliament today and over this week, a lot of us have seen some of the big billboards in relation to harassment, reminding people about appropriate workplace behaviour and this is something that I have been discussing with my colleagues. We have obviously taken complaints in the past and can continue to take complaints in relation to this, but we have had very few over the years. I think it needs a deeper conversation in relation to that and I am very happy to be part of that. On Brexit, in relation to transparency, we started working on this particular issue as soon as the referendum was over. Obviously it is not for me or any of us to tell Member States what to do in relation to the release of important documents vis—à-vis citizens, and perhaps particularly those in the UK, but what I have done is to have discussions with the Member State Ombudsmen and Information Commissioners, including the UK Information Commissioner, to remind them that if they cannot get records from their own Member State, there is always the possibility of seeking to get them from an EU institution that may also hold them. There has obviously been a lot of talk about revolving doors. We have been very busy with that over the last number of years. In relation to the Commission and the Code of Conduct, we have conducted an investigation into that and we are expecting a response from the Commission in relation to that, though I do acknowledge the proposals that have already been made by the Commission in relation to that.  A number of people mentioned limits to transparency. Yes, of course, when I talk about transparency, I am not talking about transparency at any cost. We are always talking about the appropriate release of documents in the public interest and that has to be the guiding value.  Somebody said that my office, the office of the European Ombudsman, is a mirror for the functioning of the EU and I think that is a wonderful way of describing it. In fact it describes Parliament as well because what we all do is show back to the institutions the actual impact of the laws and the regulations that are passed here.  So thank you very much indeed for your support and your comments, which I will follow up on and thank you, again, Ms Mizzi.  (Applause)

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for their contributions to this debate, and in particular the shadows and to the European Commission as well as my assistant Desislava Dimitrova and the secretariat of the Committee on Petitions (PETI). It is safe to say that we have a very positive attitude for this year’s Report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman and that we all appreciate the important work done by Ms O’Reilly and her team. The PETI Committee supports you and your work, Ms O’Reilly, and I am sure that the European Parliament and the Ombudsman will continue to work very closely towards the successful implementation of the Ombudsman’s recommendations emanating from this year’s annual report. We are on the right path, and that should be the conclusion of this journey. But let’s not fool ourselves. The EU has still to strive to achieve the highest level of accountability and transparency. Maintaining citizens’ trust in the EU institutions, especially at a time of a great scepticism regarding the Union project, must be our ultimate goal. We can start building this trust by guaranteeing citizens the right to the highest standards of public administration. We all have an obligation to represent European citizens in everything we do. We need to commit to improving the way in which the EU administration works, placing citizens at its heart, making sure that we work more transparently, that we are more accountable and that we react immediately when the highest standards are not met. Regulation (EC) No 1049/200 needs to be revised so that we can facilitate the Ombudsman’s work in scrutinising the granting of access to documents by Parliament, the Council and the Commission. We also need to ensure that the European administration follows up on, and implements, the recommendations of the European Ombudsman within a reasonable time frame. I say to Ms O’Reilly that I look forward to working closely with you, and I am sure that you will maintain your strong dedication to improving the quality of the European administration in answering enquiries and complaints from European citizens. It is in all our interests to make sure that your work is a success story.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The conversation is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Petitions (PETI), which embraces the subject, I welcome the report on the European Ombudsman's activities last year. I consider it important that the summary of the Ombudsman's work was drafted in easily accessible, comprehensible language and that the Ombudsman's office published it in all official EU languages. It can be said that the Ombudsman closed a successful year last year, and we can be EU citizens, but we MEPs can be a part of it. Efficiency is reflected in the high level of implementation of decisions and recommendations issued following ombudsman inquiries. In the PETI Committee, we monitor the Ombudsman's work and exchange views on common issues, thus contributing to resolving current institutional operational issues. The parliamentary report reiterates that, despite the progress made, there is room for improvement in the areas of the Ombudsman's remit. Here, I would like to highlight the need to further develop cooperation between the European Commission and the Committee on Petitions, including information on EU Pilot and infringement proceedings arising from petitions. It is particularly important to me to review the European Citizens' Initiative, and I agree with the Parliament's rapporteur that this is a key procedure whose effectiveness and full implementation of this EU citizenship right can only be ensured if the Commission takes into account the suggestions of stakeholders, including Parliament.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: written. - I join the commitment that the Ombudsman has shown since the beginning of the legislature in her defense of the rights of people with disabilities. In this sense, it is worth highlighting the reinforcement of this commitment during 2016 with the launch of a strategic initiative for the application of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I encourage you to continue to work actively on both the implementation of the Convention and the European Disability Strategy. I congratulate the defender for the launch of the initiative within the framework of the Convention, on the accessibility of websites and online tools managed by the Commission to improve access for people with disabilities to the public administration of the EU. It is important that the defender does not cease in her efforts to continue investigating complaints made by people with disabilities. The European Ombudsman must protect the rights of people with disabilities and ensure that the Union administration is aware of its responsibilities with regard to these rights.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - In 2016, the office of the European Ombudsman helped more than 15 797 citizens, of which 12,646 cases were resolved by providing advice through the interactive guide on the Ombudsman's website, and the remaining 1,880 requests as complaints and 1,271 as requests for information, replied by the services of the European Ombudsman. 245 investigations were opened, 235 on the basis of complaints and 10 on own initiative, 291 investigations closed (278 on the basis of complaints and 13 on own initiative). I am pleased with the significant drop in the number of inquiries into the European institutions by the European Ombudsman in 2016 (245 in 2016, compared to 261 in 2015). Wishing more success, Ms Emily O'Reilly, the Ombudsman, I hope that the European Ombudsman will continue to improve its efforts to ensure that EU citizens fully enjoy their rights and that EU institutions and agencies will continue to work to improve the rapid respond to critical remarks by the Ombudsman and improve their indicators of compliance with his recommendations.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - The next item is the debate on the 2017 oral question to the Council by Sirpa Pietikäinen, Simona Bonafè, Mark Demesmaeker, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Luke Ming Flanagan and Benedek Jávor, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on evaluation of the implementation of environmental legislation (O-0000)-0606/2017 and - the oral question to the Commission by Sirpa Pietikäinen, Simona Bonafèn, Mark Demesmaeker, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Luke Ming Flanagan and Benedek Jávor, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the evaluation of the implementation of environmental legislation (O-000066/2017)-0607/2017.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: author. – Madam President, in February this year the Commission published its first edition of the Environmental Implementation Review (EIR) to give an overview of the implementation of EU environmental law in each Member State. The 28 country reports are accompanied by a summary document listing the common challenges, such as waste management, nature and biodiversity protection, air quality, noise pollution, water quality and management, to identify the root causes of problems, and providing policy proposals and recommendations for improvement.  I would like to stress that the EIR is a soft tool to shed light on implementation gaps, challenges and problems. In this sense it is a key to providing an early warning for the national and sub-national level policymakers which can take corrective actions and address the gaps in time. The EIR also aims to demonstrate success stories that can serve as an example for other Member States. The recently launched peer-to-peer tool facilitates this kind of exchange of knowledge or best practices. The exercise is to be repeated every two years, offering the possibility for iterative changes and improvements.  We, Members of the European Parliament, welcome the EIR and believe that this new review mechanism as a whole has the potential to improve compliance and policy implementation and thus also contribute to greater transparency and the credibility of the EU.  Yet, in order to fully realise this potential, we believe that the process could be further improved, including by broadening the scope of the review, as also expressed in the motion for a resolution adopted in October in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. There is also a need for targeted assistance to the Member States to overcome the barriers of proper, effective implementation, such as ineffective governance, inappropriate institutional framework, lack of capacity and an unclear responsibility of the authorities. My co-sponsors of the motion for a resolution and oral question – Ms Pietikäinen, Ms Bonafè, Mr Demesmaeker, Mr Gerbrandy, Mr Flanagan –and I tabled on behalf of the Environment Committee the following questions, first to the Council, regarding the EIR. Parliament wishes to highlight the need to address the root causes, in particular lack of policy coherence and insufficient financing. The same goes for covering additional issues in the coming review cycles such as climate change, chemicals regulations, industrial emissions and other systemic challenges linked, for example, to energy, transport and regional policies.  In order to demonstrate clear, strong political commitment, the Council could hold regular meetings dedicated to the implementation of EU environmental law which could facilitate monitoring the performance and progress of a Member State and ensure structured implementation dialogues as proposed by the Commission. For the latter, Member States should pay due attention to ensuring transparency and broad stakeholder participation.  In addition, we would see added value in joint Council meetings to address the implementation of cross-cutting issues and also the environmental challenges of a cross-border nature. We would also like to ask the Commission this oral question and we raise some concerns about the exact means of following up on the policy proposals and recommendations for better implementation put forward by the Commission.  There are issues to be solved linked to data availability and comparability, especially in the context of the next review cycles that would hopefully run with a wider scope. We would like to hear the Commission’s views on how the EIR framework could be used as a means of assessing the implementation of the relevant Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the 2030 Agenda and, in general, of shifting from the current sectoral approaches to a coherent, consistent and holistic solution.  We put on the table tools, including a publicly available scoreboard to monitor the performance and progress of each Member State and to improve transparency and raise public awareness and ensure proper public participation in each Member State.  Last but not least, we would like to better understand the linkage between the EIR process and the infringements and, in general, the exact actions taken by the Commission in the event of non-compliance.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Parliament for the interest it is taking, through this question and its resolution, in the new environmental implementation review initiative. I can confirm that this interest is fully shared by the Council. In terms of addressing implementation gaps in EU environmental legislation and policy, this initiative has a high potential. In addition to contributing to the environment ministers’ input into the European Semester, the environmental implementation review process is meant to become a distinct and consistent process. It would involve several important elements: the preparation of environmental implementation review country reports and bilateral discussions with the Member States, as well as the identification of common issues and their discussion in the Environmental Council. On 28 February 2017, the Environment Council held its latest exchange of views on greening the European Semester. The economic system depends largely on the availability and sustainable use of limited natural resources. Keeping this in mind, greening the economy and advancing the transition towards a resource efficient circular economy becomes essential to secure future competitiveness and long-term sustainable and inclusive growth. In this context, Ministers also discussed the Commission’s communication on the EU environmental implementation review. They welcomed this initiative as a useful tool to help improve implementation of EU environmental policy and legislation at national level and contribute to the greening of the European Semester. In doing this, they underlined the need for national findings to be based on sound scientific data. Ministers also welcomed the opportunity for Member States to engage in dialogue and cooperation with the Commission and among themselves, peer to peer, with the aim of reflecting on their respective priorities, addressing common challenges and sharing best practices. As regards the specific questions that you have raised at this early stage of the environmental implementation review process, I would like to limit myself to the following comments. We agree with the identified root causes of the implementation gaps and we are willing to address them further. It is to be expected that the different strands of the implementation process of the environmental implementation review, and in particular the dialogue with the Member States on the basis of the country reports, will allow us to carry out a structured dialogue in Council. Member States are generally responding positively to the environmental implementation review process. Bilateral dialogues have already taken place in five countries since March this year. These countries are Belgium, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Luxembourg and Slovakia. I also encourage other countries to organise action-oriented country dialogues and to hold forward—looking debates on environmental challenges. I trust that these dialogues will be inclusive and that the relevant stakeholders get an opportunity to contribute as appropriate. The current environmental implementation review cycle is already very ambitious and covers a large number of complex and very significant areas. In terms of broadening the scope of the environmental implementation review to other policy areas in the future, we find it essential that environmental challenges are tackled in a comprehensive manner and that all relevant policies are taken into account. The real added value of the environmental implementation review will come from in—depth impartial analysis. However, if broadening the scope is considered, due attention should be given to avoiding a disproportionate administrative burden. As regards the involvement of the Council – although I cannot speak on behalf of future presidencies – currently, the idea is to bring the structural problems and common challenges identified in the course of the two-year period to the attention of the Council. The Council would then discuss environmental implementation review-related issues at regular intervals in line with the cycle, also ensuring complementarity with the discussion on the greening of the European Semester and the relevant post—2020 strategies. Lastly, in many areas environmental policy is interlinked with other domains. In addressing the cross-cutting issues, we should avoid working in silos and ensure that all relevant parties are involved in discussions. The respective dialogues should not be held at Council level only, but start from expert groups and other working formations. Hence the effort of engaging colleagues from other policy areas is welcome at all levels in order to achieve a coordinated and informed outcome. I thank Parliament once again for these questions.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to say how glad I am to take this point on behalf of Commissioner Vella. Commissioner Vella wishes to thank the author and all of the people involved in the interest in the environmental implementation review (EIR) and for your support for this important initiative.  The EIR puts implementation in a broader context with a view to finding practical solutions by looking at integration with other sectors and by identifying possible root causes for implementation challenges. This helps to improve the knowledge and sharing of good practice.  The main goal of the EIR was to draw attention to the need for improved implementation in order to attain the European Union’s environmental objectives. The environmental targets and deadlines which need to be achieved by the Member States are included in the legal obligations set out in the environmental aquis and are being monitored per directive and regulation.  The EIR encourages cooperation, dialogue and the search for solutions involving a wide range of stakeholders at national level. It is not feasible, but neither is it the Commission’s intention, to rely on a name-and-shame exercise. This could, at any rate, jeopardise the achievement of goals. The Commission has included in the country reports both good practices and good examples, as well as implementation challenges. The data used in the country reports are comparable.  The Commission’s ongoing initiative in streamlining reporting requirements in EU environmental law is expected to improve the quality and completeness of the data significantly.  The EIR takes a holistic approach, reflecting the spirit of the Sustainable Development Goals. and the Commission is taking steps to ensure that the second review cycle will be even more comprehensive by including chemicals, industrial emissions and the implementation of climate change policies. The nexus with climate change and other policies will also be developed as much as possible.  The Commission encourages Member States to organise national dialogues under the EIR in a cross-sectoral approach. The first five countries’ dialogues succeeded in doing so, and further dialogues are being planned. The Commission has also asked Member States to involve all relevant stakeholders during their country dialogues. We firmly believe that discussions will result in tailored solutions and mount some pressure to fill in the implementation gaps that are identified in the EIR reports.  The EIR inspires learning from good practice. On 7 September 2017, the Commission launched a peer-to-peer tool with the Committee of the Regions. It is intended to support concretely the Member States at all administrative levels to share experience and expertise. This will lead to a database of good practices.  The EIR has not changed the Commission’s policy as regards infringements, and there is no formal relationship between the voluntary approach and the legal procedures. In most cases, the infringement procedures will run in parallel where necessary. However, if the EIR succeeds over time in improving implementation, as is expected, fewer infringement procedures will be needed and, therefore, fewer resources will have to be spent on legal proceedings, and we should have enhanced environmental protection due to upstream and systematic solutions.  I wish to conclude by thanking the author and all of the people that have been involved in drawing up this report.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Commissioner Hogan, the European Union has strong environmental legislation based on the precautionary principle. Our entrepreneurs, farmers, wildlife managers, governments and citizens are held to the strictest requirements. This evaluation shows that implementation by EU Member States, provinces, regions and local authorities varies widely. Unfortunately, one Member State is cheating on environmental legislation and another Member State is unnecessarily strict in certain cases, while the same Member State ignores other environmental legislation. I regret that the water quality and drug residues in the water receive too little attention in this report. I also miss the commitment of land owners and provinces for the improved implementation of Natura 2000. Farmers have to pay off because of nitrogen precipitation in nature reserves, centuries-old family businesses have to be relocated in Twente. But how do we deal with other sectors? How differently do Member States such as the Netherlands deal with the interests of big money, with oil and gas extraction? I want to talk about that. In the Twente region in Overijssel, polluted waste water from oil extraction is discharged under drinking water and Natura 2000 areas. Surely this is the world upside down. Your response to my written questions was clear last year. Pursuant to Article 12 of the Waste Directive, Member States must ensure that such discharges (waste disposal operations) do not endanger human health and are without risk to soil and water. The Nederlandse Aardolie Maatschappij and the national government have, however, for years refused to have wastewater treated prior to discharges into the subsoil of vulnerable water extraction and nature areas. This while good purification techniques exist for this. It is therefore high time that the European Commission intervened proactively in the Netherlands, with all legal means at its disposal, in the interest of our residents, our environment and certainly also the farmers who are working well there.Thank you.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if there is one sector in which the European Union is at the forefront of the world, it is environmental protection, and therefore the regulations we have set for air quality, waters, optimal waste management, and I could go on. However, we must not only boast of having ambitious regulations, we must also be able to enforce these regulations, which unfortunately does not always happen. This is fundamental not only for the credibility of the Union, but also for the protection of the environment and for the health of our citizens and also for the economic consequences. We see it very well, for example, with the impact assessment on the circular economy which benefits in terms of employment and economic growth can bring an effective and efficient management of waste. Well then, the Commission has done to prepare a tool to assess the performance of Member States in the implementation of environmental legislation. Having a mapping allows us to understand how much reality separates us from the objectives set by law, the sectors in which we are still behind, why we are still behind, and therefore identify the causes, and which tools to concretely put in place to achieve the objectives. You understand that, first of all, it is necessary that the data are more comparable to facilitate the exchange of best practices, as we ask in the resolution. We also need to have as precise a picture as possible, including other elements in the evaluation. We think in the resolution of energy efficiency, of the transport sector, of climate change. I am pleased to hear that there is already an opening, as the Commissioner said, not least because it is unthinkable today not to consider the impact of climate change. And now I turn to the Council. All this cannot be just an exercise in style, but the Member States they must then make a concrete commitment to achieving the objectives, and we ask the Council for a concrete commitment to therefore fully adhere to the review and to take this instrument very seriously.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Commissioner, our strong European environmental legislation often contrasts sharply with its weak implementation. I have experienced this in practice in my work in the field of biodiversity policy, waste legislation and emission standards. We must therefore focus more on better implementation, otherwise our strict standards will only turn out to be paper tigers in reality. The new EIR instrument launched by the Commission can play an important role in this and deserves all support. Of course, everything can always be improved. We make a number of recommendations for this from the environmental committee. First, the EIR should not be a purely technical instrument. It must also feed the political discussion. For example, a permanent item on the Council's agenda on the implementation of environmental legislation would be a step forward. Second, it is essential that regional and local authorities are fully involved. As a Flemish Member of the European Parliament I cannot emphasize that enough. Finally, I once again stand up for the exchange of best practices. We should not always reinvent hot water, but make full use of existing expertise and innovative solutions.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, one of the biggest problems we have with implementing directives when it comes to the environment is the fact that governments do not actually take ownership of these directives, even though they themselves transpose them into law. On many occasions, the statement is made at home that ‘the EU made us do it’, a similar sort of excuse that Bart Simpson comes up with when he has obviously done something wrong: ‘someone else made them do it’. What chance is there of real committed implementation if the state itself is not really committed? The result in implementation tends to be shabby and imposed on people, rather than carried out through consultation and dialogue. A perfect example of this is the Birds and Habitats Directive. As Commissioner Hogan knows himself, I would not be here if it were not for the mess that was made of that. The directive itself is excellent. However, how it was implemented when it came to turf cutters and farmers has left a bitter taste which will not be removed for a long time. No real consultation took place, and also implementation costs ordinary people money, whether that be septic-tank inspections or training in pesticide spraying. These costs should be borne by the state and not by the individual, because it’s really important that we do this. If it’s that important then let those who can afford it pay for it.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the Environmental Implementation Review (EIR) is an EU instrument designed to monitor the implementation of EU environmental law and policy. The EIR affords the Commission a more proactive role, enabling it to monitor the implementation of EU environmental law in Member States. This scheme would diminish the discretionary margin of Member States when implementing the directives and would transfer additional powers to EU institutions. In my opinion, it would be far better to provide a mechanism which would engage with EU citizens directly and which would promote awareness, increase involvement and educate the general public about the environment. I do not think that a new EU legislative instrument monitoring the application of unilaterally imposed legislation is the answer to the improvement of environmental policies in the EU. I believe that Member States should have the freedom to set their own targets rather than being forced to comply with those set by the unelected Commission.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: - I begin by thanking my colleagues for raising these important questions in the discussion with the Council and the Commission. I would like to highlight two issues in this discussion. The first is related to funding. As rapporteur for the Union's Seventh General Environment Action Program, I know of several cases in which funds spent on environmental objectives have not yielded the desired results. Some Member States lack money, but at the level of the European Union it is not the lack of funds that is the problem, but their mismanagement. Useful investments have been made for some projects, such as improving drinking water quality, but in many other cases the money has simply been wasted. This is very clear from the Court of Auditors' reports. The Commission must act to ensure a more responsible use of the funds it distributes for environmental projects. The second aspect is related to civil society. Many NGOs I consulted with for the report told me that the assessment of the implementation of environmental policies is limited because it involves only the Member States and the Commission.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we will support this Parliament resolution because we believe that the implementation review is an essential tool for reaping the maximum benefit from environmental policies in the European Union, but also for defining and charting that path, those steps that they serve to achieve a sustainable future in Europe. However, we believe that all of this can only happen if we really tackle the paradox that sees, on the one hand, very solid European legislation on the environment but, on the other, its completely ineffective implementation. So for us you have to do three things. First of all: introduce sanctions that are truly effective for those Member States which, however, fail to enforce, to impose the "polluter pays" principle. Second thing: the infringement procedure mechanism does not work. It cannot be citizens who pay twice: once in terms of health because the environment in which they live is not protected and the second time in economic terms because they receive an infringement procedure. Those responsible have to pay, which are very often the ministries of the environment of the individual Member States, who instead remain there in their seats despite being responsible. Third thing: it is necessary to interrupt that infernal triangle that sees the polluting industry that also finances the representatives in the European institutions and in the local and regional institutions who then appoint the directors of the control institutes. If these three things are not done, Europe will never have a sustainable future.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I will follow up on my colleagues, we all in the Chamber probably feel that European environmental law, the acquis, is an extremely important part of European law and it is not important to just adopt, but then check how much the law is implemented in national legal regimes. and for how much is it actually implemented. And it is good that colleagues here have raised this issue here today, because I know from my own experience that we often pass legislation that is not always well implemented at that national level and is not always well used. And in the field of the environment, I consider this topic to be particularly important. I welcome here the information from the Commission that evaluation reports on the state of the environmental acquis will be and are being prepared. I want to emphasize and recommend that, in addition to criticizing the shortcomings of individual Member States, positive examples be highlighted, that there should be more dialogue with individual Member States than just criticizing if there are any shortcomings, because then we will have natural resistance to the environmental acquis and probably no one wants that. I am also pleased that the representatives of the Commission have spoken here about the issue of the implementation of these regulations in the future being more debated in the Environment Council. I think this is right, because it is much better for individual states to exchange experiences with each other about their specific knowledge with the implementation of this legislation, and for somehow to share their own experiences. This is perhaps even more appropriate than when the Commission is in the role of reprimanding individual Member States. I don't think that's that effective. So this is important and I am glad that we are discussing this point here.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: - Madam President, the review of the implementation of environmental policy includes 28 reports analyzing the performance of Member States in the implementation of this legislation. However, specificities and profound differences exist between each country in legal, environmental or public action. It is therefore illusory to want to improve the comparability of data between countries which are not comparable. The oral question to the Council calls on States to support the extension of the scope of the review of the implementation of environmental policy to the regulation on chemicals, industrial emissions and climate change, while pointing to a lack of funding. Yet, according to the Commission website, 180 billion euros are already spent on climate action, or 20% of the Union’s 2014-2020 budget. I therefore object to the environmental policy implementation review becoming a sinkhole for the net contributing countries, which will likely have to fund those extra billions.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that EU environmental legislation has yielded results. We have better environments than if Europe had not acted collectively. There are issues on implementation by Member States, and that is why this review is very important, but there are also conflicts in our policy. I was struck last week, watching a television programme called Ear to the Ground, by a major report on Japanese knotweed, an invasive alien species that we have tried to get rid of because it is causing havoc to buildings and roads and is spreading like wildfire. The product being used was glyphosate – Roundup – to kill this invasive alien species. Yet, in this House, there are many who would clamour for the removal of this product, and indeed the Member States are refusing, or failing, to come forward with a proposal to re-license it.
