Sometimes, on environmental policies, we need coherence at political level and at Commission level, so that we can continue to use these products to improve the environment.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, and I would also like to congratulate my colleagues who have asked questions about the assessment of the implementation of EIR environmental policies. The questions are concrete and I think that if you read them very well you will see that you also have answers. There are already proposals in these questions and I give two examples. In one of the questions he asks you if you are thinking of having a dashboard. Then in another question it is exemplified if you do not think of making an example of good practice between states. The problem is that states are unequally developed, there are insufficient budgets, both local and national, and if you think about it, that would be my question, if you think about giving support where not out of bad faith environmental policy cannot be applied, but due to lack of financial resources and we may find with the strategic investment fund, with other sources of financing to support the states that cannot, not that they do not want. And finally, I would like to tell you that I agree that there is accessibility from the public to know what is happening in the Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the protection of the environment must be a cornerstone of our policy, because the planet is being destroyed and natural disasters and natural disasters are being caused to many victims, just as happened today in the early hours of the morning in Greece, where at least 15 of my compatriots lost their lives unjustly. from the catastrophic floods that hit Western Attica. So, once again, a degraded area, such as Mandra, is mourning its victims. Unfortunately, once again, the lack of flood defenses was clearly demonstrated. We express our sorrow for the unjust loss of our compatriots, we express our heartfelt condolences to their loved ones, we express our full support and wishes for a speedy recovery of the dozens of injured and we ask, Mr. Hogan, the European Commission to launch the necessary procedures for the financial support of Greece, in order to repair the damage and to fully compensate the flood victims.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, in general, I welcome the review of European Union environmental legislation as a necessary tool. I particularly welcome the call for a joint Council meeting, which should address new issues with possible cross-border implications. This is exactly the issue that should be addressed primarily. However, not only in terms of new problems, but also in terms of existing ones. There are simply regions in the EU where, either due to poor implementation of European legislation or its ignorance, there are very strong local frictions between Member States, especially in terms of emissions. For a long time, the European institutions have been turning a blind eye to this problem, and I will just be happy when we finally start tackling it. However, I do not agree with the statement that shortcomings in administrative capacity and public administration are the main causes of unsatisfactory implementation. We are constantly increasing the administrative burden here. After all, just look at how we are decimating the Member States administratively in the latest climate package. I'd rather not even talk about the winter energy package. Let's think about it.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members of the House for their support and for highlighting the issues that have been raised. I will convey these concerns and suggestions back to Commissioner Vella. The Environmental Implementation Review is an example of how the Commission can work with Member States and other institutions to address the weak implementation of environmental rules and policy. As many of you have said, this is necessary in order to increase the European Union’s credibility. Ms Schreijer-Pierik mentioned issues in relation to water quality in the Netherlands. These are very important issues, and I see that, if water quality in a Member State is an issue where the spirit and content of the legislation in relation to our Water Framework Directive is not being implemented, infringement proceedings can be taken if necessary. I would, of course, agree that farmers should be seen as part of the solution rather than part of the problem. I would say to Mr Flanagan that 31 European Court of Justice judgments against Ireland were on the desk of a certain Minister of the Environment in 2011, and that number was reduced in three years to nine because a dedicated unit was set up and human and financial resources were assigned to it. In other words, it was given political priority. This subsequently saved an enormous amount of money for the country. So implementation is a matter for the Member State, and it is in the interest of the Member State, if it wants to eliminate the possibility of expensive legal proceedings and fines, to take action. It is in the interest of our citizens that full implementation is actually achieved as quickly as possible. But I also agree with Mr Pospíšil that, sometimes, the manner of implementation of environmental law in Member States needs a lot of attention and monitoring, and I think Mr Flanagan was right in that regard as well. There can be gold-plating, in certain cases, and we have evidence and some examples of where that has been the case in some Member States. Ms McGuinness, you have certainly come at the glyphosate debate from a different angle and it is an interesting one. Ms Grapini, again, it is a matter for Member States to decide if they want to implement support packages and financial support with assistance from EU programmes, like the LIFE Programme, for example, which can offer financial assistance, if necessary, with the implementation of certain environmental law that has to be transposed and implemented by the Member States on behalf of the European Union. Thank you again to all the contributors. I think it would also be useful if Members of the European Parliament would engage in promoting the Environmental Implementation Review in their national constituencies, in order to get feedback.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like once again to thank Parliament for the interest shown in this important initiative and for the questions and comments that have been made. We are at the beginning of a long-term process. We are embarking on a new, long road together and I am sure that we will have further opportunities to discuss these issues in this House and in other forums.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I have receivedonepäätöslauselmaesityksen1.The conversation is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 16 November 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - Although new legislative proposals - such as a soil directive - are required to complete the European acquis on environmental protection, there is no doubt that the current framework is a demanding standard in environmental protection. Its implementation, however, differs greatly between the Member States and is particularly lax in my country, Spain. It is not acceptable that the transposition of the Water Framework Directive does not yet contain hydrological plans for the Canary Islands, nor measures that really guarantee the sustainability of the vast majority of peninsular basins. Nor is it acceptable that, despite numerous judgments by the CJEU, the problem of illegal landfills continues, as tragedies such as the one in Chiloeches remind us. Neoliberal policies have undoubtedly aggravated the structural overexploitation of our nature. But even on the margins of community economic policies, the Spanish Administrations, and especially the current PP Government, have shown nothing but indifference to the protection of the environment. It is essential, therefore, greater firmness, and that the Commission act in the face of the numerous complaints for infringement of environmental regulations that accumulate in Spain.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - The next item is the report by Javi López, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on combating inequalities as a driver for jobs and growth (2016/2269 (INI)) (A8-0340 / 2017).

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: speaker. - Madam President, in this session the European Parliament will decide with this report on inequality to place on its agenda - and especially place it as one of its great priorities - the fight against inequality, not only because we are challenged by the socially unbearable injustices that They live and travel the continent, but because we recognize that the best way to promote inclusive growth, lasting growth and strong growth in the European Union is by fighting inequality. Fighting inequality is also the best way to ensure stability in our institutions and the best way to combat the monsters that we have seen in the last electoral period in the Western world. The European Union, as we know, and its institutions have been very aware of a long list of crises in recent years - since the financial crisis, the sovereign debt crisis, some internal political crises that we have suffered - but now that growth rears its head, stability rears its head and we can see a future of some stability, the time has come to make it a priority to remake our social pact and also respond to the long list of victims and victims in recent years. A job market that we know has been transformed in recent times and is no longer the source of security and prosperity that it had been until not long ago. Serve a list of 115 million European citizens who today live at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Address the unbearable inequalities that have increased in recent years within countries and, above all, between countries, when until now we had been a convergence machine, as the European Treaties well say. And for this we also make and mark a roadmap. Not only do we call for action, we not only acknowledge the economic impact of inequality, but, as institution, we say that we have to rebalance our economic policy and introduce inequality in its tools - the country-specific recommendations or the European Semester. And, at the same time, we have to build a true European social dimension. And it is no coincidence that we approved this report in the plenary of the European Parliament a few days after approving the European social pillar, a list of rights and social objectives that the citizens of the Union will have. But that list, then, must be able to become instruments, policies, European standards and resources. And we have launched some proposals: from the need to have a table of minimum income at the European level to studying the possibility of having a box that accompanies unemployment benefits, going through fighting against child poverty with a child guarantee system as a proposal ; continue to fight also against youth unemployment, as we have done in recent years; attend to the labor market, to the improvement of wages, with an index of living wages; and also pay attention to the new forms of employment that we have seen - some also derived from digitization - that concern us. All of this must be done while we tell the Union that there are underlying economic trends that concern us, that generate growth but do not distribute well, such as digitization and robotization or international trade; that there are groups that experience vulnerability in an intersecting way: the disabled, the gender gap - which concerns us a lot in this report - or the generation gap. For this, it will also be necessary to pay attention to taxes, the other side of the coin. With this, the Union sets the fight against inequality as a priority and, above all, we say that this form, the social dimension, is the best way to once again legitimize the European institutions vis-à-vis the citizens, recovering growth, stability and dignity for this continent.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am presenting this point on behalf of Commissioner Thyssen, who, as you know, is on her way to the Social Summit in Gothenburg for the first time in 20 years.  I welcome the fact that your report focuses on inequalities as this is an important topic that deserves our full attention. Inequalities are not only dividing our societies, they are putting a brake on our competitiveness and economic growth. We therefore need economic growth that benefits all citizens while we still need to overcome the damage done by the economic crisis. In the Annual Growth Survey, the Commission asked the Member States to redouble their efforts on investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies, but with an increased focus on inclusive growth and social fairness.  Your report calls on the Commission and the Member States to address issues that generate inequalities – wage settings, social protection systems which includes minimum income, gender equality, enabling social services, childcare, support to children, old age income, health care and access to housing. This is why we presented the European Pillar of Social Rights as a framework to also reduce inequalities and social risks. Parliament has been actively involved in the process that led to the adoption of the pillar and finally, as I said, to its proclamation this Friday by the three institutions at the Social Summit for Fair Jobs and Growth in Gothenburg.  The Commission acknowledges and thanks Parliament for its crucial role throughout the process, but the pillar should not be only words. Together with the pillar, we have already launched two social partner consultations. One is to collect views on the possible direction of an EU action to ensure that people in all forms of employment have adequate access to social protection and employment services. The second is on a possible revision of the Written Statement Directive, which would increase the protection for the most precarious workers, including digital workers. We have also put forward an initiative to support work-life balance for parents and carers.  We are looking forward to your report and we are hoping to get it through the legislative process as quickly as possible. The European Semester will have a key role in implementing the pillar. Combating inequalities has been and remains a priority of the European Semester. Several past country-specific recommendations have been addressed to Member States on issues that are relevant to inequality. We intend to build on this approach in the coming cycle to ensure that progress on implementing the pillar is properly reflected and monitored. Indeed, a new feature will be the use of the pillar’s social scoreboard to monitor developments in Member States, looking across a wide spectrum of policy areas which will include inequality, poverty and social inclusion.  Finally, I particularly welcome the focus of the report on children. Investing in children is key to breaking the cycle of inequality and disadvantage through generations. As regards the implementation of the current preparatory action on a child guarantee, our aim is to investigate the feasibility of such an initiative and its added value compared to ongoing actions at the moment.  So as we speak, the recovery is ongoing, with improvements in the overall situation in the labour market in all Member States. It is essential now to prevent the risk that, as the recovery continues in Europe, some people are left behind. That is why your report and this debate are very timely.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. - Madam President, this report is of the utmost importance. In fact, fighting inequality is a fundamental mechanism, it is a fundamental means to not only promote employment but also to promote growth. Unfortunately, we see in recent years how inequalities have affected the economic development and economic performance of the various Member States, and this is largely due to what was the design of economic policies that we have also had in recent years. These economic policies have exacerbated inequalities, notably through austerity policies, but also through unfair fiscal policies, and we have a series of cases here to show how tax evasion and tax fraud also cause not only a situation of profound unequal treatment as well as immense inequality. Unemployment is one of the biggest problems we have and, therefore, fighting inequality is also a way of creating jobs and being able to have an economic development and economic performance that is fair and sustainable. Combating inequalities cannot be just on paper, there are a number of proposals that are presented. It is up to the Commission to implement them, it is up to us to supervise and present the legislative proposal.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - Madam President! Combating inequalities is one of the obligations of the Member States under the Treaties. It is also an expression of social justice and social and economic development. As the title of the report we are talking about today says, combating inequality can speed up the creation of new jobs. I can bet there are many people in this House who do not agree with this point. It is not obvious to them, because they perceive equality actions as an additional effort and additional cost, the frills of a developed country, and not a lever of development. That is why I am pleased with the amendments that the FEMM Committee has prepared, which clearly show how greater equality between women and men can contribute to building and developing the labor market. Today, gender inequalities are well known to us: women earn less, have lower pensions, are blocked from promotion, and work in lower-paying sectors. This overlaps with the work-house conflict and the disproportionately greater involvement of women in unpaid domestic work. Maintaining these inequalities leads to a waste of women's potential, only partially using their education, qualifications and creativity, which play a key role in functioning in the labor market, its development and in creating new jobs.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Ms. President! Ladies and gentlemen, as the shadow rapporteur for the European People's Party, I can only say good things about my colleague López's working method and his transparent approach. The draft report itself is fundamentally for noble purposes, to create jobs, increase social security and create common European funds to finance social programs. However, in connection with the latter, the draft report also contains a number of initiatives with a vague financial commitment, which would currently be irresponsible to vote on. I welcome the fact that important elements for the People's Party have also been adopted in the joint work, but not all of them. One such example is our proposal that competitiveness aspects should also be taken into account when measuring inequalities and social problems. All in all, I consider it a great achievement to say that European Union funds should not be taken away from countries with spectacularly improving performance just because they outperform other Member States from domestic sources. In Hungary, for example, youth unemployment has also fallen dramatically, but this should not be a reason to take away funding from the Youth Guarantee prematurely. I ask the political groups to strive for the adoption of a balanced text in tomorrow's vote, not to promise irresponsibly, but to make full use of the means at our disposal for good purposes.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the rapporteur has clearly stated that rising inequalities are today threatening the very future of the European project, eroding its legitimacy and damaging trust in the European Union as an engine of social progress. Before 2008, the EU made some big leaps forward in terms of economic integration, but the financial crisis after 2008 led to a significant decline in relative income levels in the European periphery, while core Member States were generally more resilient. However, there is a broader backdrop to the whole issue of inequalities: namely, in general, in recent years, billionaires’ fortunes have grown by an average of 7-8% per year, while total wealth has grown at just 3% annually. Globalisation, deregulation and declining taxes have all been factors, but the other important factor has been the rise of a far-flung, global, cross-border wealth-management industry – so-called – dedicated to avoiding taxation of the wealthiest. The richest 1% of the world’s population now owns more than half of global wealth and the top 10% owns about 90%, while data suggest that most of the gains at the top are coming at the expense of the rest of the population. What is more, the wealthy use the power that accompanies their money to exert political influence and reduce taxes and regulation. I would like to highlight three main lines of action among the many that the rapporteur has indicated in his report. First, enhanced social dialogue and collective bargaining for determining wages, recalling the fact that the right of collective bargaining and action is fundamental and that the decline in the bargaining power of workers and trade unions must be reversed. Second, a call to the Commission to put forward initiatives to remove any kind of gender pay gap, setting penalties for workplaces that violate the right to equality by establishing different wages for identical job categories. Third, both the Commission and Member States must finally take real action against tax avoidance and tax fraud, as one of the key means of reducing drastic economic inequalities.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Thank you, chairman. Ladies and gentlemen, I fully agree that greater equality and upward convergence should be a priority. Great inequality harms us all. It slows down economic growth and employment. But the way in which this report proposes to tackle inequality is wrong. First, the answer to inequality is not an ever-increasing Europeanization. For example, the rapporteur wants a European minimum income scheme, a European unemployment scheme, a European directive on work-life balance, you name it. For example, this report does not respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. When the member states have to accept social uniformity, they cannot take sufficient account of the needs of their own citizens - certainly given the scarce resources. This has the inevitable consequence of alienating citizens even further from Europe. Do we want that? Second, I regret the repeated condemnation of atypical work. No, we absolutely must not create working poor. But having a job is still the best guarantee against poverty. Atypical employment contracts allow people who would otherwise fall out of the work boat to get to work. Creating flexibility in the labor market creates opportunities and I strongly believe in giving people opportunities, of course in combination with a good social safety net when necessary. Finally, I regret that the Youth Employment Initiative does not succeed in helping young people to find work in a structural way, but actually leads to the opposite. Indeed, it removes the incentives for Member States and regions to seriously reform their labor markets and, moreover, does not address the structural causes of youth unemployment. We just need targeted and fundamental solutions to stimulate job creation and growth. I regret that the report has taken a different path. Thanks you.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, inequalities are finally coming to occupy Parliament. And it is good news. I congratulate everyone who has worked on it, because they have achieved three things. It is true that it is a text that is lost a lot in the old social recipes, of which we have already spoken in the social pillar, which we repeat every time a river passes through here —and one passes through here—, okay, and it is It is true that inequalities will never be fixed by the labor market —the labor market is an instrument to adjust what exists—, but this text that I am going to support and that ALDE is going to support mostly has three fundamental advantages. The first is to bring the issue of inequalities to the heart of Parliament, because that unequal exit from the crisis in which not everyone is making the same sacrifices, that exit is undermining the citizens' belief in Europe. We have to tell them that we are going to take care now, that it seems that we have come out of it, that there is a greater individual cohesion between people at the income level. Second, what it says, and it is very important apart from all social recipes, is that inequalities depend on economic policies. There are the structures: fiscal policy, tax policy, income policy, trade policy, industrial policy, investment policy. And, finally, it says that the measurement, surveillance and monitoring of unequal dynamics must be introduced within the European Semester. That is the great message.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, this report is another indirect admission of this Parliament that the huge increase in social inequalities is a result of neoliberal austerity policies. We therefore welcome the report's intention, both for the improvement of working and social conditions and for the strengthening of the welfare state and social protection. The proposals for universal access to health, education and social benefits, based on the ILO proposals, are very encouraging. As a group of the European United Left in this Parliament, we stand by our position and believe that fighting real inequalities requires a shift from surprise and austerity policies, a fair redistribution of wealth, the strengthening of the welfare state, the safeguarding of all labor rights employees. We need public investment to create decent and permanent jobs and we need to create those conditions that will bring regional and social cohesion.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work done on this report, which my Group will support. We know that inequalities damage our entire social fabric, they are costly to our societies in many ways and the European Union has a limited number of tools at its disposal. Part of the question is whether it is using the tools it has got as effectively as it might. I think all of us welcome the idea of the social pillar, we would just like to see something a bit less flimsy, which will, we hope, be more sustainable. We also need to look at how we relate tackling inequalities to our commitments on the Sustainable Development Goals because they link with this report in many areas: on gender equality, on decent work, on poverty reduction and many others.  There is an obvious need, as we all acknowledge, to tackle extreme poverty. I think many of us are still affronted by the fact that the European Union has so many food banks because people cannot afford to feed themselves and their families. We need to look at how we use the European Semester as a way of moving forward on this social inequalities agenda. Many Members have spoken about tax justice and it is true that the tax justice agenda is a crucial part of closing the gap. It provides additional monies for essential social investment, along with better targeting of the EU money we have available. We should be looking at the creation of decent work. It is scandalous that we are seeing a growth in in-work poverty, so issues such as the living wage are becoming essential. Health and care, the green economy, education and lifelong learning are areas ripe for increased investment, as is the social inclusion agenda. Part of that, of course, is making sure everybody has an equal opportunity in society, and that is where the anti-discrimination agenda becomes really important.

name: Laura AGEA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to my colleague López for the work he has presented. Inequalities: let's start with numbers that must start to make us think, but more than anything else to make us act. Oxfam states that eight people in the world today hold the wealth of the poorest half of the world's population. That is, in the hands of eight people, today in the world, there is the same wealth that three and a half billion people have. This means inequality, it means that we have created an abyss that separates very few rich people from all the rest of people living in absolute poverty. So the question we must ask ourselves is that it is time to stop talking, it is time to start with concrete, effective and immediate actions. I am sorry, Commissioner Hogan, but I must tell you that we are no longer in time to see whether our plans to take care of children living in absolute poverty are more or less effective. Yesterday we should have applied them, yesterday we should have taken care of the children who live in absolute poverty, because the example of Greece and the example of Italy are there for all to see. Either we start today, yesterday, to take concrete action to resolve this gap, to resolve this social carnage with wealth redistribution policies, or we will have failed, or our presence here, our work here, our commitment here are totally, completely and absolutely useless and we shouldn't even have the courage to introduce ourselves to our citizens and say that we are working for them if we fail to feed our children. As a parent, I find it ignoble that this European Union does not know how to have the courage to bridge a gap that is undeniable. We need redistributive wealth policies, we need to heal this absolute void between the few rich and the millions of poor, we need a guaranteed minimum income that heals poverty, we need effective expansive policies that create jobs and allow people to live in dignity.We owe this in compliance with our mandate, but in compliance with the 500 million citizens who expect our concrete, effective and decisive work.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the objective of the López report is to seek to sensitize the Commission on economic inequalities in the European Union. Vast ambition, because the areopagus of Brussels has little interest in the poor. But the report does not keep its promises. He betrays the cause of the poor that he claims to defend. He betrays it by hiding the responsibility of European austerity policies in the production of poverty, because it is indeed the ultra-liberalism of the Union which condemns the weakest to precariousness and misery. By doing so, he strengthens the parties he calls populist in their nationalist struggle. Without having the courage to make the Union take responsibility for poverty, the catalog of good intentions it unfolds is not credible. Ultimately, the López report is indicative of European blindness in social matters. The European Union does not want to look its poor in the face.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Ms. President! The motion refers to a report which provides an overview of the position of governments and the social partners on the principle of "equal pay for equal work". The most serious of the inequalities is the wage gap between the central countries and the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. This is the reason for the migration from east to west. This is bad for a worker forced to leave his homeland, and bad for a host country where it causes social tension. That is why the Jobbik for Hungary Movement launched the European Citizens' Initiative, which aims to catch up with wages, and has found partners in seven countries. The Commission has accepted the initiative. A tool for catching up could be a new cohesion policy that supports human resource development and high value-added businesses, as this could be the basis for raising wages.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Madam President! The worrying trend towards inequality in income, educational opportunities, career advancement and retirement planning has led to outrage, frustration and even anger. The result is a surge in populists and extremists in some Member States. We counteract your dull slogans with concrete changes. Firstly, the EU has clear concepts and, secondly, effective instruments. One of the foundations is our European social model. Economic dynamism of the markets is combined with social equilibrium. It is about equal opportunities, solidarity with the disadvantaged, the creation of quality jobs, the fight against poverty and exclusion. The Europe 2020 strategy aims to significantly increase the employment rate, significantly reduce the number of early school leavers and further reduce the risk of poverty. Implementation also includes fine-tuning the European Semester, Commissioner. In addition to assessing economic growth and structural reforms on the one hand, social components should also be taken into account. And the EFSI? It should certainly help the small and medium-sized enterprises significantly, on the other hand the promotion of education and training. Another ambitious idea is the youth guarantee. Yes, it led to the youth employment initiative. After initial difficulties, the first concrete successes can be seen. I hope that we will succeed in further increasing the funds. But I do not consider the call for Europe-wide unemployment insurance to be acceptable, Mr rapporteur. We have often enough rejected these automatic stabilizers by a majority. They are the entry into a transfer union; we can't hold out. I think it is much more important that the European Social Fund is better equipped. It has been shown to promote social integration, stable employment, integration in the labor market and access to lifelong learning. So we have stable instruments.We want to successfully fight against inequality and create social cohesion.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe as they continue to imagine it cannot fail to take on the human capital most affected, wounded by inequalities and therefore a prisoner of its many forms of poverty. Therefore inequalities generate poverty, fighting inequalities means offering everyone a plurality of indispensable tools to defeat them. The basic choice, therefore, is to guarantee the collectability of rights. This is the time in which politics must take full responsibility for rethinking its development model, focusing on the issue of the dignity of people and the value of human capital, without dwelling on the convenient reading that binds, in a relationship cause-effect, the impoverishment of opportunities due to the economic crisis. This is therefore the time to decide not to contract public spending, but to reorient it to guarantee rights, fight inequalities, fight poverty. This is the time that leads us to generate a new feeling of community within an idea of ​​social cohesion that binds the public supply chain to the actors of the territory, to think of new models of welfare in the workplace and in the places of life, for respond to the demand for accessibility to new lifestyles, treatment and prevention, at every age of life and in every corner of Europe, to allow every child and every girl to grow in the awareness of being able to compete as an adult in a scenario that we want more and more generous with opportunities for everyone, imagining being able to build their own life project through work, certainly equally paid, but of quality and safe. In short, the Europe of sustainable and inclusive development and growth can only start from here, from the Europe of opportunities for all and for all.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Madam President!The report required a lot of painstaking work.For this a special thanks to the rapporteur, Mr López.Eliminating social disparities in order to improve economic growth along with the creation of new jobs is the right idea.This is our goal.However, I cannot agree with many of the provisions of this report proposing, inter alia,establishing a European Pillar of Social Rights, introducing a common European labor market, introducing a harmonized minimum income in the European Union, and building a global financial register.This is not the competence of the European Union.The competences of the Member States, which include social policy, should be left to the Member States.Otherwise, these proposals will be a source of confusion and conflict more than an argument for growth and job creation.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, the at-risk-of-poverty rate is unacceptably high in the EU at 24%. We face the phenomena of long-term unemployment and the working poor. I call on the Commission to use more actively the European Semester procedure to ensure full implementation of active labour market measures. Regrettably too many country-specific recommendations are not fulfilled by Member States.  I support the idea to create an EU Human Capital Fund as a more flexible and efficient instrument compared to the European Social Fund. In my opinion the fund should support policies required by the European Semester process, and backup activities related to the European Pillar of Social Rights.  Inequalities and poverty make our societies vulnerable and they jeopardise the overall competitiveness of the EU economy. I strongly believe that social minimum standards at EU level are a solution to the problem of extreme inequality and poverty, including the working poor, and these common standards should include at least minimum income agreements, adequate unemployment benefits and certain public services.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Madam President, this report is contradictory. On the one hand, it rightly states that the fight against inequality will be done by defending collective bargaining, by increasing wages, by regulating working hours and by combating precarious work, by increasing social benefits, by reinforcing and universally protecting services and promoting universal public services in the areas of health and education. On the other hand, he affirms that the mitigation of these inequalities must be consolidated by deepening the instruments that have inexorably attacked labor and social rights or contributed to the increase in inequalities. They are the European Semester or the deepening of Economic and Monetary Union, instruments that, under the social washing that is being prepared for them, with the hoax that is the European pillar of social rights and that includes concepts such as a caregiver license that will push women home, preventing their socio-economic emancipation, they will continue to dig the gap of inequities, inequities and poverty.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Madam President, it is heartbreaking to hear constituents come to me – it seems week in, week out – who are suffering under zero—hours contracts. For people who don’t know what zero—hours contracts are, it is where you go to work one day and you wait for a phone call to tell you whether you are needed in work the next day. For the purpose of statistics, the government considers that to be actual employment. That is an absolute disgrace. We have one million people in the United Kingdom, one million workers, who are on zero—hours contracts, which means they are going back to casual labour.  If any government wants actually to reduce the inequalities and give people back dignity and pride in the workplace, they need to clamp down and stop zero—hours contracts because we have so many problems in the United Kingdom. Universal credit has been a disaster: people have to wait six weeks for their benefit payments to come through. If you want to get people into work, get rid of zero—hours contracts, give them decent, well paid jobs that are for the long term and can sustain a family.

name: Anne SANDER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, inequalities should not be inevitable. They are profound, with a rate of people at risk of poverty or exclusion exceeding 20% ​​in Europe, but surmountable, they are too. So let us get down to work at European level, as well as at national level, to provide concrete answers. While I do not want to establish a hierarchy in the difficulties that our fellow citizens face, I nevertheless want to stress a new form of inequality: it is digital inequality. So yes, for me, the digitization of the economy and society creates many opportunities for our citizens, but not yet enough and not yet for all. We must therefore make proposals in this direction and, from my point of view, three projects are priorities. First, I believe that we must first and foremost bridge the digital divide. Too many rural areas are still deprived of broadband, which isolates these areas, discourages businesses wishing to settle there and thus penalizes those who live there, those who work there and those who seek employment. Second, digital skills must be developed as part of initial training, but also throughout the professional career, in order to guard against technological unemployment. Third, we must question the question of the law applicable to digital platforms, which risks keeping some employees in a precarious situation. I say yes to the development of these new economic models, but this must be done while respecting social and fiscal rules to ensure fair competition for companies and security and protection for our employees. Therefore, we need a fair framework for employment contracts. This is essential. And we are therefore awaiting the Commission's proposals.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, it is clear that economic inequality clearly contributes to financial instability and the waste of human resources. The profound crisis of 2008 was a mirror of this and the austerity policies were a disaster, in all senses that austerity has. On the other hand, economic growth does not necessarily mean reducing inequalities. In this sense, there are priority objectives that must be embraced by all of us and that are present in this report: universal education that understands that the starting points are unequal, a society where economic prosperity means decent wages, the creation of jobs that benefit economy, but also workers, a fairer tax system that helps the real redistribution of income and that is capable of combating tax evasion and fraud. Above all, and it is also present in this report, there is an urgent need to strengthen employment policies, with young people and the long-term unemployed as a priority. There is also an urgent need to combat the disparities between men and women in the labor market and to strengthen the welfare state.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, for the last 30 years, the European Union has joined neoliberalism, implemented austerity, implemented violent fiscal adjustment and created millions of unemployed and millions of poor people; that is the reality. He proceeded to Chineseize wages, because he believed that this would supposedly make the European economy competitive. And what does he face? He is facing the indignation of the peoples of Europe, he is facing a crisis of legitimacy, and he is now coming to seek other policies, he says that there must be a stimulation of decent employment. How; For what occupation? For 24-hour part-time contracts? Improving work under what conditions? With starvation wages? Is it possible for this situation to proceed? The European Union suddenly remembered the welfare state and social protection, while it has dismantled them. He remembered poverty, while he has created poverty. Unfortunately, this is the reality.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, equality should be the central axis of European policies. There can be no democracy when millions of people lack a decent job, suffer discrimination, lack of opportunities and access to a network of health, education and public and universal social protection. The report and the measures that we are debating today would be a good starting point to start giving a response to European citizens if at least two conditions are met. The first is to provide us with legislation in the European Union that establishes common standards in labor and social matters, based on the binding recognition of the rights inscribed in the European Social Charter and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. And secondly, modify the framework. It is incompatible that these measures can be developed in the context of economic governance and the European Semester, since the social dimension is not among their priorities. You have to reverse the priority. The economy must be at the service of the people, which requires a revision of the current Treaties. If we do not change politics, irrationality and fascism will continue to decompose Europe.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Inequality is a very important issue! It is actually a shame that we are discussing this at such a late hour. I hope that at least many people will follow this debate via livestream. A survey has just been published in my home country Germany. There it was said that 77% of people in Germany think that they are afraid of inequality. Many of them are doing just fine. But they still fear inequality. We know that inequality causes economic, social and political damage in our society. What does that mean? Ultimately, this means that people may not be able to fully exploit the opportunities they have, and may not be able to participate in society as they would like. For me, there are three questions about inequality. On the one hand: how do you actually measure it? Second: When has a critical level been reached that no longer encourages the individual to become better, reduces inequality, but rather discourages entire social groups? The third question is: what means can be used to reduce inequality? There are some, including here in the European Parliament, who say we simply have to develop the social systems. I believe that the issue of European unemployment insurance, as the left side here in Parliament would like it to be, is no solution. We should think differently. We should focus on the topic of promoting and challenging. Investing in education is important to give people who are really treated unequally from their point of view, but the chance to independently reduce their inequality. Investing in education, even in the youngest, in young people, is much better than inflating social systems. Tomorrow I will be voting against paragraph 37 too. European Unemployment insurance - that is out of the question with the EPP.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in his excellent report, Mr López rightly pointed out that the crisis gives us, in relation to inequalities, two large blocks of issues: the first is social, the second is economic. Over the years, some European countries have countered the crisis with senseless policies of rigor, reducing social protections, reducing the effect and amount of welfare available, in the idea that the economy would restart in this way, making it cost less the cost of labor, while instead the competition that comes from weaker parts of the world's populations has prevailed. On the other hand, ancient, yet already ineffective, redistributive tools have also been broken. The systematic scandals on the tax authorities, which have remained substantially intact as an element of negative pressure on the poorest part of the European population, those who work and have a dependent income, and have allowed companies, instead, to escape from obligations and loyalty towards the States have blown up the elements of cohesion that also guaranteed an adequate competitive capacity to the economic system. When work becomes precarious and unprotected and individual and collective rights are not recognized, productivity inevitably suffers. Therefore, what we are called to do today is to try to put in place fair and just redistributive policies, to protect the weakest and to fight against poverty. For this reason, I believe that the minimum income is the right tool, it is a universal tool that gives everyone the same protections and the same opportunities. Then we need to improve working conditions, because by working better people work harder. Today, what we are facing, on the other hand, is a world in which those who work are penalized and forced to undergo conditioning that inevitably spill over. on the quantity and quality of their work.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this report, on the content and on the approach, which I share, which states that the fight against inequality must be a top priority for the European Union. We must not forget that the increase in inequality has to do with political decisions, with austerity policies and with the regressive labor reforms that have been applied in many countries of the European Union, especially in the south. And I give the example of Spain, my country, which is the second country where it has grown the most in recent years. Nor should we forget that when we speak of inequality what some lose is won by others. There are urgent measures outlined in this report, such as the Directive on a minimum income or European unemployment insurance, which seem absolutely necessary to us. However, concrete measures are of little use if the European project does not change course. The main objective of the European Union must be to combat structural inequalities, strengthen territorial balance and cohesion and pursue the well-being of its citizens, and it must direct all its instruments towards this objective. It is about building a fairer Europe, but also stronger socially and economically, a Europe that offers solutions.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Madam President, we are discussing social inequalities as a cause of unemployment and lack of growth, and not as a consequence. This means that we have to look at inequalities and see what is the root of the problem, see what are the real conditions that make some citizens not have the same opportunities to access education, who leave school earlier, who do not have the same conditions in professional requalification procedures or in skills upgrading programs, which do not have access to quality work. Therefore, limiting this discussion to the minimum income becomes hypocritical. We are throwing money and we are not solving the problem, because we have to have an absolutely individualized approach here, because otherwise we will be facing a vicious cycle of perpetuation of dependencies. This individualized approach must be based, in the first place, on the access and the localized action of psychologists, teachers, technicians of social action, which is complementary to the means of financial assistance. It is necessary to include and hold responsible, also to hold Member States responsible. We cannot limit support for the most disadvantaged to the exercise of charity, but by activating genuine mechanisms of European solidarity that consider citizens as unique individuals, with the aim of social integration. Support for the most disadvantaged is not charity, it is inclusion, and inequalities are not fatalities. We want to work in that direction.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, when there are inequalities there can be no social justice, and when there is no social justice there can be no fully functioning democracy. Growing inequality is not only a loss to economic potential, as this report brilliantly demonstrates, it is also at the root of the rising populism and extremism that sows division in our communities and threatens European values.  Years of austerity politics have only made things worse, in particular in my country, as well as in Greece, Portugal, Spain and Ireland. I want to highlight the particular situation of women, who are more impacted by public cuts and are at higher risk of poverty and precariousness. In addition, they face multiple discrimination. However, the economic potential of women can be unlocked across Europe through anti-discrimination measures and ambitious and efficient social policies. I also want to reiterate that the number of children living in, or at risk of, poverty in our societies in 2017 is simply shameful. We need to adopt the EU Child Guarantee now, a guarantee that I have fought for in this House. Fighting inequalities can boost job creation and sustainable growth. We must include, therefore, a proper welcome for newcomers, refugees and asylum seekers, and include them in the labour market as part of the strategy. Combating inequalities must mobilise all EU instruments, including the European Semester, the EU structural and investment funds and the Youth Employment Initiative and Youth Guarantee, and we must also be ready to apply the European Pillar of Social Rights and have recourse to the European Solidarity Corps. We, as decision makers, need to mainstream this shared goal in our work across various policy areas, in a coordinated manner: working in silos is no longer the solution. The report demonstrates the importance of clear convergence between our duty as humans and our economic interest. The question is, therefore, what are we still waiting for?

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, increased inequality bears direct social costs: it reduces access to labour markets, decreases social mobility, hinders social inclusion and cohesion, and limits the self-fulfilling potential of individuals. It also undermines economic development. It also hampers productivity, especially if those with low incomes suffer poor health or if they do not have adequate access to education.   Worryingly, inequality has been on the rise recently. This is why it is so important that we deal with all factors determining it, such as the changes in the global economy, regional variations in competitiveness or the lack of structural reforms. Devising a cure to such problems also demands that we correctly identify where responsibilities lie, what are the measures Member States are responsible for and best placed to take, which are the areas where the EU can give effective support, how we avoid moral hazard, and how we avoid discouraging individual self-reliance.   Even though it does not always succeed in this task, the report has the merit of listing a great number of sectors where it is imperative to act in order to reduce inequality. Key among these, in my opinion, is education. If we want to lay the groundwork for more equal societies and economic success, the first thing we should do is to guarantee well-funded public education and lifelong learning systems.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, first, I would like to congratulate my excellent colleague Javi López on his excellent report. It is a brilliant piece of work. Then I would like to use this little bit of time to pick up on two points in the report.  Point 31 refers, as we have heard from other colleagues, to zero—hours contracts. We have heard how in the United Kingdom there are now more than a million people on zero—hours contracts. My region, the West Midlands, contains proportionally more of those people than any other part of the United Kingdom, and the growth in the number of those people in the most recent year recorded by the UK’s Office for National Statistics was 10%. This is a growing and serious problem and it requires legislative action to deal with it. A zero—hours contract is not work – it is exploitation, and it should not be acceptable in a civilised society in this day and age.  It is linked with the second point in the report that I would like to pick up on, point 42, about the failure to apply the Working Time Directive and the widespread abuse of unpaid overtime. There are five million people in the UK regularly, systematically working overtime for which they are not being paid. GBP 33 billion worth of overtime work that has been done has not been paid for. Why do employers get away with that kind of exploitation, with stealing GBP 33 billion worth of work from their employees? The answer is because at least a million of those employees are on zero—hours contracts or in similarly insecure forms of employment where they will put up with being exploited because they are frightened of losing their jobs. That is not the way it should be in a rich and supposedly civilised continent like ours in this century. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Mr Schulze)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I agree with the focus of this report on finding the right direction to combat inequalities. It is based on the assumption that greater economic equality within society leads to greater growth and also to job creation. Of course, I consider it important to focus on investing in education and social innovation, quality services and also business support. We should not forget that. The idea of ​​a universal minimum income is under consideration, but should remain fully within the competence of the Member States and cannot be implemented at European Union level, for example in the form of a directive. Nor can I support the proposal to introduce European unemployment insurance as an extension of national systems. This is again a topic only for the Member States. Unfortunately, I also cannot agree with the introduction of a European youth guarantee, because we cannot promise to be able to ensure the same standards for every child in every Member State here at European level. However, we must support the Member States in being able to ensure the conditions for quality education and employment. That is the task of the European Union.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I firmly believe that anyone who cares about the European Union must insist that the priority be to bring down inequalities on the continent, not only between its countries, but also within them, starting from a basic concept: the European project and the political and economic integration of its Member States and its peoples must serve the objective of recovering sovereignty for decisions concerning social and economic matters. Sovereignty that has been progressively eroded by the dynamics of uncontrolled globalization and financial capitalism. The data clearly show that the crisis of recent years has had a dramatic effect on the growth of inequalities in its most varied forms: income, gender, class, geographic, intergenerational. The divergences have grown more than proportionally for the weaker groups, and it is therefore imperative that the European Union take responsibility for relaunching a social agenda capable of reversing this trend. In a few days, in Gothenburg, the heads of state and government will meet to conclude the agreement on the European pillar of social rights. We must be able to transform this solemn event into a real movement, capable of finally equipping the Union with a social strategy suited to the challenges of modernity. Let's start with concrete initiatives, let's not limit ourselves to listing a series of principles. Starting from the European institutions we apply a more extensive version of the quality framework for traineeships, including a guarantee of remuneration, we finally ban unpaid and low quality traineeships in Europe. Furthermore, this Parliament, I want to remind you, has proposed a framework directive on decent working conditions for all forms of employment. So, on this front too, can the European Commission show us that it really wants a triple A Europe social.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the subject we are debating this evening, as has just been mentioned, should be the underlying theme of all the work we do in this Parliament. A Parliament that, in my opinion, should put the fundamental rights of European citizens and the fight against poverty at the top of its initiative. Unfortunately, we are faced with an unprecedented growth in economic, social and cultural inequalities and this situation is at the root of the enormous difficulties and social malaise that European citizens find themselves experiencing. Suffice it to say that since 2005, income poverty has been steadily increasing and that, according to a report by Oxfam, in 2015 there were 342 billionaires in euros and 123 million people, almost a quarter of the European population. at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The regressive labor market reforms in various Member States, alas also in my own country, have weakened the representation and bargaining power of workers, resulting in increasingly precarious working conditions and lower wages. Social mobility has practically disappeared. To counter this situation it is not enough to resort to redistributive policies, which are however very important, but it is essential to act through a vast set of policies ranging from macroeconomic to education. For this reason, I believe it is imperative to intervene on social spending, tackling the problem of poverty through support for families, guaranteeing free universal access to the health service and introducing a decent minimum income for all. Equally vital is to restore centrality to public policies to promote employment and investment in infrastructure, as well as to improve the quality and efficiency of education systems and accessibility to public services.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteur on the report and on the strategic importance of the topic. Inequality, poverty, unemployment, emigration of young people, insufficiently good social welfare systems, education, health, housing, pensions, are really topics that should be the focus of this esteemed House and all the institutions of the European Union. Much more time should be devoted to addressing these crucial issues for our citizens, much more than exhaustion in ideological confrontations. I therefore welcome the call on the Commission to present to Parliament a proposal for measures to overcome the inequalities arising from economic crises. The proposed plan should offer concrete measures to improve working and living conditions, a positive business environment, which will encourage investment, employment, strengthening the welfare state and social protection, taking into account the specific situation of the Member States. It is necessary to answer how to provide access to a quality education system, youth employment and their better housing, how to provide quality health care to all citizens, income security and a decent pension above the poverty line, how to find solutions to over-indebtedness and prevent further over-indebtedness. I support the rapporteur and the Committee's proposal, and I suggest that much more time be devoted to solving these problems in Parliament.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, I do not think anyone here is questioning the importance of this report. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, all the colleagues who contributed to the amendments and the final form of the report. The problem is that yes, we recognize, there is a shared responsibility between the Member States and the Commission, but Commissioner, we need to think about big policies, where we can influence. Cohesion policy has not achieved its goal. We have regional disparities not only between states, but also within the same state. And I think we need to continue to increase these cohesion funds. Then there are the big problems with the situation of children in poverty and the lack of access, especially in rural areas, of children to education. Tax systems, it has been said here, make a lot of money in these tax havens. We have debated many times in Parliament what we could do to stop this. And finally, the justice systems in the Member States and, here, you too, the Commission, can influence because, if justice were to work, there could not be so much tax evasion.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Madam President, the European Union prides itself on tackling wage and social inequalities and building, he says, an equity capitalism. This is a joke; capitalism by definition means inequality, the capital-labor opposition. But today, especially, there is a challenge. Today in Greece, not in the resorts of the rich, but in the slums, in the working-class neighborhoods of Attica, we have so far 15 dead from floods and the macabre list is growing. This is inequality. You see, flood control is not a priority for either the European Union or the governments, which finance business groups from the bloody taxes of the people and not measures to protect their lives and property. Your fair development is barbarism. The rains are a natural phenomenon, the catastrophe is your policy, which is responsible for all these dramas. So let go of fairy tales, that you will eliminate inequalities. Take action today, use taxpayers' money for immediate relief, complete restoration of family damage, flood and earthquake projects.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, we are all very worried about employment in Europe and we are putting in place a number of measures that are still very insufficient. But the question of gender equality in relation to employment is particularly acute, because it is women who are the first victims of the job market, not because they are inferior to men, but because society as a whole has not yet integrated the concept of gender equality. The European Union must take this issue very seriously, in order to enable women to gain access to employment. Qualification, of course, is one of the components of success, but supporting women in their maternal function is also essential and I believe that this maternal function must absolutely be recognized as a fundamental function socially and be recognized as such. in all its dimensions, including employment, of course.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, the acceleration of globalization processes by the European Union has resulted in a major economic recession from 2008 onwards, which has negatively affected the strong economies of the Member States. So we had millions of jobs lost, there was a significant increase in the number of unemployed and eventually the middle class was significantly eliminated in almost all countries. Unfortunately, in the Greece of the memoranda the middle class has been completely destroyed. Thus inequalities were created in the distribution of wealth, the rich became richer and fewer and the poor poorer and more. States are unable to deal with this situation because primary production has been destroyed and therefore there is no growth, no industry is protected. We have imports of products from third countries, duty-free and without safety standards, which create unfair competition for the corresponding European products; we have an unfair tax system that puts the burden on the financially weak. To address this whole situation, the causes of the inequalities must be eliminated.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after years of economic crisis, the fact that I record in my college is that social inequalities threaten the future of the European project, erode its legitimacy and damage confidence in the European Union as an engine of social progress . While it is true that Brexit has opened a window of opportunity for Europe, reducing inequalities must be one of the main political priorities, not only to address poverty or promote convergence, but also because it is the prerequisite for economic recovery, the creation of decent jobs, social cohesion and shared prosperity. Equality and fairness are an integral part of European values. We need a genuine European pillar of social rights, which promotes upward convergence, and a deeper and fairer social dimension of the European Union, economic and monetary, by allocating legislative instruments to the citizens of the European Union, institutional and financial necessary to guarantee the social progress that must be the next stage of the European integration process.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all 35 contributors in this debate. It would be impossible to reply to all the comments, but I want to make a few general remarks on behalf of Commissioner Thyssen. Combating inequalities is a shared priority. Rising inequalities undermine social cohesion, economic growth and the very stability of our political institutions, as many of you said. As the report rightly points out, automation and digitalisation add to the existing challenges as they rapidly transform the world of work. So, along with the undeniable opportunities that are offered for social participation and for innovation and job creation, they also carry with them the risk of widening inequalities. This debate is timely in the context of the social summit in Sweden, and I can assure the House that President Jean-Claude Juncker and Commissioner Thyssen and the Commission generally are committed to the implementation of the proposed actions that have been outlined by Commissioner Thyssen. The only appropriate response to the challenges that have been presented here this evening is to invest more and better in the people of Europe, and this means starting early on and continuing right throughout their lives. This is the essence of what is contained in the European pillar of social rights. And following the pillar’s proclamation, the Commission, for its part, is committed to following up with concrete actions. We are counting on the European Parliament’s continued support in order to ensure that the pillar’s principles and rights are translated into deeds on the ground.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: speaker. - Madam president; First of all, I would like to thank the Commissioner and Commissioner Thyssen - who was unable to accompany us today - for their words, for their commitment to working as the European Union has never done so far in the social sphere - because legitimacy is important to it - and also to remember that this Parliament has worked together to get here. Tomorrow we will approve a report, but we will approve a report after a year of work, of joint work between the different groups. I also want to express my special thanks for the collaboration that there has been, a fruitful collaboration with the rest of the parliamentary groups and, especially, with those who have been in charge of this issue. And it must be said because we approved - we hope to approve - this report tomorrow, at a very special moment, just a few days after the approval of the social pillar, at a summit of the European Union, with a firm commitment from the three institutions for a route that defends, recognizes and protects the social rights of European citizens. So it is in our power that tomorrow we send a strong, joint message from all or the majority, from the vast majority of political groups in this regard, because otherwise it would not be understood and it would also be tarnished by the messages that the rest of institutions will send in a few days. That said, inequality, because it challenges us socially, morally, ethically; inequality, because we have learned that it works, that it acts as a solvent of trust between citizens, and between citizens and the European institutions; inequality, because, as we have learned, the fight against inequality favors sustainable, lasting growth; and inequality, because fighting it is the best way to recognize and combat the anxieties, uncertainties and fears that run through the hearts of Europe, and it is the best way to regain their confidence in these institutions.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 16 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - The radicalization and increase in xenophobia in the individual Member States of the European Union is one of the consequences of the continuing dissatisfaction caused by significant property inequalities within society. This trend has deepened even more as a result of the economic crisis and the ensuing right-wing austerity measures that Europe has been forced to face in recent years. At the same time, neither European nor national institutions have so far been able to respond vigorously to the problem of growing inequality. Insufficient support for the middle class and the widening scissors between the poor and the rich are proving to be the cause of growing frustration and the strengthening of extremist political forces. Reducing property and income inequality must be a priority of economic and social policies at all levels. At the same time, it is necessary to closely monitor whether it is being fulfilled. The measures must also include further employment support aimed primarily at young people or the long-term unemployed.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - The report on combating inequality as a factor for jobs and growth addresses the growing income and wealth gap between the most and least economically beneficial entities. The report seeks to raise the issue of inequality as a top priority at European level and proposes to reduce it by combating poverty and social exclusion, but also by improving living and working conditions and active labor market policies or strengthening trade union and workers' rights. Given that one of the main reasons for the widening income gap is the rise in unemployment, the report proposes strengthening key employment policies, focusing on two particularly vulnerable groups: young people and the long-term unemployed. Strengthening and modernizing the welfare state and the social protection we want to provide to our citizens is crucial to tackling inequality. The fight against poverty, especially among young people and children, explains one of the biggest concerns when we face the consequences of inequality, not only from a social point of view, but also in terms of future potential. Addressing gender inequalities so that everyone in the labor market operates on an equal footing will reduce inequalities and have a positive impact on sustainable growth. Finally, tax systems are crucial to the redistribution process if they are well designed and functioning properly. The importance of the fight against fraud must be emphasized, which in today's world is a task of international coordination and regulation that must be given a higher priority on the European political agenda.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: written. - The social summit will take place in Gothenburg on Friday. A summit that will hopefully be known in retrospect as one of the markers in which we say goodbye to an EU where it is all about market and currency. Indeed, this adage has led to inequality between Europeans increasing both within and between Member States. That is why I would like to compliment my colleague López. Partly thanks to him, inequality among European is on our agenda. For years it has been a thorn in my side that youth unemployment is sky-high in a number of Member States. A lost second generation threatens. I can fully support increasing funding to combat this, as López wants. The same is true of his call to limit zero-hour contracts as, in my opinion, this creates uncertain revenues and thus increases inequality. His appeal that collective bargaining really is an EU right is unfortunately necessary in view of all precarious employment contracts. The EU is at a crossroads. We must turn towards a social Europe. A summit will not reduce unemployment, increase wages and combat poverty. That requires concrete action!

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - The fight against inequalities is definitely needed, because they inhibit the proper, sustainable development of society. However, we cannot allow the slogans calling for greater social equality to also openly violate the competences of the Member States, which include issues of social policy. The European Union is not empowered to harmonize social policy, introduce the pillar of social rights, or manage welfare systems. The acquis communautaire does not entitle the Union to harmonize a minimum income in the European Union and, going further, to introduce a European insurance system. Tax matters are also a Member State competence. Eliminating social disparities in order to improve economic growth is a matter of great importance, but here, in my opinion, under the banner of establishing social equality, it enters the domain of the Member States, violating the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: written. - The fight against inequalities has to be faced from a triple point of view that analyzes the economic, social and territorial aspects. To end inequalities, the first thing is to ensure that European citizens have equal opportunities throughout their lives, regardless of where they live. It must be borne in mind that economic inequality is the main result of unemployment and that to reduce it, we have to act on the root of the problem. In the EU there are too many people living at risk of poverty and exclusion that we have to integrate, in particular to break this cycle of poverty from which it is so difficult to break out. On the one hand, it is necessary to favor the environment for the establishment of companies and promote labor policies that promote integration and permanence in the labor market. On the other hand, we need strong public finance systems that support those most in need and that guarantee equal opportunities. We have to combine active and passive policies to obtain lasting results instead of measures that indiscriminately increase public spending, threatening the sustainability of the welfare system

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- One of the main challenges today is the need to address the continuing widening of the income and wealth gap.Deepening inequality increases poverty, affects the most vulnerable groups and naturally increases dissatisfaction.A key means of reducing inequality is to create sustainable jobs, which not only provide livelihoods but also improve the overall social and societal status of people.However, I also consider it equally important to be able to obtain affordable and high-quality education that will enable them to better integrate into the labor market.The interest in reducing inequalities must be a natural part of the Union's internal and external policies.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - The problem of economic inequalities is manifested more strongly than before in most Member States of the European Union. Several causes are at the origin of these economic inequalities: globalization; changes in the labor market and in particular the precariousness of jobs; the development of technologies and in particular robotization; the economic crisis and related austerity policies. The National Front has been talking about all of these reasons for many years!
