Our workers are losing their jobs because large companies prefer to produce in third countries, which cost less in labor, and globalization facilitates this relocation. They are losing jobs because of robotization, encouraged disproportionately by the EU, without serious study of the risks of unemployment. Finally, the insecurity of jobs is increasingly alarming. Originally a consequence of the economic crisis, it developed with the application of European austerity policies. Mr Lopez's report seems to "forget" these reasons. On the other hand, he proposes to fight populism which "feeds on inequalities, endangering the European project", and to include migrants in all actions that should resolve these problems.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - This Friday, November 17, the Presidents of the European Commission, the European Parliament and the Council will sign a proclamation aimed at establishing the European Pillar of Social Rights. Equal opportunities, better access to the labor market, fair working conditions, increased social protection and inclusion, these are the various objectives that the European Commission and the Member States must pursue together. While the signing of this proclamation is a first step in the right direction, it will have to be accompanied by legislative initiatives at European and Member State level, as well as new financial means to achieve these objectives. Otherwise, this plinth will find its place in the cupboard of beautiful promises. I am therefore delighted that our Parliament has come out largely in favor of this report on the fight against inequalities, which in my view contains many initiatives to be implemented within the framework of this European pillar of social rights. Let us now turn these promises into concrete actions to improve the well-being of all European citizens.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the Russian ban – EU fruit and vegetable sector, by Czesław Adam Siekierski, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development  (O—000082/2017 – B8—0610/2017) (2017/2950(RSP)).

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: author. - Time is running fast, it is the fourth year since the introduction of the Russian embargo on, inter alia, agricultural products from the European Union. Hence our next steps - a question put to the Commission under Rule 128 of Parliament's Rules of Procedure on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture, which prepared this question at the request of the coordinators. The Russian import ban has deprived European fruit and vegetable producers of an important export market, and the extension of the embargo until December 31, 2018 will undoubtedly cause further serious consequences for this sector in the EU. This ban for the third year in a row causes significant losses for producers in the EU, regardless of the conflict in Ukraine - European farmers have nothing to do with the Ukraine-Russia conflict. Given the persistent volatility of agricultural markets, the Russian ban has further worsened the situation of EU agricultural producers. Given that it is not feasible to open up new alternative markets for the EU fruit and vegetable sector, markets in line with the Russian market in the short and medium term - especially due to non-tariff trade barriers - it is imperative to find a sustainable solution to this situation right up to the end the validity of the Russian embargo. In the light of the above comments, a question arises for the Commission. Does the Commission intend to take further action to support European fruit and vegetable producers and exporters? If so, what specific and sustainable actions is it considering? Secondly, European fruit and vegetable producers cannot be left alone. What measures will the Commission and the Council take to ensure the future of European fruit and vegetable producers and exporters? Third, what action will the Commission take to help farmers compensate for the losses caused by the Russian ban? Will the Commission publish a study on the effectiveness of diversion and shaping? EU agricultural production as well as distribution and demand since the introduction of the Russian embargo, with particular emphasis on the situation of small producers and the consequences they bear? So much for the questions. As for the comment, we should thank both farmers and traders that they worked very intensively in the search for new markets with visible results. Also, the European Commission tried to give support as much as possible, and the funds and resources that helped farmers to survive this difficult situation were saved. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Hogan, who has acted very decisively in this regard. However, one would like to express a slightly broader opinion that the sanctions adopted by the European Union against Russia are not very effective. President Putin, one could say, is laughing, but in retaliation he introduces significant restrictions on EU farmers who have nothing to do with the cause of the sanctions, that is, Russia's attacks on Ukraine, but bear the costs of this situation, as I have already mentioned. If the EU wanted to introduce serious, effective sanctions against Russia, it had many other options, but it did not take advantage of them, but pursues various interests that are very beneficial to some, but not to farmers.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by underlining the strong support that the European Union has provided to producers of fruit and vegetables since the beginning of the Russian embargo. Through our exceptional measures we have already provided a total amount of aid of EUR 490 million, which corresponds to a withdrawal of 1.7 million tonnes of fruit and vegetables. These exceptional measures continue to operate and they sustain the market. The EU support allows producers to adapt to the new market situation and, in parallel, we are working to ensure a gradual opening of new markets for European Union apples by lifting sanitary and phytosanitary barriers, particularly in Asia, in countries like China, India and Vietnam, and in the American countries, particularly the United States and Canada. I am disappointed, however, that the United States has not fulfilled its promise to open the market for fruit to Poland and Belgium in particular, as it promised to do some time ago. So this diversification of trade that we are seeking to open up is developing much more slowly for fruit and vegetables than originally expected.  However, I want to recall that the overall EU export figures for agrifood products are increasing. They total EUR 137 billion for the 12-month period from September 2016 to August 2017. This is well above the export figures of July 2014 when the Russian embargo was imposed.  These figures are no consolation to our farmers who are involved in the fruit and vegetable sector, who still need our support and who are continuing to suffer market losses and income losses. In view of the persisting market difficulties, the temporary exceptional measures in relation to fruit and vegetables have been prolonged after 1 July 2017 for one more additional year, and the matter can be reviewed again at that stage.  The support which we have focused in particular on certain fruit tree crops is important in terms of alleviating market disturbance. Last summer, the budget devoted to the scheme was increased following the peaches and nectarines crisis, as additional quantities for withdrawal were allocated to Greece, Italy and Spain.  In addition, many of you asked, in the context of the withdrawal of the product from the market, to increase significantly the support in terms of the withdrawal scheme and the amount of product for fruit and vegetables. This was done in a Delegated Act recently for producer organisations, and it is applicable since June of this year. This provides considerable additional support to the market. I have promotion support as well for the marketplace, where Member States can allocate up to 70% assistance from the European Union to promote the possibilities for fruit and vegetables right around the world and diversify into other markets. By mentioning these particular issues I am saying that we are doing everything we possibly can, by all the means at my disposal, to help farmers in the fruit and vegetable area to overcome the market difficulties in the food and vegetable sector arising from the Russian embargo, and that farmers are not being left totally on their own.  I would also like to underline that in some Member States, and for certain products, such as peaches in Spain, or apples in Poland, there are structural problems of over-production in those countries, and we have to look at these issues and monitor them. These temporary exceptional measures cannot be considered as the appropriate way to remedy these types of situations and we will continue to look at those markets and those particular products with Member States in order to see what we have to do to address this problem of over-production in an appropriate way.  I would say to Mr Siekierski that the political decision regarding sanctions in respect of the Russian embargo, and their effectiveness or otherwise, is not a matter for the Commissioner for Agriculture, but a matter for political decisions that have been made elsewhere.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, from last August until next June, no less than 52,530 tonnes of peaches and nectarines will be withdrawn. Almost 30,000 in my country, Spain, but also in Greece, Italy or Portugal. I know that withdrawing them is possible thanks to the more than 70 million allocated to the products affected by the Russian veto until next summer. But that is certainly until next summer. That is why I bring this matter to the Plenary, due to the permanent uncertainty to which farmers are subjected. Every year, for three, the Commission announces the extension of aid, and every year, for three, our farmers have waited with their hearts in a fist to know if the quotas and withdrawal prices will cover their needs or not. It is an untenable situation, Commissioner, and I know that you are sensitive to it. We cannot allow our producers to be hostage to Russian tactism. It is a fact that the embargo is hurting us. Also that it has generated a boom in Russian production. One example: while the Union's imports have fallen by 40% since 2013, its largest agricultural company - Rusagro - increased its sales by 16% in 2016. So let's be realistic. The Kremlin is in no rush to lift the veto. Therefore, we must think about the best way to deal with it in the medium term. I have proposed converting emergency measures into structural measures, because if we know that the Russian veto is going to last, why not better protect ourselves against it? I think that a more stable aid framework helps to reduce uncertainty. I also ask you to continue working on opening new markets and I acknowledge your successes, such as the signing of the treaty with Canada. That is a good way to go. I will end, Commissioner, Madam President, by saying that in lands like mine it is very difficult to explain that high-quality products have to spoil. By That is why I thank you for your participation today and I ask you to treat this matter as a priority.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President, Commissioner, for more than three years the Russian embargo has deprived some European fruit and vegetable producers of export outlets. To help these producers, the Union adopted exceptional market measures which enabled the withdrawal of around 1.7 million tonnes. Commissioner, I would like to congratulate you on this. Despite this supply management system, which is unfortunately due to end soon, productions such as apples, peaches and nectarines are still experiencing serious imbalances. Faced with this continued embargo, I therefore urge the Commission to do everything to facilitate the mobilization of operational programs by producer organizations, in order to better plan production according to the market. Our Parliament has made it possible, I believe, to make progress in this area with the Omnibus. These operational programs will have recourse to export support actions in the event of a crisis. They will have to be fully utilized.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are three and a half years after the Russian boycott. Three and a half long years. Our farmers have always been told that this crisis is temporary. It is now the damn fourth crop that we cannot export to Russia. That is no longer temporary. That is structural. It's time to change the gun from one shoulder. The fruit farmers have a structural problem. But you, Commissioner, also have a structural problem if you want to keep your promise to support farmers. I think we should open our wallets to compensate our farmers for the damage suffered. They are the victims. In addition, we must focus on structural solutions. Because it is not the workforce and will of our farmers. Commissioner, many farmers are talking about it. Dramas happen. I do a lot of field visits. Many companies are on the brink of bankruptcy. Farmers live in poverty. And what's worse, in my area, many commit suicides. With us, 60% of the Conferences went directly to Russia. We cannot compensate for this with small exports to new markets. I therefore ask you, Commissioner, to move from temporary to solid structural measures. I will help you with that. I hope that after this debate, Parliament will adopt a resolution calling for real compensation for the damage suffered. I also urge an action plan for new markets. I would like you to speak to Commissioner Malmström about a real action plan to promote our fruit. As Europeans, we can be proud of the best fruit and vegetables. Let's promote those too. I know that the European Council is taking those sanctions against Russia, but I would like you to speak to Mrs Mogherini to improve our agricultural relations with Russia. Thank you.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- This issue that we are debating today goes back to the coup d'état in Ukraine and the Minsk Agreements.The European Union intervened directly in the coup in tow of NATO and the United States, with enormous costs for the European Union budget and for European producers.This embargo has been renewed every six months until today.The impact on fruit and vegetable production in Portugal has been enormous, representing around 15 million euros annually.The aid obtained can only compensate for a small part of the losses.Therefore, what we demand today, here in the European Parliament, is that the European Union compensates producers who cannot be victims of this situation and rethinks its neighborhood policy with Russia.Agriculture has paid a high price for the common agricultural policy, which is increasingly liberalized to the detriment of the income of those who produce it.Do not add this bill to anyone who has already been so punished.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - The embargo imposed by Russia has had a significant impact on food imports from the European Union. Maybe not quite what its initiators had hoped for. Europe, not even the countries that have exported the most to Russia, has not experienced a crisis, but the incomes of farmers and processors have fallen sharply. This Russian embargo was not news for Lithuania. We have also received various export bans from Russia against him. And it has always been related to a certain political context. Thus, although profitable for producers, the Russian market was never forecast. However, it was this fourteenth global embargo that fundamentally changed the map of the structure of Lithuanian agriculture. Due to the huge losses suffered in individual sectors and the uncertainty about the future, farmers are withdrawing en masse from production and are mostly switching to crop production, mainly cereals. The figures are telling: in the dairy sector alone, dairy farmers have fallen by 34% since the embargo changed. Most of them switched to cereals. This is wrong, it is not only less profitable for the farm itself, but also detrimental to the economy because grain is exported en masse. And the export of raw materials never creates such added value as, for example, the production or processing of milk. Such changes are undoubtedly unfavorable for the climate as well, as imbalances arise between the crop and livestock sectors. Speaking specifically about fruits and vegetables, Lithuanian farmers, who lost their largest export market due to the embargo, gradually reoriented, when some people started processing and we could start to be glad that we learned to survive without the Russian market. If not Lithuania was devastated by floods this year! I took the initiative to collect video material from Lithuanian farmers and show you the lakes that have been turned into Lithuanian fields due to the unprecedented rainfall in summer and autumn. So this year’s vegetable harvest was massively flooded and rotten. Even today, farmers in some areas are murmuring technique and tries to dig up crop residues or separate it.But it is clear that people will suffer huge losses.Nature also seems to have imposed an embargo on us.And I’m afraid it could be disastrous for farmers who haven’t recovered after fourteen years.I hope that the European Union will face this critical situation in solidarity and find the necessary resources for emergency aid.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the question asked here obscures the most important, namely the origin of the problem. Why has Russia imposed an embargo on our agricultural products? It does this because of the European Union, its sanctions and its aggressive policy. Europe looked at the straw in the eye of the Russian neighbor, ignoring the beam in his. In reality, she wanted to give a lesson in morality to Russia, to Mr. Putin, that is the reality. And yet the European Union’s outrage is selective. Where is she when the Committee on International Trade asks to modernize our customs union with Turkey? On the scale of European Union values, then, would Turkey be a more respectable partner than Russia? Where is the outrage when the European Union grants trade preferences to Ukraine, a country, I remind you, afflicted by civil war and corruption for four years. Let the Commission stop this hypocrisy. The Russian embargo is a disaster for all European farmers and there are not 36 ways to end it. We simply need to lift the European sanctions against Russia, which are unnecessary.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! The Russian import ban on a number of agricultural products has existed since 2014, and we all felt that we didn't need to discuss it today. We all hoped that this import embargo would no longer have to exist in 2017. That is why I think it is good and right that our committee chairman put the question to the Commission, because unfortunately we have to assume a long-term process. First of all, I realize that I can get rid of the compliment to the Commissioner at this point: he has really tried to make up for this failure, but we are a little bit really the repair shop. I urge the Commission once again - I believe that the colleague is not here. We also suffer a little from Russian tactics, you could also say that we also suffer a little from American tactics. So the European farmers have come into the clamps of the superpowers who, if you will, are making big politics at the expense of third parties, namely medium-sized companies, our farmers. So, please, Commissioner, do not let up in your Commission to ensure that we, as the European Union, normally finally rebuild the bridge between America and Russia that we should be. And, if you will, there is also a lack of common European foreign policy. You said very correctly: as a minimum, of course, when the European Union says for foreign policy reasons: “We are participating in our common policy with America”, the American side also keeps the things it has promised us. We now urge you once again - the situation is as it is, we have to catch up - not to give up. Provide the farmers with money Disposal, because the least we have to do is that our farmers get at least financial compensation.But my second request again: don't forget big politics either.We have to solve the problem.When big players argue, there is always a third loser.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mrs McGuinness, Mr Hogan, we can understand two things through the Russian embargo. One is that third countries use the agricultural sector in the European Union, which makes us vulnerable, and on the other hand, disproportionate subsidies in different Member States, subject to the closure of competition within the European market, lead to some Member States being able to be more vulnerable. -competitive from other Member States. After my meetings with producers of apples, peaches and vegetables, such as potatoes in Bulgaria, I am extremely worried, as they say they will stop their activities. Commissioner, I urge you to do your utmost in the future to use all possible instruments, such as the crisis reserve and state subsidies, to achieve justice. For a single crop in the European Union, there must be a single ceiling of maximum support from the Member States. For strong European agriculture in the single market, the same rules must apply to producers.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - It is very good that this item is on the agenda tonight, Commissioner.Years have passed since the boycott and unfortunately there is no solution yet.The effects for the sector can still be felt.I mention tomatoes as an example.The sector in my country, the Netherlands, indicates that the price formation of tomatoes is still poor, especially in the summer months, precisely the months in which they used to be exported to Russia.I therefore strongly urge the Commissioner to remain committed to reopening the Russian market.I really want to underline that.Commissioner Hogan: campaign for a reopening of the Russian market.Good luck.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, economic history teaches that economic sanctions from one country to another, or from a coalition of countries as in the case of the European Union, do not, in the vast majority of cases, achieve their objectives. But there is one person in the world, one who is convinced otherwise, and who declares that the sanctions have not harmed the countries of the European Union. Is it Alice in Wonderland? No, it is Mrs. Mogherini, who, by publicly saying something of this kind, that is, that the sanctions have not damaged the European economy, is making Soviet "disinformation". This is inadmissible, given that we all know what the data are, heavy, that since the sanctions have taken place, the European Union has lost 44% of the economic movement towards Russia. We have damaged the European economy the most and there are some countries, and mine is certainly not the last since the made in Italy has collapsed in exports to Russia, there is incalculable damage. And of this, if there was justice, if there was the possibility of making the idiots who made this decision pay for the damages, these damages would be very heavy, and God knows if one day we will not be able to make them pay to these responsible, that is to you of the European Commission.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I regret that our colleagues who are members of the Committee on Foreign Affairs are not taking part in this debate in greater numbers and I thank the one who is a member and who attends it, because the problem which we are seeking to resolve this evening is not the sole responsibility of agriculture and is not the sole responsibility of your wallet. However, Commissioner, it is for the Commission - it is its function under the Treaties - to manage the consequences of the decisions taken by our States. You have understood this correctly because you have relentlessly used the power that is yours to try to open up new markets. The numbers have been recalled, this work is bearing fruit, no pun intended, today. However, neither European producers nor consumers benefit from this work. The prices remain infinitely low for the former. This is the case with pears, apples, peaches and nectarines, in particular. The prices are not really attractive for the European consumer either. Therefore, Commissioner, Madam President, should we not, once again, question the functioning of the food chain? Are some players not taking advantage of this situation in Europe? Commissioner, the Omnibus taught us how to work with Mrs Vestager. Shouldn't we mobilize our services on this issue too?

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: - Madam President, Mr Hogan, as all my colleagues have said, we are now on our way for the third year in a row. This generates uncertainty and the fruit and vegetable sector, in some cases worse than in others, is trying to resolve the situation. But the situation is bad. It is true that the Commission has put 500 million euros on the table, it is true. But what is happening? I have spoken this morning with a farmer from Lleida, in Catalonia, a peach farmer. He has received the price of nineteen euro cents, nineteen euro cents per kilo. The costs are thirty-five euro cents. There is a huge difference. He has made a drastic decision —Joel is called—: he has left agriculture; he leaves agriculture because he cannot live off it. That's the problem. Therefore, the Commission has put money into this political problem that has entered agriculture, but something more needs to be done. Mr Dantin said it and I point it out: the situation must be resolved, because fruit and vegetable farmers are suffering, and consumers are not benefiting because we continue to pay dearly for fruit and vegetables.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - The Russian boycott has indeed hit the fruit and vegetable sector hard. For our Flemish growers - and I am thinking of the pear growers in the first place - it is a disaster. Crisis support is absolutely necessary in order to absorb that first shock, to guarantee an income for farmers and to ensure continuity. But that is of course not a structural solution. Especially when we know that a resumption of exports to Russia is not for tomorrow. You have mentioned the numbers, Commissioner. So far, 1.7 million tons of fruit and vegetables have been bought for tens of millions of euros. Then I, and many people along with me, have to say that I have a hard time with quality products ending up as compost or animal feed or not being harvested for that money. That is against everyone, in the first place the growers themselves. I therefore prefer to see us fully deploy our resources to tap into new markets, to introduce and promote strong quality labels, to sell our fruit instead of destroying it, and to think about alternative models that do not overproduction and promote waste. This will only work on one condition: with the cooperation of everyone - politicians, growers, exporters, processors and consumers.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, I am here as the Foreign Affairs Coordinator of my EPP political group. Both I and my colleagues support the maintenance of the sanctions decided by the European Union in recent years against Russia. Moreover, I think we should be prepared to introduce other measures if Putin's actions require it. I recall that these sanctions were decided together with the most important international political partners of the European Union, including the United States. Sanctions have been reached as a result of very clear actions. Only the deputy from the National Front did not see them, he had seen something completely different. It is about the annexation of the Crimea by the Russian Federation and it is also about Russia's direct intervention in eastern Ukraine. I repeat, only the National Front sees civil war when it comes to very clear Russian interventions. Russia's position has not changed for three and a half years, Crimea continues to be under Moscow's control, and the Minsk agreements are far from being implemented. With each passing day, we are also confirmed by the efforts of the Moscow administration to undermine the democratic regimes in a number of European Union countries, most recently in Spain, about the referendum in Catalonia, but they are also undermined other democratic regimes. In this context, taking a step back means losing our credibility. Sanctions, of course, come at a cost. The ones Putin introduced by refusing to come to the negotiating table directly affect European farmers, and I believe that European farmers must be supported by all possible means to deal with these difficulties created by the irresponsible behavior of Russian leaders.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the import ban imposed by Russia has deprived European fruit and vegetable producers of one of the main export markets and its extension to 31 December 2018 will cause further damage. For three years there have been significant losses for fruit and vegetable producers in the European Union, as they do not have alternative markets comparable to the Russian one. I agree that the Commission should promote studies on the effectiveness of reorientation towards other markets and on the evolution of production, distribution and demand in the agricultural sector since the embargo began, but above all, solutions that are of an urgent need must be urgently identified. concrete support for the sector, structural measures must be identified. The fruit and vegetable sector must be supported by increasing the quantities eligible for the subsidy under the new EU aid scheme, the level of compensatory aid for the withdrawal of products from the market must be increased, giving priority to alternative solutions over free distribution and, above all, it would be important to ensure that the deadlines for payments to farmers are shortened.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, at the beginning of the summer, the peach growers in Imathia were forced to dump more than 20,000 tons of peaches in the landfills, because for them the Russian market was an important market and they had invested enough to be able to open this market. The economic disaster for Greek farmers is enormous due to the Russian embargo and they have not been compensated. The farmers had invested heavily in the Russian market. Other Greek farmers involved in fruit and vegetables have also suffered huge losses. Since September 2014, I have warned you about this, Mr Hogan, and I have asked you a question, but you have done nothing. The EUR 123 million you were supposed to have was crumbs for all the farmers. So there must be a regulation, farmers must be compensated from the crisis reserve, there must even be state aid. Understand, sanctions are not going to work. The only result they have brought is to protect the Russian economy itself, the Russians are now developing their own agricultural economy, their own fruits and vegetables and soon they will not need imports. You have achieved the opposite result with this policy of yours.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, since 2014 we have been debating here in the European Parliament the problems that European farmers are facing due to the Russian embargo. Meanwhile, the Russian market is occupied by new producers, mostly domestic, but also producers from third countries. The Russian government used the imposed embargo as a measure to protect its farmers who supported cheap loan programs for novice farmers. The number of such new loans in 2016 alone rose to over 9,200, which led to an increase in agricultural production in Russia. Our fruit and vegetable producers, as well as milk producers, urgently need the help of the European Union and the measures we have now are good, but they are not enough. Therefore, I am in favor of establishing a crisis fund outside the budget for agriculture to help farmers in such situations of market instability, but also because of climate change that is taking an increasing toll. Due to the mentioned circumstances, Croatian producers of mandarins, apples, but also milk, have suffered significant losses in recent years, while their Russian partners have found new suppliers. After the introduction of the Russian embargo, the prices of fruits and vegetables in Croatia have dropped significantly, and producers who have invested in production for the Russian market are in big trouble because they have to repay loans and have no one to sell their products to. European farmers need to be supported in order to find new markets for their products and survive until they eventually return to the Russian market, and for that they need financial support from the European Union. According to the available information on the implementation of measures to withdraw fruits and vegetables from the market, I have noticed that some Member States do not use the money granted to them and I suggest that unused funds be redirected to those in need, such as Croatia.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, allow me to welcome the efforts made by my colleagues to make this debate possible, and at the same time I would like to thank Commissioner Hogan for his efforts to support the agricultural sector. The fruit and vegetable sector has suffered the most from the embargo on Russia. Its extension is likely to continue to cause major imbalances, including in Member States that have not had direct trade relations with Russia. In these states, as well as Romania, the markets were invaded by vegetables and fruits from states that traditionally exported to Russia causing a significant drop in prices, which brought local farmers to the brink of bankruptcy. I therefore believe that the Commission needs a concrete action plan that takes into account all the Member States of the European Union, and not just those that have had direct exports to Russia. Finding new markets remains a challenge for the European Commission. We appreciate the trade agreements that have been reached in this regard, but, Commissioner, please note one thing from the European Parliament: we cannot agree with other quality standards for agricultural products that are imported into the European Union from third countries. Whether we are talking about the livestock or plant sector, consumers in the European Union must guarantee that the products consumed have the same quality standards regardless of where they come from. I would also like to draw attention to the problems that farmers in the Member States face today in their dealings with retailers. Despite the existence of firm contracts between the parties, with payment up to seven days after the sale, these conditions are still violated by supermarkets, and the cancellation of the order from one day to another is now a common practice, which creates major difficulties for farmers. . In this context, Commissioner, I appreciate it that it is the task of the European Commission to order the Member States to strengthen their control mechanisms in order to avoid the situations set out above.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: - (NL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the farmers are the victims of this embargo. The European intervention aid was welcome, but often insufficient to cover the costs of high-quality production, such as the Conference pear. Producing a Porsche simply costs more than - with all due respect - a Lada. Second, you cannot simply replace a market of 130 million consumers. Pigs grow, dairy cows continue to produce milk and you can't just stop the growth of lettuce, potatoes or apples. The result: oversupply in the markets and plummeting prices. For pears, for example, this amounts to 25 percent. Whether it concerns Ukraine, Russia or Brexit, the farmer is always presented with the bill. Fortunately, our farmers are creative. Some have invested in other varieties. They have responded to a growing middle class in Asia and South America and the increasing demand for fruit and vegetables there. With result. This year for the first time more than 10 million kilos of Belgian apples ended up on the Indian market. However, it is of the utmost importance that we also learn from our mistakes. If 40 percent of your exports go to one country, such as Russia, then you know you are taking a risk. However, not all sectors learn equally quickly. The share of pork that went to Russia goes to China today. In this way we once again give one country the power to plunge our pig sector into crisis again with the snap of a finger. My suggestions to you, Commissioner Hogan, are therefore clear. Please continue your structural policy, because yes, Mrs Vautmans, structural policy is indeed being pursued. Continue to support exports, but keep in mind the needs per sector. Evaluate trade per sector and then open new markets per sector. Learning to diversify and invest, that is my credo.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - As we all note, European farmers really were not much to blame for the war in Crimea, the embargo. However, it happened similarly to what happens in chess, they were the first victims on the chessboard and the consequences are still being felt today. Measures were taken, some were also taken. In the dairy sector, the situation is much better today than it was then. The biggest problems are dealt with by those sectors, especially in fruit growing, where these are permanent crops that you do not plant every year, but grow for 20 years and you simply cannot cut a 10-year-old apple or pear. However, market prices were quite low because of this case. We are aware that this three-year period is a period that cannot be extinguished only with current and extinguishing measures, but it is necessary to continue with some structural measures. I therefore welcome what my colleagues have already said is that part of the solution lies in restructuring the markets, and we have been somewhat successful in this. However, I think we still have a lot to do within the EU, especially as we have said today in fair trade practices, because in crisis situations the shortest end is always pulled by farmers, those who are second in the chain know how to cut their piece of bread, but they leave to the farmers what is left in the end. The measure of accelerating consumption, ie the consumption of fruit and vegetables, is also very important, so measures such as milk and fruit in the school diet are one of the appropriate measures. In any case, we must also play a more active, more decisive role on the foreign policy stage and try to reach the end and lift these sanctions.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, It is known that the ban imposed by Russia has had a negative effect on European fruit and vegetable producers. My country, Latvia, is one of the countries hardest hit by the Russian embargo. However, the negative effects of this ban on the economy have largely been overcome. Latvian farmers have been able to find new markets not only for the export of fruits and vegetables, but also for other food products. Latvian farmers have conquered reliable markets. The main vegetable export market is the Baltic States - we sell almost two thirds of all vegetables and four fifths of fruits and berries. Vegetable export volumes to Germany, Norway and Poland have increased. Latvia's economic performance is favorable. The rapid economic growth in recent years also indicates our country's excellent ability to adapt to the consequences of the Russian embargo. Rain and floods are a big problem, and here we expect European solidarity. Russia has not complied with the terms of the Minsk agreement. It has repeatedly proved that it is not a reliable partner. Sanctions must therefore remain in force. For our part, we must look for new opportunities for food exports by continuing to support our local farmers, rather than creaking and complaining as if the Russian market is the only place where we can export our products. Here, too, the Commission has a job to do in helping to find new export markets. I believe that Europe must continue to provide humanitarian and development aid and, within that framework, we must export food to countries where hunger is a daily problem for people. During an election observation mission to the Gambia, I saw that, due to the peculiarities of the climate, fruit had hardly been available there for several months. Climate change is causing hunger on a significant part of the African continent. And we need to be far-sighted, given that the greatest population growth in the future will be in Africa. By helping it, we can also support our farmers.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, farmers are paying the bill for a problem that they did not create without, however, being properly compensated for it. The effort made by the Commissioner, who referred to here, is to be commended, but we still have a long period to go in order to compensate for the absence of the Russian market and to mitigate not only its direct but also its indirect effects. Whoever exported to this market started selling on the domestic market and this is having a tremendous effect on smaller economies. Prices have dropped and the sector is no longer competitive for small producers. The producers in my region, the Azores, are also affected by these indirect effects of the embargo and these too have to be compensated. As we demand for the Observatory of the milk market, at my proposal, it is urgent to define what is meant by the crisis in the fruit and vegetable sector with an individualized observation of the outermost regions. Only then will we be able to realize the enormous dimension of this problem and act accordingly. Furthermore, there is an urgent need to consider the outermost regions in the definition of any additional aid package for combating crises, as has already been demanded by Parliament, also at my proposal. The outermost regions cannot remain dependent on national solidarity, on the distribution of EU financial aid packages. The outermost regions must be considered autonomously. I count on you in this challenge.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, about three and a half years ago, due to Russia's involvement in Ukraine, the European Union imposed sanctions on it, which it has extended until the end of 2018. This was in response to Russia's ban on the purchase and import of fruit and vegetables from countries of the European Union. This development has created a huge economic disaster for the producers, especially the small ones and mainly the Greeks, whose production has been absorbed almost entirely by the Russian market, a market that is large and, as it has been proven, difficult to replace. That is why the European Union must protect its producers and take those steps that will solve the problem. The problem is not only solved by giving some form of subsidy, it is solved by the lifting of sanctions against Russia as soon as possible.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the question about the effects of the Russian embargo on farmers states that this has nothing to do with the situation and the European Union-Russia confrontation over Ukraine. Why does he hide the truth? Why is he hiding the person in charge? Everyone knows that this is the reason why the European Union started the sanctions against Russia and that it responded with an embargo. For the past three years, the European Union and all governments, including Greece, have been renewing sanctions every year, hence the Russian response, aware of the consequences for poor farmers and especially for peach growers, especially in Greece. are hit, erased by the common Agricultural Policy, and by the embargo, and by the frightening fall in prices that it causes. The KKE parliamentary group has been sending a letter to the Agriculture Commissioner for months and we insist that crumbs do not solve the problem. We demand immediate compensation from all farmers for all their damage from the European Union, as it is solely responsible for their dramatic situation.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank all of the speakers who have responded to the questions initiated by Mr Siekierski. In relation to the Russian embargo, you can hear from the members of the Committee on Foreign Affairs here this evening – for which we are grateful that they attended, including the Chair, Mr McAllister, and the rapporteur, Mr Preda – that there is a difficulty in relation to lifting the embargo and the Russian sanctions are going to remain in place. This is going to have a knock-on effect of retaliatory measures on the Russian part in respect of farming and agricultural products. I do not see any political sign that this policy on Russia that we have in the European Union at the moment is going to change politically. If it changes, it changes everything, but we have to be realistic that politically it is not likely to change in the short term. Mr Valcárcel Siso was not reflecting on what I said in my contribution when I outlined all of the measures that are being taken within the budgetary framework available. EUR 490 million has been allocated in the last three years. I have extended the measures until the end of June 2018 and we will review the situation again then. We have increased the rate of aid for the withdrawal of products from the marketplace since last July under the Delegated Acts. These are the issues that we have been improving.  On Ms Petir’s notion that we need to have a crisis fund outside of the budgetary position, we have had a crisis fund of EUR 1.5 billion mobilised for all sectors outside of the existing CAP budget. I am sure you noticed this in relation to all of your sectors in terms of your farmers. This was a significant amount of additional money that Ms Georgieva – the Vice-President of the Commission at the time – and I were able to mobilise for the farming community, and Member States were able to do more on top of that. I take note of the fact that we have not sufficiently replaced the markets that were available in Russia from the fruit and vegetable sector. We have not been able to achieve the type of market options around the world to replace that particular market for fruit and vegetables. Therefore, there are no initiatives on promotion to target the food and vegetable sector which I am prepared to look at. I do not want to give anybody the impression that I have not been doing anything in relation to the marketplace. I have been to China twice on trade missions, Japan twice, Canada, Mexico, Colombia, Saudi Arabia and Iran last week, Vietnam and Indonesia, and I have been promoting all European products, including fruit and vegetable products, on trade missions and to companies throughout that time. I am probably the first Commissioner to get outside the office and into the marketplace to try and replace some of the markets that were lost at the time of the Russian embargo, and I am very happy to be able to do so. In relation specifically to structural solutions, I certainly hear what Ms Vautmans has said in relation to the Belgian situation – that structural solutions are required. But in addition to the measures that I have already outlined and that we are implementing, I will certainly be prepared to consider what the Belgian Government is prepared to do in terms of state aids, in terms of modifying the rural development programme, for example, if it wants to look at structural solutions. In response to other Members here that have mentioned that, certainly if there are structural proposals that we can look at, we will look at them in the context of modification of our rural development programmes. That is an option that is open to them. It is an option to look at state aid provisions within the ceilings of EUR 15 000 per farmer as well. We are allocating and promoting fruit and vegetables in various ways, not just through our promotion programmes, but through our school schemes as well. An extra EUR 50 million in addition to the original CAP budget was mobilised last year, arising from the decision that was made here to promote our school schemes, which include fruit and vegetables. I had the pleasure of visiting PC Fruit with Ivo Belet MEP and Tom Vandenkendelaere MEP. I was looking at the excellent work that PC Fruit is doing there, looking at options and varieties and new consumer tastes and patterns in order to find new markets. Some of the markets that we have had in the past, the products perhaps may not be suitable anymore in relation to these particular consumer markets, and we have to look at options and consider helping in the research area with companies like PC Fruit in order to develop alternatives in terms of consumer tastes and to promote those types of new products. I agree that we have not solved the problem in relation to fruit and vegetables arising from the Russian embargo. I respect the sentiments that have been expressed in relation to that here tonight, but I am also being open about the fact that solutions are not going to be easy, particularly the ones that involve removing the sanctions, which had the consequence of stopping the export of our products to the Russian market. But I do not accept, Mr Marias, that I did nothing. You know I did a lot for your country as well over a period of time. Maybe I will give you the full details in relation to what I did for Greek agriculture in the last three years, including in the fruit and vegetable area, and you might be surprised.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: written. - The support measures for the fruit growers must remain in effect until there is a diplomatic solution with Russia. We thank Commissioner Hogan for the working visit he paid to the Fruit Test Center in Velm, Limburg. The Commissioner then also confirmed that the aid measures will remain in force for the coming years. Incidentally, these aid measures are beginning to bear fruit. The Commission has indeed worked to open new markets in Mexico, India, Japan and Canada. We fully support this approach, but at the same time we request that the Commission shift to a higher gear in order to strengthen the position of Flemish fruit growers. We also argue for the support of investments in the context of the transition of the fruit sector to innovative and sustainable fruit varieties. Innovation and research in the fruit and floriculture sector are crucial in view of the upcoming negotiations on the new EU multiannual financial framework. As European Christian Democrats, we do not want the budget for agriculture to be cut back, but rather that extra resources are allocated to invest in sustainable and innovative cultivation techniques. We hope that the other political parties will support this strategy.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: written. - It has been more than three years since the start of the Russian veto on EU agricultural products. In total, more than 440 million euros have been allocated in aid to the affected producers until this April. Given that the veto has been extended until the end of 2018 and that Russia plans agri-food self-sufficiency as a goal for 2020, European producers expect the Commission to reconsider its intention to end the aid in June next year. We have to draw a clear lesson from this experience with Russia: the need to diversify our markets. I therefore ask the Community Executive to promote trade agreements with third countries and intensify promotional campaigns for the products most affected by the Russian blockade. Trade agreements must, however, be balanced when dismantling tariff and non-tariff barriers, ensuring that they avoid unfair competition from imported products from third countries that do not have the same quality and food safety standards as the EU. If we manage to improve our presence abroad, we will not have to lament in the future for any new unilateral action by third countries against our exports.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: - When political decisions affect economic sectors, those sectors must be supported in order for producers to have a decent guaranteed income.Unfortunately, for the third year in a row, the Russian embargo has generated significant losses for European producers.And because of the persistent volatility in agricultural markets, the ban imposed by Russia has the consequence that the situation of EU agricultural producers has worsened.The fruit and vegetable sector is suffering from the Russian embargo.The EU needs to respond in concert when it comes to its decisions.On this occasion, I call on the Commission to take urgent action to support this sector in order to compensate for the losses incurred and at the same time to find alternative markets that absorb the surplus of fruit and vegetable production.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. – The Russian ban on EU fruit and vegetable imports has deprived European producers of a significant export market. Currently in its third year, the ban has caused significant agricultural market losses in this volatile market. Opening alternative trade routes in the short term was very difficult for all the affected stakeholders. The EU’s strength could still be used to seek long-term solutions.  The Commission must look into the potential re-orientation towards other markets, as well as the evolution of EU agricultural production, distribution, and demand in the past three years since the introduction of the Russian ban. The actions taken up by the Commission to support European fruit and vegetable producers and exporters have indeed been needed and will still be needed. These measures must provide sustainable assistance to these important players in the European agricultural sector.  Both the Commission and the Council must ensure that the future of these producers is safe, with a special focus on small producers. As a perfect tool for revitalising the internal market for fruit and vegetables, let us start harmonising the VAT levels on food articles. Reducing to a common, very low level of VAT could have a positive impact on producers, consumers and the fight against fraud.
